PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Bill of Rights be abandoned. Australians' rights are already protected under our Judicial System. The Bill of Rights denies an accused person legal representation. The Human Rights Commission is the first stage of the judgement being placed upon the person accused. The Commission comprises of people of non-judicial qualifications.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should: Abandon the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will:
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this and any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustified power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject a Bill of Rights in this or any other form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19 October 1986.

(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) prepare and bring in a Bill for an Act for the purpose of ensuring, to the extent that it is within the power of the Commonwealth so to do, including but not limited to the corporations power in the Constitution, that all enterprises employing more than 25 full-time or full-time equivalent employees make at least one work station available to be worked on a roster basis by at least 4 young people between the ages of 16 and 22 on a permanent part-time basis, in accordance with the following outline:
PROPOSED YOUTH EMPLOYMENT BILL 1986
OUTLINE OF PROVISIONS
Purpose

The purpose of the Bill is to ensure, to the extent that it is within the power of the Commonwealth to do so, including but not limited to the corporations power in the Constitution, that all enterprises (1) employing more then 25 full-time or full-time equivalent employees make at least 1 work station available to be worked on a roster basis by at least 4 young people between the ages of 16 and 22 on a permanent part-time basis.

Experience has shown that young people demonstrate a great deal of responsibility in manning roster spots under this arrangement and welcome the permanent nature of the work. The scheme is designed to eliminate youth unemployment immediately and to give them experience in a ``real work'' situation, not a ``make work'' situation.
Requirements
1. Number of work stations.
Enterprises employing 25 full-time or full-time equivalent employees or more are to be required to make 1 work station available.

Enterprises employing 200 full-time or full-time equivalent employees are to be required to make 2 work stations available. Enterprises employing in excess of 200 full-time or full-time equivalent employees are to be required to make 1 additional work station available for each additional 200 employees.
2. Time span.
(a) From the commencement of the Bill, enterprises would be required to produce a Youth Employment Work Stations (Y.E.W.S.) Plan for their enterprise within a period of 9 months.

It would be a requirement of the Bill that upon completion of the Plan enterprises do not employ additional labour, other than of a specified nature which cannot be supplied by their existing workforce, until they have met the requirements of making 1 work station available.
The Bill would provide that nobody may be retrenched to make a work station available.
(b) Whenever an enterprise reaches an employee threshold, that enterprise may not employ additional labour until they have met the requirement of making 1 work station available as a Y.E.W.S.
3. Specifications of the Y.E.W.S. Plan
The Y.E.W.S. would
(a) be worked on a roster basis, employing at least 4 young people on a permanent part-time basis;
(b) be for persons aged between 16 and 22 years;
(c) provide a minimum time of employment for any one person of 4 hours per week;
(d) the rates of pay will be in accordance with the rates of pay for casual work at the appropriate age level as set down in the award for that particular operation;

(e) the company will liaise with the Taxation Department to ensure that personal tax contributions are not deducted from the weekly pay unless it is clear that the total pay level for the year will exceed the non-deductible threshold;
(f) if it is necessary for union fees to be paid by the casual worker, then the responsibility for paying these union fees will be the employer's, and not the employee's.
(g) must be part of the ordinary, permanent function of the enterprise. It should be the equivalent of a normal, full-time, salaried position in the enterprise.
(h) the enterprise provides whatever training is necessary for those persons to operate it at the equivalent level of skill of a normal full-time salaried position.
Recruitment

The Supervisor of the Y.E.W.S. should liaise directly with the nearest CYSS office. There should be no involvement of third parties such as personnel officers or junior managers on the one hand, or employment agencies on the other, unless the personnel officer or junior manager is the supervisor.
Supervision
Selection by the enterprise of the person within the enterprise who shall supervise the Y.E.W.S. must be on the basis of:
(a) positive attitude and willingness to co-operate in the successful operation of the Y.E.W.S.
(b) concern and interest in the problems associated with long-term unemployment of our youth; and
(c) ability and preparedness to discuss and assist the youth employees with
(i) the specific job,
(ii) full integration into the work force, and
(iii) associated problems which concern young people.
Reduction in Tax
Enterprise would be reimbursed by a tax rebate on their company tax on half the cost, including on-costs, of employing a worker at a Y.E.W.S.
This is designed:
(a) to offset the additional cost incurred by the enterprise for training, and the need to pay award casual rates; and
(b) work stations are not to be made available above the prescribed quota because of training difficulties in doing so and tax cuts.
Supervisory Board
A tripartite Supervisory Board to be set up by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations
(a) to ensure
(i) the Y.E.W.S. are being created in accordance with the employee thresholds laid down by the Act,
(ii) that the conditions for Y.E.W.S. are being met, and
(iii) liaison with CYSS;

(b) if satisfied that the requirements for a Y.E.W.S. have been met, to issue a certificate to that effect, a copy of which would direct the Commissioner of Taxation to allow the tax rebate as specified in the Bill; and
(c) to cancel, withdraw or not issue a certificate if, in the Board's opinion, the conditions have not been met.

(1.) Enterprises shall include but not be limited to companies, partnerships, private and incorporated businesses and any other form of public or private business which may be regulated under a Commonwealth head of power.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. Has the Federal Government forced the New South Wales Government to divert funds from other areas to ensure that the English as a second language program is maintained at present levels in that State, despite the Budget decision to cut funds to ESL by about 50 per cent? Has the Minister seen statements by various people in New South Wales in the education sector, including the State Minister, Mr Cavalier, who said that the Hawke Government's manoeuvring is a `desperate way out of a desperate political situation'; Dr Paolo Totaro of the Ethnic Affairs Commission, who has described it as robbing Peter to dress Paul and as a technique of divisiveness; and Miss Jennie George, of the Teachers Federation, who has accused the Government of chicanery over this issue? Will teacher development in New South Wales be the only program to suffer in the Hawke Government's attempt to escape the political odium of the Budget decision or, as suggested by Mr Cavalier, will there have to be cuts in other areas, such as Aboriginal education? Finally I refer to the Minister's claim last week that agreements had been achieved with all States but New South Wales on maintaining English as a second language programs. I ask her to detail the agreements reached and the amounts involved in transfers from other programs in the other States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the reports in the Sydney Morning Herald containing comments such as those outlined in Senator Chaney's question but, of course, I am not in any position to say whether those are accurate or inaccurate reports. What I can assure Senator Chaney and other honourable senators is that the content of most of them is quite wrong. The resources that our Government wishes to have allocated to ESL programs in New South Wales-$4.8m-do not come from any other agreed area of expenditure; they come from unallocated extra recurrent funding. New South Wales will receive from next year in the vicinity of $18.4m which is as yet unallocated. The reason that it is unallocated is that it is a part of the resource agreement funding which is a part of the four-year legislative funding plan. With regard to the States-I exclude New South Wales-Territories and non-government systems, that money is to be allocated to areas of national importance, as agreed between the Commonwealth and State governments.

ANSWER.PARA: During the early course of our discussions about this matter, the New South Wales Government had sent in for agreement by us a number of proposals on which to use the extra recurrent resource money. All of those proposals had to do with professional development; that is, all of them were to fund programs which essentially allow teachers to withdraw from classroom teaching and attend professional development seminars and things of that nature. While our Government considers professional development to be an important area, in the present circumstances it does not consider it to be a matter of the greatest national priority nor of the greatest priority in New South Wales.

We have said to the Government of New South Wales-I understand that there will be a formal agreement to this shortly; certainly there has been informal agreement already-that, of the $18.4m, $4.8m will be allocated to the ESL area and the rest of the resource money can be allocated to the professional development programs as set out in the New South Wales Government's letter to me. Any talk of disadvantaged groups or Aboriginal groups losing funds is absolute nonsense. There was no mention, for example, of any program to do with Aboriginal education in the propositions put forward by New South Wales in the first round of negotiations. Whether there has actually been any claim to that effect or whether that is just garbled reporting in the Sydney Morning Herald, I cannot say. But I can say-I have documentation from the Minister for Education in New South Wales, Mr Cavalier-that his original series of proposals all had to do with professional development for teachers in state schools.

In the present climate it is more important that extra Commonwealth resources be allocated to the ESL area ahead of some of those professional development programs. There may be some argument with that proposition by the New South Wales Teachers Federation-I expect that there will be-since it is intent on placing professional development proposals higher than any other. But that is not our view. I believe it is not collectively the view of the New South Wales Government. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Unsworth, made it perfectly clear publicly on a number of occasions that he considered the maintenance of ESL programs to be of the highest priority of his Government. We have found a way of doing that. When I say that we have found a way, I must say that that way of allocating the extra recurrent money has been available to the New South Wales Government from Budget night, and it was pointed out in documentation that I issued with the Budget Papers. But there is agreement now between the New South Wales Government and us that that is how the money will be allocated. I believe that agreement will be formalised in the next few hours.

As to other States and other systems, similarly there have been discussions with them to the effect that they have the opportunity of allocating some of their extra recurrent funding to make up ESL shortfalls if there is any need to. There may not be a need to because of the flexibility that was available to the other States and systems in the use of their funds. Victoria and South Australia have already announced supplementary funding to make up shortfalls. As well as that, they have the flexibility provided for in the Commonwealth program. Resource agreements have not been concluded with the other States or with the non-government system, so I cannot give Senator Chaney details of those at this stage. But I will be happy to give Senator Chaney and the Senate details of resource agreements as they are concluded between the Commonwealth and our various partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services aware of the recent criticism of the Department of Community Services by Dr Adam Graycar, the South Australian Commissioner for the Aging? I point out that Dr Graycar alleges that the Department's vigorous support for normalisation principles may lead to nursing home residents being made more miserable by having to do things they do not want to do. I ask the Minister: Are Dr Graycar's allegations correct? If not, would he care to inform the Senate of the true position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in Adelaide yesterday and spoke to many people who heard Dr Graycar speak. If I may say so, Dr Graycar is as well known for writing speeches to seminars of that type with an eye for publicity as he is for adherence to the facts, and certainly in this case-a remark which is shared by people on both sides of this House. Dr Graycar's paper and his remarks are a very good example of someone setting up a straw man and then battering him down with a bulldozer. In fact, the last thing that the Commonwealth or the Department of Community Services wishes to do is to have people in nursing homes or in other institutions of that type slavishly adhering to routines and being made to do things that they do not want to do or would not normally do and, in particular, being made to do things which they are not fit to do, as is suggested in Dr Graycar's extraordinary paper.

ANSWER.PARA: What the Government wants to do and what I think most people want to do is, within limits, to make life in nursing homes as homelike as possible. We are not capable of making life in nursing homes completely homelike because, by definition, people in nursing homes are supposed to need nursing care and attention practically 24 hours a day. But we believe that people in nursing homes should, where possible, be able to invite relatives in to see them when they like, to even eat with them when they like, and to visit them at times other than rigid visiting hours, which is the usual thing in some hospitals. We certainly want people in nursing homes to have the right to participate in activities if they choose to do so, but not to be forced to take part in activities in which they may not wish to participate. We certainly do not want people who are physically ill to be forced to take part in activities in nursing homes, or to be forced out of bed when they should not be out of bed. We want to provide sufficient nursing care in nursing homes so that people will not have to do that.

The great value of the theory of normalisation, which was introduced some years ago but which is not a term used by me and not a term in general use by my Department, is that it at least enables us to have some measure of how we are going in enabling people to live their lives as normally as possible, or in a homelike atmosphere, in areas such as nursing homes. The intention is the absolute opposite to that suggested by Dr Graycar. I suggest that either Dr Graycar has set up the Department of Community Services as a straw man to knock it down, as I say, or his view on what normalisation is and is not is a peculiarly outdated one and certainly not the view of this Government or my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education seen reports of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee's endorsement and praise of the Bond Corporation's proposed private university on the Gold Coast? Does the Minister welcome the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee's decision to embrace the establishment of Australia's first non-government university? Does she also welcome the Committee's appointment of Professor John Lovering as its representative on the Bond university's advisory council, where he will join distinguished and experienced educational administrators, such as the Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the University of Queensland, the Pro-Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University, the Director of the Queensland Institute of Technology and the Director of the Brisbane College of Advanced Education? Does the Minister agree that the involvement of such leading administrators of government higher education institutions will ensure the successful establishment of the Bond university? What significance does the Minister see in the acceptance of positions on the advisory council by Queensland's four top educationists? Finally, does the Minister still maintain that the Bond university is a threat to higher education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of the attitude of the Vice-Chancellors Committee to this matter because I had extensive discussions with the vice-chancellors last week. I think the description of their attitude as contained in Senator Townley's question is a far cry from what their attitude actually is. They were quite annoyed to find that their attitude had been described as warmly welcoming the proposal. They have explained to me that they share my concern that the standards and reputation of Australian universities should not be undermined by the proliferation of private institutions that operate at a sub-standard level.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of an overwhelming concern with the standards of Australian universities generally, some individuals from some institutions have agreed to join an advisory council. I think those individuals were accurately named in Senator Townley's question. Their purpose is to provide advice with regard to standards. Beyond that I am not aware of any function that they have.

From the beginning of this proposal and other similar proposals of which we have heard a bit over the last few months I have made clear two things: First of all, it is the policy of this Government not to provide any public funding for private institutions and, secondly, this Government is concerned to maintain and indeed enhance the reputation of Australian universities. Both of those objectives are shared by the Vice-Chancellors Committee.

As I have said to other people who have asked me in more detail about the Bond proposal, I am unable to comment on it in detail because I have not seen it. Although there have now been discussions with Queensland institutions-there were not to begin with-the proposers of this idea have been loath to bring the proposal to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission or to me for further comment. I do not know why they are so coy about it, but coy they are.

Until we see the proposal in more detail, all I can say is that our Government will not give public funds to private institutions, and our concern is that the standards and reputation of Australian universities not be undermined by any private institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education aware of a demonstration which took place in Perth last Thursday protesting at the Government's introduction of the new Austudy allowances for secondary students? Will the Minister comment on the effect of Austudy in secondary schools? Further, is she concerned at the claims that the Commonwealth is withdrawing support from students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the demonstration and yes, indeed, I am concerned by claims that the Commonwealth is withdrawing support from students because in fact the opposite is true. For example, Commonwealth assistance for expenditure on the secondary level of Austudy in Western Australia will increase by over $1m next year; by the end of next year an additional 1,700 students will receive the benefit. So those statistics demonstrate that Western Australia as a State will get increased resources and have an increased number of students eligible for benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been a ground for concern in that, because we have moved to an age related scheme, that is, that from now on the secondary benefit will be paid to 16-year-olds regardless of their level of study rather than to students as they pass into year 11, those students who are still 15 when they enter year 11 will not immediately be eligible for Austudy. They will not be eligible until their sixteenth birthday. Of course, under the previous arrangement, they would have been eligible for the secondary assistance scheme. So we are aware that there is ground for concern for those 15-year-olds continuing into year 11 next year before their sixteenth birthday. I have had discussions about this with Mr Pearce, the Western Australian Minister for Education, and pointed out to him that, as Western Australia benefits overall to the tune of an extra $1m for secondary allowance payments and as a much larger number of students-as I have said, an increase of 1,700-will be eligible under the age related allowance than was the case previously, it is fair and reasonable that Western Australia offer additional support to its 15-year-olds. I am pleased to report that, as a result of the Western Australian Government's Budget, I can now inform the Senate that the Western Australian State assistance will be increased from 15-year-olds to cover all students in years 11 and 12. So there will now be State assistance for all 15-year-olds in Western Australia, even if they are in year 11. There will be Commonwealth assistance to all 16-year-olds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of what amount?

—There will be Commonwealth assistance to all 16-year-olds of quite a substantial amount; so benefits will flow to low income families regardless of whether the student is 15 or 16. I also remind those honourable senators who were not here during the debate last week on Austudy that the families of those 15-year-olds who have gone into year 11 will get Commonwealth assistance. If they are pensioner families, they will get the child allowance of $17 a week plus the family allowance, which will mean an average of $24 a week. If they are low wage earning families, similarly the family will be eligible under the family assistance scheme to $17 a week plus the family allowance. So there will be an average of $24 per week Commonwealth assistance going to support the 15-year-old in year 11 who comes from a poor family. In Western Australia there will also be the State benefit. The Burke Government is to be congratulated for having extended its benefits to 15-year-olds going into years 11 and 12.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Does the Minister or his Department have any information on whether the United States of America is fishing illegally for tuna in Australian waters? If so, what is that information? Has the Government had discussions with the United States with a possible view to licensing United States tuna boats to fish in Australian waters? If such discussions have taken place, what moneys would the Government expect to get from these fishing licences? Finally, has any research been done by Australia to establish whether yellowfin and skipjack tuna swim together with dolphins in Australian and south-west Pacific waters, as they do in other waters? If no research has been done, are there any plans to undertake such a study?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be aware, I am an expert on the habits of dolphins! Senator Powell was kind enough to give me some brief notice of this question. She first asked whether the Minister for Primary Industry had any information on whether the United States of America was fishing illegally for tuna in Australian waters. The answer which the Minister gives is that we are not aware of any illegal fishing by United States tuna boats. Coastal surveillance by the Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy and civilian coastal surveillance have given no indication of any illegal fishing. Senator Powell then asked whether the Government has had discussions with the United States with a possible view to licensing United States tuna boats in Australian waters. The answer to that part of the question is yes, it has, in the context of a multilateral access treaty between the United States and the governments of 16 South Pacific countries, including Australia. We are one of the 16. But no commitments have been made by the Australian Government at this stage, and any commitments which may be made in the future are likely to be made in the context of a multilateral arrangement.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Powell also asked what moneys the Government would expect to get from fishing licence fees if fees were imposed pursuant to multilateral arrangements. I am unable to answer that part of the question. A major obstacle in the current multilateral negotiations has been the level of fee, which would be in the form of a lump sum to the Forum Fisheries Agency, which would then distribute it in a manner worked out by the 16 countries. Senator Powell will appreciate that it is probably a difficult exercise to get agreement among 16 countries on both the size and the distribution of a fee of that kind. Finally I was asked whether any research has been done on the matter of yellowfin and skipjack tuna swimming together with dolphins. The answer to that question is no, there has been no research in the Australian fishing zone because little purse-seining is done on skipjack and yellowfin tuna in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Per se.

—Yes, Senator, per se. United States tuna boats in the region report that dolphins do not swim with target fish as happens in the eastern Pacific. Forum Fisheries Agency supports this view. There are no plans for research at this stage. However, if American tuna boats are licensed, as is the case with all foreign fishing vessels in Australian waters, they will be required to report extensively and allow observation by Australian fisheries officers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA: FASHION PARADE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a report in today's Australian on a Liberal Party of Australia fund raising fashion parade on the weekend? At the event, attended by Mr Howard, the wives of several members of parliament modelled French and Italian designer outfits, but no Australian designers were included in the parade. Does the Minister have the same lack of faith in Australian designers as Mr Howard has displayed?

—At Question Time in the Senate, I suppose Liberal senators and members of parliament are within my ministerial responsibilities in a sense. I am not sure that that extends to their wives. But my attention was attracted to the article by a picture of Mr Howard, as the caption says, wolf-whistling his wife, which is an extraordinary picture for the Leader of the Opposition, I must say. I suppose one point can be made in the context of all this. The colleagues of honourable members opposite in the House of Representatives had a great time last week questioning the Prime Minister about the origin of his suits.
—And he didn't answer it, either.

—I propose to give an answer about this fashion parade, Senator Crichton-Browne, as distinct from that. I guess a point can be made about the triviality of this debate, but I just make the point that, at a time when increasingly Australian designers are achieving international recognition, substantial interest in Australian designers has been shown from other countries and such interest should be shown in Australian designers in Australia.
—In what country did Mick Young buy?

—I was just trying to make a point of a different quality, I would have thought, from the quality of Senator Walters's interjection. Let me say that the textile industry in Australia has created an international interest in Australian made garments. This has been done in the United States through an export campaign, which was widely supported by Senator Archer, as I recall. Senator Archer was also an enthusiastic supporter of a fashion parade put on largely for the benefit of Government Ministers at the Australian Labor Party national conference in Hobart earlier this year, as I recall.
—I am sorry; I was not there.

—But your colleague Hodgman was there inciting people to riot, as I recall. The point I make is that all of us in this country, including perhaps the Liberal Party, need to realise that the textile and clothing industries in Australia can become much more competitive if they are restructured and Australians are encouraged to buy quality goods and move to the top end of the market much more than the industry has been encouraged to do in the past. It is important that this is recognised not only by all Australians but by politicians who are subject to criticism of one kind and another about these matters. I notice that the fashions were described by Mrs Howard as being very expensive. I assure her that that is as a result of devaluation and nothing else.

—I refer the Minister for Education to her announcement of 26 August that a decision would be made on 29 September on the allocation of the additional 1,000 tertiary education places promised in the Budget. Has that decision been taken and, if so, can the Minister give the Senate the State by State and institution by institution split-up of the new places?

—Yes, Cabinet endorsed the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's advice last week and the details Senator Parer is seeking will be contained in the schedules attached to the States grants tertiary assistance legislation which will come into this place this week-I gather on Wednesday.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen Press reports on the improvements in the steel industry and on Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's improved performance? How does BHP's efficiency compare with steel operations overseas and with its performance before the steel plan was established?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fairly regular question that is asked in the Senate following quarterly reports from the Steel Industry Authority. Although I bore, irritate and infuriate Opposition members by continually referring to these things, I think that it is important that attention is drawn to successful aspects of Australian industry. There have been a number of articles over the weekend which report on the encouraging improvement of the Australian steel industry. The last quarterly report of the Steel Industry Authority shows raw steel production as being up 6 per cent over the previous quarter to 1.6 million tonnes for the quarter. An article on the Australian steel industry by Mr Andrew Main in the Sydney Morning Herald today suggests that BHP's steel division has become the most profitable major steel corporation in the world with the lowest global operating costs.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of natural advantages which the Australian steel industry has enjoyed. One is relatively close access to coal for the steel industry's purposes. But the fact is that BHP earned $US350m in the last financial year from its steel operations; this was up 52 per cent on the previous year. West Germany's Thyssen Group was BHP's closest rival, earning $US250m in the same period. BHP's production costs are now lower than all the other major producers, including the United States, Canada, West Germany, Japan, Brazil and South Korea. In terms of improvement in industrial relations in the steel industry, only a week or two ago I drew attention to the enormous improvement in steel industry industrial relations with the significant drop in man hours lost as a result of industrial disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not so good this year, is it, because 1986 has hiccuped a bit.

—There has been a slight hiccup in 1986, and that takes us back to a performance that is about one-seventh in terms of man hours lost of the performance under the coalition government. That is regrettable. I think people know the reason for that loss-it was largely the result of an electricians dispute in the steel industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The other aspect which is very encouraging is the improvement in productivity in the industry. The average productivity has increased from about 180 to 190 tonnes per man to in excess of 300 tonnes per man in one plant and an average of about 290 tonnes. These things are important in improving the performance of Australian industry generally, particularly because of the downstream consequences in other industries. In response to Senator McIntosh's question, I can say that the steel plan is working and is generating wealth and manufacturing jobs for Australians. It is also generating great security in manufacturing jobs for those remaining in the steel industry and that is very encouraging to the Government, as it should be to all Australians.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY MOTOR VEHICLE REGISTRY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Territories aware of the report of the case in the Australian Capital Territory Magistrates Court involving registration in the Australian Capital Territory of four motor vehicles which were allegedly part of a Queensland car theft racket? I ask whether he is aware of the criticism by the magistrate hearing the case of:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . procedures of the ACT Motor Registry which allowed stolen cars to be registered.
What changes to the law are to be implemented to prevent this from happening and when will the new procedures be adopted?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some 27 particular items in the brief before me from the Minister for Territories, but unfortunately the issue that has been raised by Senator Reid is not included amongst them. I have no personal knowledge of the incident to which she has referred, but I will seek an early response from the Minister.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Will she please inform the Senate of the result of last Friday's well attended and high level conference on legislative and award restrictions to women's employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to inform the Senate that the conference, which was highly successful, formed one of the later parts of the package of legislative reforms introduced by this Government to ensure equality of opportunity for women in the work place. Following the Sex Discrimination Act and the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act and other measures taken in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, we have now reached one of the penultimate stages in completing the reform measures relating to women's employment in the steps initiated by the Federal Government to ensure that State awards remove any discriminatory provisions which prevent women from gaining employment for which they are qualified.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Giles pointed out, the conference was extremely well attended. It was opened by the Prime Minister and attended by representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and all States. Participating States addressed the July 1987 deadline for reform-that is, reform under the Sex Discrimination Act, which gives a two-year period for all State awards to be brought into line with the Act. I am pleased to note that the Queensland and Tasmanian governments attended, and they will also need to review their legislation as discriminatory legislation will not be allowed to continue.

The ACTU and the CAI issued a joint communique agreeing to resolve all issues by the end of 1988, and the communique was supported by South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales. The Business Council of Australia indicated that it saw no obstacle to even faster removal of discriminatory provisions. In particular, the ACTU and the CAI agreed to resolve discriminatory provisions in Federal industrial awards. The Office of the Status of Women and the Women's Bureau in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations have commissioned a survey of all discriminatory provisions. The ACTU and the CAI will develop model variations and encourage their implementation, the aim of which will be that no woman will be debarred from any job for which she is qualified.

Some occupational health and safety areas in which there is currently discriminatory treatment have been referred to Worksafe Australia-the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-for authoritative and comprehensive resolution. In addition to manual handling or weightlifting, on which Worksafe Australia will shortly release a discussion paper, the conference asked Worksafe Australia to develop a national standard on lead processing as a high priority and also a code of practice regarding shift work.

In conclusion, the conference was highly successful. I would like to record the Government's appreciation of all the participants in that conference. I believe that by 1988 there will be no case in Australia where a woman is prevented by a discriminatory practice from undertaking a job for which she is otherwise qualified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to the comments at the weekend of Victorian Senate candidate, Mr John Halfpenny, who described corporate raiders as parasites and blamed corporate greed and irresponsibility for exacerbating structural economic problems in Australia? Did the Minister note also that at the same gathering of Labor lawyer luminaries the Victorian Attorney-General, Mr Jim Kennan, called for reforms to minimise the level of takeover activity? Does the Minister agree that these fervent outbursts of anti-capitalist sentiment are a further body blow to rational economic debate in this country which will do nothing to get the Australian economy up off the canvas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the reports of Mr Halfpenny's remarks about corporate raiders being parasites. However, I did meet a man who attended the conference of Labor lawyers-a Labor lawyer himself-who said to me that Mr Halfpenny had described Labor lawyers as parasites, or something like that, during the conference, which somewhat aggrieved my informant. I think Mr Halfpenny, in fairness, probably would extend his remarks to all members of the legal profession and, no doubt in an ebullient mood, would embrace Liberal senators, corporate raiders and everybody else in the description of parasites. But these sorts of things are said from time to time in order to give illustration to a particular point.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that reforms to limit takeover activity have been processed already in some ways by this Government. Legislation has gone through the Senate in relation to partial takeovers at a time when takeover activity was much higher than it is at present. The effects of imputation in the taxation package which the Government has brought down will be to provide some restraint on wild and speculative takeovers.

Those two things together are probably welcomed by most sections of the business community in constraining what have been somewhat ill-considered speculative takeovers at some time, particularly six to nine months ago. The level of corporate takeover activity of that kind has lessened in the past few months. Apart from that, I do not think that the Government has any wish to take the matter further at this stage, or indeed has any intention of doing so.

Takeovers perform some very useful functions in terms of large corporations, particularly in providing stimulus and innovative ideas to management in one way or another. Some takeovers have been of very considerable success in terms of improved performance by major Australian companies. It is quite impossible to generalise about takeover activity, but the mechanism of takeovers has some beneficial effects as well as some detrimental ones. On balance, the sort of policy mix which the Government has adopted to date is likely to be the most sensible and practical one in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that the Queensland Government has failed to respond adequately to the Federal Government's initiatives to help the north Queensland tin industry? Can the Minister detail the extent of the assistance his Department is offering tin producers and comment on the likely impact of the Queensland Government's meagre offering?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Queensland tin industry is angry and frustrated at the meagre assistance of $221,000 offered to it by the Queensland Premier, and it said so in a letter to me and, indeed, publicly in a statement issued last week. The Queensland Premier announced in Townsville last week that his Government would waive lease rental payments owed by tin miners in north Queensland for 1986 at a total cost to the Government of $221,000. However, royalties remain payable, albeit deferred for one year. That is to be contrasted with the Commonwealth's contribution of $1m to the industry in the aftermath of the collapse of tin prices some months ago, of which I think $756,000 was directed towards the tin mining industry in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: It is perfectly understandable under those circumstances that the tin mining industry, as represented on this occasion by the Queensland Chamber of Mines, through its Executive Director, Mr Pinnock, should be describing the Queensland contribution as a pittance and calling upon the Premier to honour his earlier promise to make fully matching funds of up to $1m available. The contempt shown by the Queensland Premier for the struggling tin miners of his State is all the more remarkable when one considers his own, by now notorious, description of the $145,000 loan put handily in the way of a National Party apparatchik as being a lousy amount. Those are the standards he brings to bear when it comes to his own political pay-outs. It is not an indication of the generosity he brings to bear when struggling sectors of the industry in his State come to him for assistance which he has earlier promised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. I ask: Are you aware that yesterday afternoon a number of women from the tent township now located on the lawns opposite Parliament House demonstrated by lying in the middle of the road and, in so doing, caused the Australian Federal Police to close off the road to protect their safety? I might say that, from my observations, it was one of the rare occasions when the women were in more danger than the police. In so doing, the police denied traffic access to Parliament House, which, in turn, denied reasonable and proper access to the main entrance of Parliament House by members and senators. Mr President, will you seek to ensure that such premeditated, deliberate and unlawful acts by protesters do not interfere with the duties and responsibilities of members and senators in the future?

—Not being in Canberra yesterday I am not aware of the incident alleged by Senator Crichton-Browne. However, now that he has drawn the matter to my attention I shall have appropriate inquiries made and discuss the matter with the Speaker of the House of Representatives.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of recent criticisms of immigration officials at Australia House in London about the procedures for the issuing of visitor visas? Mindful of the effect of such problems on Australia's tourist image and our general administrative competence, is it true that people wishing to travel to Australia must wait in queues for between five and six hours in order to be interviewed to obtain a visa? While not suggesting that we should drop a requirement for visas, I ask: Can Australia House not have a less punishing procedure for the processing of visitors visas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that the matter, which has been subject to Press comment after Australian Associated Press reports a couple of days ago, arises because an Association of British Travel Agents conference is being held in Australia in the future. As a result, 3,000 to 3,500 delegates are expected and they are almost all coming from the United Kingdom. This almost equals the average monthly visitors visa figure issued in London throughout the year. This also occurs at a time when the number of visas issued is starting to peak because of the Christmas holiday period, et cetera. Because of this, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs engaged additional staff to facilitate visa issue in London, as it always does, but there have been some delays. I do not know whether there is any accuracy in the statement that people must wait in queues for between five and six hours-I will seek that information-but we do know that on one day last week the Department issued 540 visitors visas. Currently, however, there is a delay of about 15 working days to process postal applications. The Department is very concerned about this and is investigating further whether this delay is just a seasonal aberration or whether long term remedial action may have to be introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly the situation is not very satisfactory if people have to wait for five or six hours. I suppose it is not really very satisfactory if people have to wait a long time for postal visas. As Senator Coates says, that is an administrative matter to be overcome, and it certainly does not mean that we should remove the requirement for visas, as was suggested in some of the criticism in the Press. The United Kingdom, France and other countries require visas from this country, as we do from them. We hope that the administrative matters will be able to be overcome once we have determined the full extent of the delay. When the situation returns to normal and there is not such an abnormal demand for visas, I would expect the matter to be overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The Government plans to amend the Foreign Takeovers Act to allow foreign companies to take out exploration leases without first seeking Government approval. The Government claims that this measure will not affect its power to enforce foreign investment regulations, as rights to mine any deposits found will need official sanction by the Government. At present the Government is engaged in a dispute with Peko-Wallsend Ltd over exploration in Kakadu National Park. The Government claims that Peko's--
—Order! The honourable senator is giving far too much information. It is Question Time.
—I will try to be brief, Mr President.
—I suggest to the honourable senator that he ask a question.
—The Government claims that Peko's rights to explore do not give automatic right to mine. Peko, however, claims that the exploration right--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to come to his question; if he does not I will ask him to resume his seat.
—Thank you, Mr President. In view of this, how can the Government go ahead with the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill before this vital issue is resolved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Matters of foreign investment are essentially ones for the Treasurer, rather than this portfolio. I will see what comment the Treasurer might want to make in response to Senator Siddons's question. I can say quickly that I do not think there is any immediate connection between the points he is trying to make and the situation that has arisen in respect of the Peko leases in the existing stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park. The fact that those particular Peko leases may, on one construction, carry with them some right to mine, subject of course to environmental procedures being satisfied, export controls being granted and the leasehold areas being large enough to make a mine economically viable, is a result of the particular terms and conditions attached to those leases and not something that is true, as I understand it, of exploration licences generally.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a very fundamental and categorical distinction usually between exploration licences, on the one hand, and mining or production licences or interests, on the other. Any new exploration licence issued by the Government anywhere around Australia where I am familiar with current practice would carry with it only the capacity to explore, not subsequently to mine. Subsequent mining would require a whole new application being made for a whole new class of interest. As I said, I will refer Senator Siddons's question to the Treasurer to see what else he might care to say by way of reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education seen the recent Press reports that salaries to be paid to academics at the proposed Bond Corporation university in Queensland range from $150,000 per annum for its Vice-Chancellor to equivalent amounts for academics and administrators? As the Commonwealth will not be contributing to any of the cost of this private university, can the Minister inform the Senate to whom the costs of those high salaries will be passed? Is the Minister aware that this university will be charging full cost fees? Finally, is the Minister aware of the range of these fees, and if full fees are charged, what effect will this have on both the students and the standards of teaching?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the matters raised in Senator Black's question really do come to the question of quality and standards in this proposed institution. I am aware that the Corporation has advertised or intends to advertise a supposed vice-chancellor's salary in the vicinity of $150,000. That is roughly double what is paid to vice-chancellors in our public institutions. I am also aware that some of the claims that have been made by spokespersons for the institution have been to the effect that the institution not only will be fully self-funding, but also will actually be profit-making. The only conclusion one can draw from these claims and the amounts that are being advertised to entice people to go and work in the institution is that the full fees will be very high indeed. If it is true that the institution will be profit-making, costs such as the cost of staff and the vice-chancellor will be borne by the students. The range of the cost of full cost courses currently offered by our public institutions is between $7,000 and $18,000 a year. That is in a situation where--
—You're guessing.

—I am not guessing. If Senator Teague would like to address himself to the information that is being put out by our public institutions in advertising their full cost courses-I will be happy to provide him with a list-he will find that the costs of full cost courses in public institutions range from about $7,000 to $18,000 or higher for expensive courses such as medicine or veterinary science. These are the costs that are being charged, for example, by the Adelaide University for full cost medical students. They are easily checked. They are the costs being charged by public institutions. If, however, a private institution is to cover costs, to offer its staff twice the salary that is being offered in public institutions, and is to make a profit, the cost of courses would escalate enormously.

ANSWER.PARA: It may well be, as was suggested in the Bulletin magazine last week, that if the institution gets going it will not pay for itself-it certainly will not make a profit-and that it will be subsidised by the profits made by real estate prices in adjoining land owned by the same corporation. But the fact of the matter remains that if the institution is to charge the full cost for courses, if those courses are not to be mickey mouse and sub-standard, and if they are to provide profits and the capacity for the institution to pay double the salaries that are paid in public institutions, we would be looking at double the highest cost in a public university, which would be from $20,000 upwards. As to who would pay those costs and what the standards would be of the students who would be prepared to pay, I think those questions really need to be answered in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and for Defence. Does the Government have any policy-if so, what policy-to heal what is now a clear breach in our relationship with Indonesia?

—Aspects of the defence co-operation program with Indonesia have been the subject of some quite extensive discussions between the two countries in recent times. I am not aware of the precise circumstances which lie behind the matters to which Senator Lewis has referred. I will raise the question with the Minister for Defence and give the honourable senator an early reply.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that only about half of Australian defence industry related expenditure is spent domestically? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether this situation is likely to change in the future and what, if any, actions the Government is taking to upgrade Australian industry involvement in meeting our defence needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of this matter to which Senator Foreman has drawn my attention. For a long time now there have been complaints from Australian industry about practices embraced by the Department of Defence and the Services relating to Australian procurement, and I think they have been the subject of legitimate criticism.

ANSWER.PARA: The participation of Australian industry in defence projects is well below the potential of our industry to meet defence needs. In 1985-86 some 45 per cent of defence industry related expenditure was typically spent in Australia but, combined with required offset commitments and exports of defence equipment from Australia, the proportion of defence related expenditure typically spent domestically amounts to about 58 per cent. So of the $2.7 billion spent on industry related activities last financial year, just over half was spent in Australia.

I understand that this proportion is likely to grow in future years. This is because of higher local content in defence purchases, such as the construction of the new submarines in Australia, the rundown of projects with high overseas contents and local developments to meet special Australian requirements. Also collaborative projects are expected to at least double current historically low export earnings. So overall we might anticipate significant growth in local defence related industry activity as a result of these factors.

However the Government is concerned to ensure that this trend is accelerated so that Australian industry can be given maximum opportunity to participate in defence projects. Last week the Government, through the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, announced a strategy to encourage Australian defence industry development, and that includes a series of measures to assist Australian industry bid for defence work and develop and export defence products. The package is designed to ensure greater exploitation of the potential for local and overseas sales in the defence areas and it includes the provision of defence forward equipment plans to Australian industry, a review of industrial capability to supply defence products, defence assistance to exporters, defence offsets priority for exports of indigenous products and Austrade involvement in defence exports.

Might I say, by way of observation, that that is not before time. It will help bring Australian industry into a situation experienced by many other countries with large defence budgets, and that will be beneficial to Australian industry and the economy as a whole. We can expect from that announcement local defence related activity to increase significantly each year, and a boost should be given particularly to export areas.

I believe, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, that Australia has demonstrated itself to be competent, especially in systems and electronics, and current economic conditions favour the competitive export of defence products. We anticipate that Australian industry will take up the new opportunities which this package offers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 20 October, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

This motion is brought forward as a matter of urgency because it is just one example of indecision on the part of the Government on an issue which is of importance to the community. It is an issue which is getting perhaps less attention than some of the other issues which have more immediate impact. There has been a great deal of discussion in the Parliament and elsewhere about the state of the economy. There has been a great deal of discussion about the taxation system and the impact it is having on individual Australians. But there is little discussion on this matter which is of great public concern and interest. The issue is whether those receiving unemployment benefit should be required to render some service to the community in return for that benefit. This is a matter on which the Government did appear to be proffering some leadership. Hopeful remarks were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his address to the nation in June this year. But those remarks have come to nothing. There has been a drawing back from the principles that he adopted at that time.

One is reminded of all those areas in which there is a need for Government action but where the Government is not providing a lead. For a year or more we have been saying that the issue of work practices is important if we are to get back to being a productive country. We introduced that in our industrial relations policy in a formal sense in May of this year. It was pooh-poohed by the Government and we now have a follow the leader exercise by the Government in that it now talks about work practices but provides very little lead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following which leader?

—The lead of the Opposition. It is the same with respect to the need for more flexible wages. If Australia is to provide increased living standards for its people, it is quite clear that we have to have a more flexible approach in that area. The Japanese and others have demonstrated that. We find this Government very reluctantly coming to the party instead of providing a lead. In the area of Aboriginal land rights the Government has failed to show a lead despite the repeated entreaties of the Opposition. It was an issue on which the Government played politics, made promises and broke promises. In no way even to this point has the Government demonstrated clearly where it thinks it should go.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, at Question Time a few minutes ago, Senator Ryan, the Minister for Education, demonstrated her approach to the needs of tertiary education in Australia by damning the efforts that have been made by some individuals to expand the availability of tertiary education in this country by the provision of a private university. I do not know why the Minister should be concerned about whether the fees will be high, given that no one would be forced to go to that university. Presumably high fees will be paid only by those who think that the degrees being offered are worth it. On this issue, as on so many, we find a total lack of lead from the Government.

It was a pleasant surprise to find that, when the Prime Minister gave his address to the nation in June of this year, he took a lead on a subject about which there has been a lot of public concern and interest. Let me quote what Mr Hawke had to say on 11 June this year. He said:

. . . while society has a responsibility to the unemployed, this is a two-way process. The time has come, we believe, when this two-way responsibility will best be served by providing as far as possible the opportunity, particularly for the younger recipients of unemployment benefit, to undertake some community work in return for that benefit.

He went on to say that it was his experience from the Priority One campaign that this was the overwhelming view of young Australians. That is a fact; it has been demonstrated by surveys. It is the view of the Opposition not only that this proposition is correct but also that in fact it is a proposition that has the overwhelming support of the young, the overwhelming support of the unemployed and the overwhelming support of the community. In interviews following that address to the nation, of course, the Prime Minister was asked to comment on whether this could be a matter of compulsion. He made it clear that the operation of the work test was such that, if work was being made available, indeed, people might have to choose between doing some form of community work and receiving the dole. The question that the Opposition would ask about that is: What is wrong with that? Why should not the availability of some sort of work for the community be a reason for not receiving unemployment benefit for doing nothing? After all, the unemployment benefit has always had a work test; it has always been the case that if work was available one had to take that work rather than the unemployment benefit.

So we had a very promising lead by the Government in that second week of June. It took a matter of days for that lead to evaporate and for the Government to go back to shilly-shallying around, coming back to the point where it would accept only that some voluntary arrangements might be entered into and that it might be useful if those on unemployment benefit were given some opportunity to do something on a voluntary basis. But if they choose not to do it, nothing would be lost. That, in the view of the Opposition, is not a satisfactory situation. We believe that it is not good enough simply to leave this matter on the very lacklustre basis that the Government has now adopted of simply expanding voluntary community work. Given that the duration of unemployment in this country has risen sharply over the term of this Government-it has gone from an average of 32.6 weeks of unemployment in 1982 to 48.8 weeks now-and that the Government is predicting a continuance of high unemployment and given the concern of the community and the evidence which is available that, for many, a long period on the dole is utterly destructive of those people individually, it is clear that something ought to be done and that this Government's very soft approach is not appropriate in 1986.

I would like to make it clear that the Opposition, in bringing this matter forward, understands that in dealing with the unemployed we are dealing with a very varied group. I suppose any member of parliament who keeps an electorate office would know that among the unemployed there are many people who are desperately concerned about being out of work and who spend a great deal of trouble and effort trying to bring themselves back into full time employment. Many dreadful experiences come before us as individuals of people who are being put in a very difficult personal situation by the unavailability of work. That is one side of the coin. The other side of the coin is the sort of evidence which has been brought out in anecdotal form both by business people who approach us and by the media. Recent examples of that have appeared in the Weekend Australian, which reported on people in receipt of unemployment benefit at Airlie Beach in north Queensland. That is merely one example of the sort of thing which is frequently brought to the attention of members of parliament. More importantly, it is an example of the sort of thing which is well known to many people in Australia. Many individuals know that there are those other unemployed, those for whom the dole or unemployment benefit is seen as a reasonably acceptable alternative for a time. There is deep concern at the abuse of the social security system that occurs. The public response to the article in the Weekend Australian and to the 60 Minutes program which dealt with the attitudes of people who are receiving assistance in the United States as compared with people receiving assistance in Australia indicates the depth of public concern about whether our present social security system and the unemployment benefit system in particular, while being necessary for those many Australians who cannot find a job, is not structured in a way that is doing damage to many receiving that benefit.

It is important in introducing this debate to stress the point that in regard to the issues which are raised in this motion, which requires no more than the endorsement of the principles that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit, discussion should be calm and rational because one is dealing with a difficult and sensitive subject where there are a number of different objectives. What is quite clear is that in looking at whether or not some obligation should be put on people who receive unemployment benefit, different objectives need to be considered. There is the objective of the individual. The Opposition believes that a long period of unemployment is extremely destructive to the individual. We believe that society should be looking to provide the individual with a more dignified alternative than money for nothing. We believe that that is in the interests of the self-respect of the individual concerned as it is in the community interest.

The second objective is that we think that, with the massive outlays of the Australian community for unemployment benefit, it would be desirable to have some return to society other than the maintenance of those individuals who are unemployed. We see the obtaining of some productive effort in return for that massive public expenditure as being a positive virtue. The third objective, which again is of concern to many Australians, is that we should have some better safeguard against abuse of that area of social security than the checks which can be carried out by the government departments involved. In common with the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who will be responding to the debate, for some time I was responsible for administering the unemployment benefit system. During the course of administering that benefit I came to the conclusion that administrative means alone would not be adequate to prevent the abuse of unemployment benefit. It appears to me that a system of inspectors, no matter how enthusiastic they may be, the system of simply having forms and questions asked by clerks, will never prevent those who wish to take advantage of the system from doing so. One of the great advantages of providing some community obligation in return for unemployment benefit is that it restricts the capacity of people to abuse the system rather than to use it.

In putting forward this principle we cannot get a great deal of guidance from countries outside Australia. The American examples, which are often referred to in debate on this subject, tend to refer to what are called supporting parent beneficiaries in Australia. There does not appear to be any country that we can look to for a precedent in this area of activity. We can get some assistance from experience in the United States dealing with those welfare recipients who are the heads of single parent households, but personally I have not been able to find examples of widespread provision of work in lieu of unemployment benefit. That in part is due to the fact that Australia's unemployment arrangements are unusual. There is virtually unlimited access to unemployment benefit, subject only to the work test. It even includes those who have never been in the paid work force. Most countries operate on a system involving a form of social insurance with contributions paid by employers and employees, and there are limited periods of time during which employees or ex-employees are entitled to benefit. The issue of work for unemployment benefit therefore does not arise in the way it does in Australia.

It is the Opposition's view-a view which seems to be widely supported within the Government-that the structure of assistance provided in Australia, which does not require people on unemployment benefit to give society anything in return for that benefit, is damaging and unhelpful. This is not a view that we have come to in the last few months. In 1982 it was a concern of the previous Liberal and National Party Government that we needed to operate our unemployment benefit system more effectively. We had a very high profile example of the Aboriginal communities of Australia who took it on themselves to make it clear to the Government that they were opposed to the receipt of what Aborigines call `sit down money'. At a time when criticism of Aborigines and Aboriginal communities is very common, it is perhaps worth pausing to remember that it was remote Aboriginal communities which expressed the strongest distaste about receiving unemployment benefit because they felt it was `sit down money'-money for doing nothing. They saw that as being very destructive of their communities. During the 1970s we developed the community development employment projects within Aboriginal communities. These have been expanded gradually over the years, and I think that in its last Budget, the Government expanded them considerably again. We welcome that as being the forerunner of an attitude which basically holds-that people will be better off if they perform some socially useful function in return for support from the people of Australia.

We sought to widen that experiment in 1982 by introducing an experimental program in work in lieu of unemployment benefit. We called that the experimental community projects program, which involved inviting States and local government authorities to participate in a program which, at that time, was meant to be voluntary and to involve perhaps 1,000 people on an experimental basis. We undertook to review that after about 12 months of operation. It is a matter of regret to the Opposition that the incoming Government chose to discontinue that program before it had got off the ground and before we were able to learn from that experience.

We have reached the point in 1986 where we face a long period of economic downturn. On the Government's own predictions, we face continued high unemployment and a situation in which the Government itself, particularly through the Prime Minister and his address to the nation, opened up the possibility that the unemployed would be asked for some responsibility in return for the support which society was giving them. The Opposition welcomed that very strongly, just as we welcome the fact that there has been some move on the part of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its recent pronouncements on wages and related matters. In the last couple of weeks the trade union movement in Australia has endorsed a youth policy which is based on the premise that young people should not receive the dole unless they are engaged in work, training or education. When the trade union movement of this country moves in that direction, it is again a sign of the growing national agreement that we should alter a system which is not serving the unemployed well, particularly the young unemployed. The National Times on Sunday described this as:

. . . an approach which is similar to the Federal Opposition's work-for-the-dole strategy and reflects growing public concern about the social and economic impact of paying the dole to teenagers with no strings attached.

We have a situation in which the trade union movement itself is embracing some elements of the approach we have been putting forward. It is well known in this chamber that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has long been an exponent of that view. In an interview in Playboy magazine some years ago, in reference to youth support schemes, he said:

I think there should be a standard allowance payable to everyone at 17 or 18. It doesn't matter whether you're a student or on the dole or whatever, you should have the same rate, and you should have to do something for the payment you get. You should be engaged in study or training of some kind, or work.

I interpolate there that it is the Opposition's view that there certainly should be for those Australians-and young Australians particularly-who are not in study or training, some kind of work which they can do in return for the support which the community very properly offers them. In that same interview Senator Button was asked:
What if you're out of work, like a lot of people are?
Senator Button replied:
In my view, if they want the allowance, they should work for it.

That sort of positive view, which was reaffirmed in the Senate only a few days ago by Senator Button as his personal opinion, is the positive view which the Opposition is putting forward in this motion. We put it forward because we think it is important at this stage that there be common ground and agreement on that general principle so that the Government can proceed from here to do the necessary work to put a system in place. We do not pretend that putting that system in place will be easy-we believe that it will need a great deal of work-but we think that the Government is in a good position to proceed with the full support and affirmation of the Opposition.

It is a matter of deep regret, and the premier reason why we have had to bring forward this motion, that the Government has been pushed off that principle, partly by the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and the National Conference of the Australian Labor Party. We note that the very negative views which have been adopted by those Ministers bear a very strong resemblance to the rather negative view put forward in this place by one of the Australian Democrats, Senator Powell, in a question to Senator Grimes just a day or two ago. Our plea to the Senate is that we should avoid the sort of inflammatory approach taken by Senator Powell; indeed, that we should adopt the more considered approach taken by Senator Grimes in his response to that question. We should adopt the principle that there should be some social obligation on those receiving support from Australian taxpayers.

That view has been put forward by the Opposition with great enthusiasm for a considerable time. We put it forward in 1982 on the basis of experimenting with it. We believed then that that was the appropriate approach. We now believe that, with the time that has passed, the growing length of unemployment, the continuing economic difficulties faced by this country and the continuous undermining of the social security system by those who abuse it, the time has come for us to be imposing some social obligations on those whom the community is very ready to assist when they are otherwise in need of support. I commend the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Chaney, I believe that this is an important subject and a subject which deserves serious debate. It is perhaps a little unfortunate that the nature of the debate should be an urgency motion, but I admit that the opportunities for this sort of debate in the Senate do not seem to be very frequent lately. It is important also that in the wording of this urgency motion Senator Chaney should have introduced an element of conscription by using the words `some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit'. As Senator Chaney has said, in the past a lot of the debate in this area has been fairly emotional.
