In fact, in the days when we were in opposition between 1975 and 1983 there was frequently a lot of emotional debate in this place about unemployment beneficiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember that the very first Press statement put out by the previous Government on getting to power in 1975 contained a pejorative description of the unemployed as dole bludgers. That attitude went on until 1983, with the exception of 1982, as Senator Chaney said, when at a very late stage a scheme was introduced by the previous Government to try to do something about a few people in this area. From 1975 to 1983 the unemployment benefit for those under the age of 18 years remained static-in fact, it was eroded by inflation for all those years. From memory, in 1978 the unemployment benefit for adult single unemployed people was no longer indexed. Those people were treated in that way by the previous Government, despite the fact that we were reaching a stage then when unemployment was rapidly increasing towards its famous climax in 1982 when approximately 250,000 people were added to the list of unemployment beneficiaries in this country. In all that time the Opposition's present enthusiasm for changing the system in a positive way, as Senator Chaney said, to enable positive effects on unemployment beneficiaries was not eminent at all. Senator Chaney, I know, like all Ministers for Social Security in this country, was concerned at the time about the unemployment benefit system-how to get it under some sort of control and how it should act as an incentive rather than a disincentive for people to work-but no positive actions were taken by the then Government in that area.

Today we still have a fair amount of emotive argument about the unemployed and what they are doing. As Senator Chaney said, a lot of that argument is anecdotal. He pointed out the response that the Australian newspaper got to its articles about the alleged numbers of people at Airlie Beach. Only two sitting days ago I pointed out in this place, as had been pointed out previously, that the figures quoted by the Australian about Airlie Beach were false. The manager of the Commonwealth Employment Service office in Airlie Beach had previously pointed out that the figures quoted by the Australian were false and I pointed out that in Queensland the number of people on unemployment benefit, in particular the number of young people on unemployment benefit, in resort areas such as Airlie Beach is lower than in the rural and metropolitan areas. But we still have this anecdotal evidence given that excessively large numbers of people in those areas are on unemployment benefit.

Senator Chaney also mentioned the 60 Minutes program. He at least had the decency to point out that the 60 Minutes program falsely represented the scheme in America as a scheme forcing unemployment beneficiaries to get work. In fact, the scheme largely refers to single parents. I point out a matter which has been missed by many people; that part of that scheme was the provision of free child care to enable people in that program to work. In this country the cost of that free child care would in some cases exceed the cost of the unemployment benefit and would add considerably to the administrative costs of the scheme which has been suggested by Mr Howard, Mr N. A. Brown and other members of the Opposition. They are factors which are carefully avoided in this country as so often, as in the past, the unemployed are blamed for their own plight.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his address to the nation on the economic situation in June this year, stressed that it was important that we provide the opportunity for the unemployed to obtain work and, where necessary and possible, to obtain some community work. As a result, the community volunteer program, which was announced in the 1986-87 Budget, aims to provide another option for unemployed people to get work experience in the voluntary community service sector. This is in addition to the volunteer youth program which already exists. The new program, which will be based on firm principles, will cost initially about $3.3m. Those principles will be that participation in the program will be voluntary; the program will be open to all unemployed, but with young people as the principal target group; participants will retain their entitlement to youth unemployment benefit; participation will be part time, so that participants will have time to search for jobs in the general labour market; and work opportunities will not be in areas normally involving paid employment and will not substitute for paid employment. The maximum involvement of the community and business sectors, as well as all levels of government, will be sought.

The differences between the Government and the Opposition in this area, as demonstrated by this scheme, are differences of sensitivity, practicality and common sense. What we want is a solution which works, is acceptable and does not divide society. The best solution to unemployment, it has become a cliche to say, is of course to provide sufficient employment in the economy so that people are in normal and satisfactory work. In the absence of that we have to have a scheme which treats those on unemployment benefit, or those otherwise on benefit, with sensitivity; a scheme which is practical in that it works, is not abused by employees or employers and is approached with common sense. It is pointless having a scheme and having young or old people who are on the unemployment benefit wandering around the country doing tasks which they see as useless, which the rest of the community sees as useless, and which breeds resentment both in young people and in the community.

The proposition put forward so often by Mr Howard that young people and all those on the unemployment benefit should do compulsory work is simply not on, first of all, I suggest, in this situation of financial constraint and in the reduction in the size of the public sector, including the Public Service, which we are operating under at the moment and which seems to have support from both sides of the Parliament. As my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has pointed out, we would need an army of public servants to administer a scheme such as this. I doubt whether the costs of that would even be made up by the amount of cheating on the system that Senator Chaney seems to think would be detected in that area.

When we see that roughly in excess of 700,000 people are likely to participate in the scheme and many of those move on and off the unemployment benefit frequently, we are looking at an increase in staff, in the Commonwealth Employment Service alone, of in excess of 1,000. Although there are long term unemployed in this community, most unemployed people move in and out of the unemployment ranks fairly quickly. To insist on a system where all these people would be required to do the sort of work that Senator Chaney is apparently talking about would require an increase in the Public Service that would run contrary to what this Government is trying to do, but certainly contrary to anything that members of the Liberal Party and the National Party have been suggesting should happen in this country. They have no problem in walking around this country advocating that we should slash the numbers in the Public Service and slash public expenditure but they have no qualms in walking into this place when it suits them and talking about a massive increase in the number of public servants for their pet projects-projects which, as Senator Chaney has said, have some popular appeal. But that appeal depends on a lot of anecdotal evidence and it is not based on fact.

Contrary to what many supporters of the scheme suggest-I am not saying that Senator Chaney is one of those; he certainly did not mention it today-this would not be a costless exercise. To mount a scheme in this country which would provide that all those on the unemployment benefit would be required to do some form of community work has been estimated, again by my colleague Mr Willis and others, as costing something like $700m in outlays on education and training associated with such a scheme. I would be delighted if we had a spare $700m to promote the welfare of education and the training needs of the unemployed or, indeed, of pensioner groups generally. Equally, I would be amazed if the Opposition ranks its priorities of expenditure on the unemployed as highly as this. I am sure that it does not.

But members of the Opposition do not speak in one voice in this regard. As Senator Chaney complained about what he saw as the Government's lack of resolve I think, in passing, I would like to mention the Opposition's changes in direction of its resolve, depending on whom one listens to or of whom one takes any notice. For instance, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr N. A. Brown, wants to abolish benefits for the long term unemployed and introduce some form of compulsory work for them-the very people who need the benefit most, I would suggest. This would go along with the fact that, when members of the Opposition were in government before, they had no problem about slashing the unemployment benefit for young unemployed, even if they were long term, and for single unemployment beneficiaries if they were long term. The former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, recently called for the abolition of the unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds with cuts in employment schemes because apparently this would assist people by sharpening their resolve, I suppose, to go out and seek employment. Various people on the other side, such as Mr Donald Cameron in another place, frequently advocate that we should not be paying the unemployment benefit to young people. In taking this attitude I think members of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what the ACTU said, though.

—I will come to the Australian Council of Trade Unions in a minute. The honourable senator knows what the ACTU is saying. It is not saying what Mr Donald Cameron said, that is for sure. I have no argument with what the ACTU is saying, as Senator Chaney knows. I think we really must look at how we should operate in this area. We should look at certain principles on which we should judge our behaviour and we should certainly look at what we are trying to do and at how we could best assist the unemployed. In doing so we have to take account of the feelings and the opportunities of unemployed people themselves and I suppose that we even have to think of our international obligations under International Labour Organisation conventions.

SPEECH.PARA: In deciding that the scheme we introduced in the Budget would be voluntary, part time and would not substitute for full time employment, we took into account certain principles. Implict in the principles espoused by so many members of the Opposition-if not by them, by conservative members in the community-seems to be the principle that compulsory work for unemployment benefit schemes are worth while because unemployment beneficiaries are not really interested in finding work and that there is some obligation for those dependent on government handouts `to do something'-it is always `to do something'-for society in return. I do not subscribe to the dole bludger theory which is generally applied to the unemployed in this country. Of course, there are some people on the unemployment benefit who should not be getting that benefit. Of course, there are some people on the unemployment benefit who are not generally interested in finding work. But it is my experience that the majority are interested in seeking work. In fact, the latest CES data show, for instance, a ratio of 23 people registered as unemployed for every one unfilled vacancy available at the CES.

Whenever jobs are advertised for young people in this country now there are queues of people seeking those jobs. The voluntary youth program demonstrates that many more than can be catered for by existing projects are willing to do voluntary community work if the opportunities are available. We believe that the community youth program which will be introduced will pick up more of those people. But to force people into such a situation and to leave the opportunity open for unscrupulous organisations or individuals to take advantage of that, as they have done in the past with some of the programs that have been introduced in this country, does not solve our problem and certainly does not do anything for those unemployed or unfortunate enough to have been in that difficult situation for so long.

In terms of any reciprocal obligations to society we believe, and the social security legislation in this community has always provided, that people who are genuinely unemployed and actively looking for work are entitled to their unemployment benefit assistance. Unemployed people on the unemployment benefit are already subject to a general work test in this community. Under that work test they have to establish their legitimate status as active job seekers. To put the extra obligation on them in the absence of the availability of sufficient community work I believe is being a bit difficult and says more about our need to feel good as a community than to do something positive for the unemployed.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions had this sort of thing in mind and the need for an integrated strategy to look after the unemployed when it advocated recently a five-year program designed to guarantee school, work or training opportunities under which income maintenance would be related to work, school or vocational training. That is a very different kettle of fish, I believe, from what is being suggested by the Opposition in its motion here this afternoon. Scandinavian countries and some of the other social democracies of western Europe have this sort of program in which government takes it upon itself to provide work and opportunities for training and other activities in exchange for unemployment benefit or a social benefit itself.

When we reach the stage at which we can do that-the ACTU suggests it might take five years to do so-I dare say that we will have a situation in which we can have education retention rates at the sorts of levels of western Europe, which are very much higher than we have here, and the sorts of training schemes of some of those social democracies in western Europe where people can be trained with the protection of their dignity; their self-esteem will be looked after. They will therefore receive that social benefit in exchange for contributing to society but at the same time they will be more likely to be able to get work as the economy recovers.

In this society we have always accepted, rightly or wrongly, that unemployment benefit is available from almost the moment someone leaves school if we cannot provide a job for that person. We will solve that problem and be able to tackle that philosophical problem that Senator Chaney talks about only as we increase the number of tertiary education places, as we have been doing; as we increase the number of traineeships available, as we have been doing; and as we increase the school retention rate, as we have been doing in the last few years. Contrary to common mythology, young people who are actually in receipt of unemployment benefit in this country are in receipt of that benefit for shorter durations than older people. We really have to look at how we allocate the resources we have. We have to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to allocate significant additional outlays to employ young people who eventually will be employed anyway or to provide greater emphasis on the older unemployed and those long term young unemployed people who otherwise would not receive the assistance. We know the unemployed need to be put in touch with a range of education and job opportunities, but we do not see the need for compulsory work in exchange for these benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating an urgency motion that was brought forward by the Opposition in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

The Australian Democrats believe that every community pays for unemployment in more than one way, and that is something which has been stressed frequently by my colleague Senator Macklin in our Party councils and in public, and by others of us. As unemployment persists in this country, we are able to see more clearly every day how true it is. Not only is unemployment unproductive in the sense that it leaves idle a valuable resource-the most valuable resource that any country has is its people-but also it is unproductive in its results. Unemployment leads, almost inevitably, to poverty, which leads to hunger and to crime. This has been demonstrated many times over recent years. A supporting parent who cannot find any work and who is living in such an expensive city as my home city of Sydney will eventually feel tempted to steal or, worse, maintain those dependants at even the most minimal of standards. This whole situation is becoming even more strongly dickensian, and the image of ragged, starving children begging in our streets comes closer to realisation, as time passes, due in no small part to the tiny allowance for children in the dole payment. I think it is $16 a week. Whoever felt anybody could support a child in a reasonable way on $16 a week?

To proceed as we are now doing is cruel and inhuman in that it permits the continuance of thousands of personal tragedies which could otherwise be avoided. The evidence is steadily mounting that suicides, ill health, drug addiction and criminal activity are strongly associated with long periods of unemployment which, of course, we have in this country. The gloomy predictions that the Economic Planning Advisory Council made only this morning make it obvious that some palliative measures to share the load of unemployment will be necessary in the immediate future. I question those points made by Senator Grimes. It is not good enough for Senator Grimes to stand up here as a representative of the Government and say: `We cannot do anything about this as it costs this much money and that much money'. It is something to which the Government will have to address itself because, if EPAC is to be believed, there will not be any dramatic improvement in unemployment statistics for a very long time. In fact, we can expect the situation to worsen considerably before it gets better. That is the considered view of the Government's advisers, expressed only today.

I turn to the question of work alternatives because that is what this debate is about, and properly so. It is a good thing to be debating at this time. The Australian Democrats have believed for a long time that this is one of the major issues involved in unemployment. It is now one of the issues most prominent in the mind of the public, and it should not be ignored. The dole is plainly valuable in that it does give a means of support to the unemployed. But its effects, when continued over long periods, are now being perceived as much less valuable. It is, of course, the conventional wisdom that paying an unemployment benefit, free of any obligation to work for it, is an enlightened and useful course of action, and the one offering the most dignity, personal freedom and assistance to the recipient, especially in conditions of long term unemployment.

The Democrats believe that conventional wisdom now has to be questioned. In my experience-this includes talking to the people in many drop-in centres around the country-many young people see the dole system as dismissive and rejective, as a putting down of their position by society. This is especially the case, I have found, with young people who have never worked and who cannot find work because they lack job experience. They see the dole, which is provided to them without any real chance of work, as virtually a statement by society along these lines: `We have nothing for you. You are basically of no value to us but, because it would be less than decent to allow you to starve or go unclothed, here is an amount of money just sufficient to avoid those indecencies'. While there is no doubt that a few people are happy enough to go on living on the dole without seeking work, my experience is that the vast majority of the unemployed would accept work if it were the sort that they felt would give them training and some future and, especially, if it had some value to the community at large. I still believe that young people have that spirit in them, that if they felt they were doing something of value and importance they would find that an acceptable reward. They want work not only for economic reasons-let us put this myth aside-but also because their self-respect and levels of prestige in our society are dependent on it. There is still this idea of the work ethic.

Because of this, I think we should start looking now at a two-tier system of unemployment benefit-a higher benefit of some kind paid to that majority of the unemployed prepared to undertake some form of useful work and the lesser benefit, perhaps the present dole, paid to those who are not prepared to do it. The Democrats resist strongly the idea that work should be compulsory for unemployed people to be given at least a minimum means of support. To take that step would be virtually to reintroduce a form of slavery-a compulsion on people to work in areas which they might find repugnant or unduly onerous. I know there are many people in the community who take a contrary view, and they say that all unemployed people should work to qualify for the dole. The Democrats believe those people are in error and need to think this through more carefully. I commend that point to the Opposition. The basic point is that one can, as the saying has it, take the horse to water but one cannot make it drink. We can compel people to work in certain areas-certainly we can say that a person will go hungry if he does not work-but does anybody in this chamber or in the community believe that we will get honest, responsible, reasonable, productive work from people in those circumstances? Of course we will not. What do we do then? Do we introduce the lash or something like that to make them work? This leads, as I suggested, into an area of alternatives that are far from palatable to a modern and reasonable society. For this reason I shall move later in this debate to amend the wording of this matter of urgency, and that will be initially a motion for suspension of Standing Orders.

Another point that is worth making concerning community work programs is that when work programs are organised, which would permit all who wish to work to do so-that is what we need, I think-such programs ought to offer a wide variety of choice of occupation and should have a strong training element. Those people who say that this cannot be afforded by the community might not have stopped to consider the real cost of unemployment. One can think of all the houses that are burgled, all the young people who are going on to drugs and the amount of crime. All these things, quite apart from the actual costs of the dole, are a charge on the community. As far as I know, no real effort has been made to assess that cost. I think it is high time that the Government did. If we assessed that cost, we might be shocked at what it was.

There is no doubt in my mind that the work alternative is a necessary next step in dealing with unemployment and it must be a continuing policy while unemployment is long term. There are, of course, obstacles. The basic one is the school of thought which dictates that such a move would create a sub-class of workers on lower pay scales than awards provide. That is true; it would do that. There is no way the public sector, especially in our present economic circumstances, can afford to provide work on a full time basis for half a million people on award rates and conditions. That would plainly be ridiculous. However, the fallacy of this thinking is that the only alternative that is seen is to allow our unemployed to go on rotting away mentally and physically on the dole. There is middle ground, and it must be explored and it must be brought into being.

Some of the answers to these objections could be, for instance, guarantees that work undertaken as part of the work alternative would not be work that would otherwise be done by unionists. This was one of the things done by the Civilian Conservation Corps during Roosevelt's New Deal during the last Depression in the United States of America. Very valuable work was done which would not normally have been done but which was still of enormous value to the country and is still of value now. There should be a strong training element or educational element, because it is not satisfactory that we spend many thousands of dollars putting a person through the schooling process if he or she comes out of it and obviously has not benefited. What do we do? Do we regard that money as being wasted? No. When a lot of these young people reach the stage of having been on the dole for a while, they say, as some of them have said to me: `I mucked up my school, Senator; what do I do about it now?' One could say: `Go to night school', I suppose, but quite often these people, for one reason or another, do not have that kind of initiative. If a program were provided through which they could recoup their educational standards and get work experience at the same time, these young people are likely to be of value to the community instead of a drain on it and possibly a negative cost for the rest of their lives, which would happen if they turned to crime and things of that kind.

I have put this view before in this place and I think it is worth while: If the Australian Council of Trade Unions feels sensitive about this-I can understand why it does-why should it not maintain a very large measure of control over such a program or even, in fact, the whole control? I think it has an obligation to the community to consider that as an alternative. A very important change which must take place is that governments, unions and employers accept the concept of permanent part time work, job sharing and voluntary early retirement. The EPAC predictions make it even more necessary. What is there now will have to be shared more widely. The message is there clear and loud in front of us.

In answer to a question I asked of him in September 1983-now three years ago-the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said that the introduction of more flexible methods of work organisation was part of Australian Labor Party policy and would be implemented following discussions with all parties concerned. One small part of his answer to me at that time read:

There is little doubt that greater sharing of employment opportunities through job splitting, greater facilitation of part-time work, and other measures, could expand the number of people engaged in employment.

It is simply not good enough. Here we are, three years later, and the Government has still not come to grips with this obvious and necessary area of action. Plainly it has been put in the too hard basket, and that is simply not good enough. What the Democrats want is a closer tying of unemployment schemes to the community and to business.

I want to mention in this context the scheme introduced some years ago in his businesses by my colleague, the Democrat senator for Victoria, Senator Siddons. He introduced a work station system on a roster basis which could be occupied by at least four young people between the ages of 16 and 22 on a permanent part time basis. In other words, that one job was split into four so that four young people instead of one could gain experience. Siddons Industries Ltd has, in fact, been carrying out this scheme for the past four years and has found it to be very successful indeed. Many of the young people who have gained work experience have gone on to get jobs elsewhere. Siddons Industries gives preference to those who would normally find it particularly difficult to find work, such as those who have difficulty with reading, or in one case a youth who had a breakdown at the age of 16. These cases invite the compassion of the community. In the experience of Siddons Industries, virtually no roster spot has been missed over the last four years, demonstrating the responsibility felt by young people in this regard and their anxiety and their eagerness to have this sort of opportunity.

I have discussed the matter of permanent part time work versus short term, full time work with social workers and others concerned with young people. There is no doubt at all that the experience of having a full time job for a short time, then not having a job, is probably more shattering to a young person that never having had one at all. A permanent part time job gives responsibility, stability and dignity to these young people. It is our responsibility, wherever possible, to provide this. It can be done by incentives to industry without difficulty. I commend that thought to the Government.

It is now more than a year since the Democrats' community services initiative scheme was submitted to the Government. There has been no response from the Government as yet. Basically, we asked the Government to allow an increase in permissible income to unemployed people and to pensioners to $60 a week so that there can be an incentive for them to help meet the mounting need for human services in our local communities. At present they get such a pitiful allowance it is not worth their while doing even a day's work. That is ridiculous. These services would include minor home and garden maintenance, shopping, reading, transport, et cetera, for elderly or disabled people; respite services where families are caring for a sick or disabled person; assistance to voluntary organisations and self-help groups; child care centres; community need surveys, and information distribution on local matters. Payment, we foresee, would be in addition to unemployment benefits and pensions by way of a nominal hourly service fee plus expenses incurred, for instance, for travelling. Current low levels of additional permissible income for unemployed people severely limit the amount of service fee which would be paid. They also hit hard at the business sector, especially small business-this is not generally understood-because they savagely reduce spending power in the hands of hundreds of thousands of people, many of whom have families and who would wish to go ahead and have that extra money.

As I mentioned, the Democrats do not approve of the imputation in the motion that this should be compulsory and should apply to all young people and be required of them. Because of that, and in terms of Senator Haines's contingent notice of motion, I move:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Haines moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Haines, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out `required of', insert `made available for'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today debating a motion of urgency in the name of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

Apart from providing for the national defence, there is probably no other responsibility that lies as heavily upon the shoulders of a government as its obligation to create the opportunities for employment for all those who actually wish to work. This has long been a central view of the Liberal and National parties. For instance, on 9 September 1983 my colleague Mr Ian Macphee, a shadow Minister in the House of Representatives, gave an address to the Australian Institute of Management, Queensland Division, in which he said:
Governments have an obligation to create an environment in which the market-place can manage effectively and fairly in the interests of all its investors-including its human capital.

That is a point of view which all of the members of the Opposition would wish to endorse and to endorse without qualification. The betrayal of the human capital, which is represented by continuing high levels of unemployment, stands as one of the great condemnations of the Hawke Government since it has been in office. For instance, if one looks at the monthly economic and social indicators for September 1986, one sees that the seasonally adjusted figures for unemployment at the end of September give us unemployment, in terms of raw numbers, of 634,000, representing 8.4 per cent as an unemployment rate. That rate is extraordinarily high by any standards. It is high by world standards; it is particularly high by Australian standards. Mr Warwick Smith, the Federal member for Bass, some time ago produced an analysis of the record of the Hawke Government in terms of unemployment, compared with the record of the 86 months during which the Fraser Government was in office. He demonstrated that the figures continue to show that unemployment is at a higher rate than it was for 81 of the 86 months of the Fraser Government. Not only does that continue to be the case, but the situation is worsening. For instance, we have heard a great deal about the Priority One: Young Australia scheme. My colleague Senator Vanstone will have a great deal more to say about that. I only make the point that the unemployment rate when the Priority One scheme was introduced was 8.1 per cent; it is now 8.4 per cent. So even with all of the so-called initiatives of Priority One and all the expense more people are out of work, and in particular there are more young people out of work. For instance, the Treasury Round-up for September 1986 shows that the unemployment rate for those aged 15 to 19 years is in the vicinity of 22 per cent. That is an unbelievable statistic in a country such as Australia, and an unbelievable tragedy for the hundreds of thousands of young Australians who are affected.

Above all, this Government has been deficient because it has made no real attempt to change attitudes; it has made no real attempt to recognise the social, psychological and personal consequences of unemployment. The Government takes the attitude that all one needs to do is provide more financial assistance, to find more money for particular schemes, to regard the Treasury as a bottomless pit and to dole out financial handouts rather than seek to change structures-as Senator Chaney has said, to change work practices-and attitudes throughout the community. People have recognised that for centuries. The great historian, Plutarch, in his Life of Coriolanus, wrote:
For it was well and truly said that the first destroyer of the liberties of a people is he who first gave them bounties and largesses.

It appears that this Government has no solution other than more bounties and more largesses. The important issue, as I have said, is that of establishing and understanding the creation of a psychology of dependency among people who are condemned to prolonged periods of unemployment. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, one of the most distinguished of the United States senators, had this to say in his book Family and Nation:
The issue of welfare is the issue of dependency. It is different from poverty. To be poor is an objective condition; to be dependent, a subjective one as well.
He went on to say that the important thing about that is that it brings about a situation which is somehow different from the norm. He said of this dependency:

It is an incomplete state in life: normal in the child, abnormal in the adult. In a world where complete men and women stand on their own feet, persons who are dependent-as the buried imagery of the word denotes-hang.

It is important to understand that it is in the creation and continuation of this idea of dependency, this feeling of dependency, that the root of this great problem lies. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has studied this question and has focused on the question of unemployment among youth in particular. In the OECD Observer of November 1985 it is reported that unemployment for people aged 15 to 24 years is `a serious social threat that could undermine the mechanisms of training, education and the provision of human infrastructure for the society of the future'. It went on to say that these days education itself is simply not enough, stating:

At the same time, it is becoming increasingly clear that initiatives confined strictly to traditional educational systems will not be enough to put an end to the difficulties encountered by young people today.

It went on to make the point that many young people intentionally bring about a situation where they are under-employed and that they sometimes spurn the labour market and can make a career out of welfare, supplemented by undeclared incomes. The motion put forward by Senator Chaney today seeks to address fundamentally the issue of dependency. It seeks to address fundamentally the psychological point involved in the long term condemnation of individuals to a welfare dependency situation. Professor Wolfgang Kasper in his book The Destruction and Creation of Jobs drew particular attention to the social costs of high unemployment. He said that Australia was at risk of losing sections of its youth to cynicism, despair and bitterness as high levels of unemployment denied them the right to a bright and happy future. He said that society:

. . . should not be complacent about the loss of productive potential and the redistribution of incomes and life opportunities implicit in large scale unemployment, unemployment is the single most important cause of poverty.

It is the breaking of this trap, this vicious circle of unemployment dependency and therefore lack of self-esteem, lack of capacity to gain work and lack of capacity to hold down meaningful jobs, that this motion introduced by Senator Chaney seeks to address. It is important to understand the long term impact of prolonged periods of unemployment. An article by Robert Hadler in the Australian on 2 September dealt with a recent report. The article stated:

People on the dole show far less initiative in seeking new work and stay unemployed for much longer periods than those who do not register for unemployment benefits, a government job search survey has shown.
Those registered on the dole with the Commonwealth Employment Service took an average of 60 weeks to find a job, while those not on the dole took an average of nearly 22 weeks to do the same.

The position is even more acute for young people in that circumstance. When Mr Peter Kirby undertook his major study on behalf of the Commonwealth and produced his report entitled `Labour Market Programs', he made a particular point about previous job creation schemes in Australia. Quoting from a publication of R. E. Smith from the Australian National University, he stated:
The Australian programs are more oriented towards providing immediate employment for members of the target group, rather than increasing their long-term earnings potential.
He went on in his recommendations to focus on the creation of permanent opportunities. His first recommendation was:

The primary objective for any labour market program should be to enhance the participant's long term employment and earnings prospects through the development of a needs based approach, in which individually tailored packages are devised in appropriate combinations from the available assistance.
His second recommendation was:

The barriers which prevent or deter people from engaging in education and training while they are without employment should be reviewed and, as far as possible, removed. Available resources should be transferred from passive to active forms of assistance.

That is precisely what Senator Chaney's motion is all about. This recommendation seeks to bring about a situation in which some form of community based work is required of those who seek to draw the unemployment benefit and who seek to exercise the right they have to a degree of government support but who have in the past not been required to demonstrate any active obligation to contribute in return.

The Australian Democrats amendment moved by Senator Mason is simply another weak and feeble opt-out provision. It is a motherhood statement that work should be available for rather than required of. If work were available for, presumably there would be no need for the unemployment benefit in the fashion that we currently pay it. It is not to be thought that Australia is not taking steps in this direction. This week's issue of Time magazine contains an interesting article dealing with the work which is going on at the Prahran College of Technical and Further Education in Melbourne, where people are being given assistance to provide themselves with skills which will make them more likely to be employable in both the long run and the short run.

I conclude by coming back to my central point, that is to say, to the value of the work ethic, of work experience and of a practical personal commitment to find work and to undertake work. The American sociologist, Mickey Kaus, in a publication entitled The Work Ethic State has attempted to analyse this. I do not believe that the points could be put more succinctly, or that the purport of Senator Chaney's motion could be more adequately summed up than by Mr Kaus's words. He states:
Welfare doesn't work. Work ``incentives'' don't work. Training doesn't work. Work ``requirements'' don't work. ``Work experience'' doesn't work and even workfare doesn't quite work. Only work works.

That is the purport, the whole thrust of the motion which Senator Chaney has put before the Senate today-that only work works. Only the practical experience of work provides people with the necessary skills to move into long term situations of employment and employability. Only practical experience, only real work, allows people to break out of the cycle of dependency and the psychological traps of dependency which, unless they are addressed and overcome, will destroy a large proportion of an entire generation of young Australians whose blighted futures will stand permanently as an accusation against the incompetence, the lack of care and the lack of ability that this Government has demonstrated since it was first elected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is discussing the following motion of urgency proposed in this place by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

The Australian Democrats have moved an amendment to that motion seeking to delete the words `required of' and in their place to insert the words `made available for'. The opinion of honourable senators on this side of the House is that the Democrats' amendment will be supported. It gives some sense to a proposition which indeed is a matter of urgency; nobody in the community in Australia would doubt that. In introducing the motion of urgency, Senator Chaney called for the matter to be discussed in a calm and rational way. He emphasised the need for calm and rational discussion and to avoid any sort of inflammatory approach to this problem. That proposal would be supported not only by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber but also by honourable senators on this side of the chamber and people out in the community. But, unfortunately-it is unfortunate not only for the Liberal Party but also for the people of Australia-Senator Chaney has a dwindling influence within his Party despite the fact that he is the Leader of the Liberals on that side of the chamber.

I refer to a very happy picture that appeared in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. It shows the smiling face of the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, sitting in company with a Liberal hopeful, Ian Storey, and one Charles Copeman. Charles Copeman appears to be having a greater influence on the Liberal Party than is perhaps Senator Chaney. I will quote directly from the article of what Mr Howard said of Charles Copeman. The article states:

``We've had a whopper of a scare campaign over the last few weeks over something called the New Right,'' Mr Howard said. ``And I'm happy that Charles Copeman is here. He's a person I admire very greatly.

``Of all of the people I've met in that so-called grouping there is nothing extreme or un-Australian about them. And most of their ideas are increasingly ideas that middle class Australians are expressing.
``I think quite honestly the whole thing is a big yawn in political terms and purely a diversionary tactic by the Labor Party.''
Mr Howard said the Government had acted as if it had a problem by erecting the New Right as a ``bogey man'' and then attacking it to try to divide the Liberal Party.

I certainly think there are divisions within the Liberal Party. Let us compare the speeches here this afternoon of Senator Chaney and Senator Puplick with the actions of Mr Charles Copeman. On the very bottom of this article in today's Sydney Morning Herald is a reference to page 4 of the same newspaper. The headline on page 4 is: `Peko under angry Govt investigation'. Why would the New South Wales Government investigate Peko-Wallsend Ltd, the Chief Executive of which, Mr Charles Copeman-he has had a high public profile in recent weeks-is a very close friend of John Howard and someone whom John Howard admires? The reason is that the Besco Batteries factory in Villawood in Sydney is a member of the corporation that Peko- Wallsend controls. On Friday of last week, just three days ago, that company shut up shop, lock, stock and barrel, tight as a drum, and in the process sacked 500 workers. It chucked 500 working people out of jobs.

The increasing influence of the New Right in the Liberal Party may be the reason why we have this matter of urgency raised this afternoon. The advisers to the Liberal Party, the close friends of the leadership of the Liberal Party, are indeed increasing the numbers of people on unemployment benefit right throughout Australia. Peko-Wallsend is on most people's lips because it came to fame in June of this year in the Pilbara in Western Australia when that company, whose Chief Executive Charles Copeman, is a close friend of John Howard, took it upon itself to sack over 1,100 workers. Those 1,100 workers were tossed on to the scrap-heap because of allegedly unproductive work practices. It has taken many months to prove that those practices are unproductive. As yet it has not been totally proved.

What kind of calm and rational discussion can we have with a party so dominated by this new thinking, this new activity, that prevails within the Opposition? It was only earlier this month that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr N. A. Brown, said publicly that he wants to abolish benefits for all long term unemployed people. He wants to abolish benefits to those people most in need, the long term unemployed. I ask honourable senators: Where is the Opposition going and where can we get calm and reasonable discussion on this very important matter? One Malcolm Fraser, who was a leader of the Liberal Party, very recently called for the abolition of the unemployment benefit to 16- and 17-year-olds, along with cuts in employment schemes.

The Liberals want to cut, cut, cut and at the same time to set up grandiose schemes for compulsory work for the unemployed and to hire an army of public servants to police those schemes. At the same time they call for cuts in government spending and cuts in the strength of the Public Service. This motion of urgency represents another example of the callous and insensitive campaign being waged in our community by the Opposition and its cohorts of the New Right against those unfortunate people in Australia, the unemployed, who do not have jobs to go to at the moment. Essentially, such a campaign seeks to blame the unemployed for the fact that they are unemployed. It is the tradition that has worked so well for honourable senators opposite in the past-that of blaming the victims. The implications of the argument put are that the unemployed, particularly our young unemployed, should be punished, and compelled to work in some ill-defined community jobs. Perhaps this could be the digging of holes and filling them back up again, clipping grass with nail clippers or something such as that, because at the moment there just are not enough jobs to go around.

We have discussed this matter in this place on many other occasions. Why are there not enough jobs to go around? What is the level of investment taking place in Australia today? Who advises about investment? Again, let me refer honourable senators to another stalwart of the Liberal Party of Australia, one John Elliott. Mr Elliott, who is the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party, last week called for business people not to invest in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another traitor.

—Indeed, another traitor, as Senator Robert Ray says. This financial wizard of the Liberal Party, John Elliott, who has made his money, I would suggest, from workers who drink Foster's beer-because he now owns that company-will now invest off shore the profits from the beer that workers drink. I certainly will not be drinking Foster's beer in the future, although I will not be entirely taking the pledge.
—What brand are you going to drink?

—There is a very good brand from South Australia, I understand, by the name of Cooper's. I have not tried that one yet. Indeed, I might even refer to a brewery in my own State which is continuing to employ people, that of Alan Bond. It may help him win some yacht races at the moment as well. Let me return to the campaign that is being waged at the moment. It is a destructive and divisive campaign at a time when we need co-operation, consultation and a rational and reasonable discussion on the issues affecting Australia's economy at the moment. We do not need the divisive tactics that are being engaged in. We can look, yet again, for leadership to the trade union movement, in the recent announcements by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to which Senator Chaney referred. Honourable senators opposite have tried to claim that initiative as part of their policies. The argument that Senator Chaney used to prove that it was part of the Opposition's policy included a quotation from the Sunday slimes-I am sorry, I did say `the Sunday slimes', but I really meant to say `the National Times on Sunday'; we call it `the Sunday slimes' for short on this side of the House. I will talk in some little detail about that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The notion that the unemployed, be they young or old, should be compelled to work for the unemployment benefit ignores the reason why such a benefit exists. It exists because unemployment exists and because this community of Australia is of the view that all its members are entitled to a decent living allowance. It is insensitive to seek to punish our unemployed by forcing them into working in jobs with little or no social worth and into performing work for under-award payments when any realistic assessment of our economy reveals that full employment is not possible. The Opposition is quick to claim the ACTU's proposal as an endorsement of its own work for the dole campaign. In fact, the two proposals have nothing in common. The ACTU proposal is designed as a positive strategy to equip our unemployed, particularly our young unemployed, with the skills, training and education that our industry can use while at the same time ensuring that our young people can feel that they are indeed our most valuable resource. The ACTU proposal suggests the development of a five-year program for 16- to 19-year olds which guarantees educational, training, or work opportunities under which income maintenance is to be related to educational work or vocational training, and only if they are not available will the person be entitled to unemployment benefit. The motivation here is vastly different from that of the Opposition. It is a positive attempt to improve our skill and training base. Indeed, it can be seen as an extension of the Government's traineeship scheme. It is an attempt to strengthen the relationship between employment training and schooling.

As I have said, the matter of urgency is, indeed, a matter of urgency. Senators on this side of the House agree with that. It is something that the Government has been addressing since attaining office in March 1983 when 691,000 people were unemployed, in seasonally adjusted figures. Despite an enormous growth in the labour force, that figure has now been reduced to 634,000. Our strategies and policies are in place; our new program has recently been announced; and it will go a long way to resolving the particular problems that large sections of our community face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating today a matter of urgency proposed by Senator Chaney; that is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

The contributions to the debate this afternoon have been many and varied, but none were more startling than that of Senator McKiernan, who cannot seem to perceive the debate in any terms other than the suggestion that unemployed people should be punished for being unemployed by being made to work. If the good senator cannot see this debate in a light other than that, it would be my suggestion that he would have done better not to have participated in the debate at all. There are, I think, three matters that need to be considered in support of this motion. The first is the opportunity that such a system would offer to young people, to old people or to anyone who is unemployed. The second principle that needs to be considered is that such a scheme would provide some return in kind for the expenditure on unemployment benefit. The third principle is that such a system would provide a restriction on the abuse that is being undertaken by many in the community. I will deal with those principles one by one.

Let me deal first with the opportunity that the endorsement of this principle, if finally put into practice, would offer. The first thing that this sort of system would offer is a way out of dependency. My colleague Senator Puplick has already made some comments in this regard and I would like to expand on those comments. People who are on the unemployment benefit are dependent on the state; there is no way around that. In that respect, I would like to return to some comments I made in my maiden speech and briefly reiterate them here, because they are relevant to the point of dependency and to the situation that we put people in when we put them on any form of benefit, including, obviously, the unemployment benefit. I said this:

All of these welfare recipients have a limited income. They are all poor. A new identity has been forced upon them and they have become reliant upon the state for their most basic needs. This is a humiliating and dangerous position to put them in. They are becoming the children of the State. They have become institutionalised just as surely as if they had been given a uniform, and we probably have already given them a number--
And, of course, we have. I went on to say:

Few have yet adequately grasped or recognised the nature of this new client state-suspicious, more sophisticated, more articulate and yet more helpless, more bitter and more resigned. And so with the best of intentions, the state has paid out millions in welfare and without realising it, has created this new client state, with people trapped by the state-with no future beyond the next welfare cheque. There must be a better way-a way that enables welfare recipients to retain a greater degree of individuality, a way that will free them from the prison of dependence on the state and will enhance the individual's opportunity to set in train his or her own advancement.

I still believe what I said at that time, and I think those remarks are particularly relevant to the debate on whether or not people who are in receipt of the unemployment benefit should be required to make some sort of contribution back to the community in exchange for that. The word `required' can mean that we are making the unemployed do this because it is what they should do, and one could infer from that some sort of punishment. One could, but one need not. One can also see in that the opportunity that it creates for people. The first opportunity is to get out of the notion of being dependent.

We have all heard the slogan `dole bludger', a most demoralising and insulting term. To some people this applies as a perfect description of their desire and intention to take from the system all they can and to give nothing, but for many others it is a most inappropriate term. It is an inappropriate term for the many young people who are now looking for jobs and for whom there are not enough jobs. The Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, has told the Senate that the ratio of people looking for jobs to jobs available is 23: 1, and he relies on Commonwealth Employment Service figures. I put it to him that the ratio is not quite as high as that. I know many employers who simply do not bother registering jobs with the CES because they believe that the CES is quite incompetent at matching the unemployed skills in the community with the jobs available and seek to fill the positions themselves. I do not think that would necessarily reduce the ratio to such a substantial extent that the point Senator Grimes was making would not be true-that is, that there are many more people seeking jobs than there are jobs available. Those people should not have to be subjected to the term `dole bludger', neither should the people who are retrenched because the economy is in such a parlous condition, being run by the Labor Government; neither should the people who would like to get another job be called dole bludgers. It is not a term that should be used to apply to people of all ages with inadequate skills for the jobs on offer-people who are willing and able to work but whose skills do not match the jobs on offer. It is inappropriate to refer to those people as dole bludgers.

If we had a system in which people who were in receipt of the unemployment benefit were contributing in some way to the community, I contend that the term `dole bludger' would no longer be applied and that it would take an enormous emotional burden from those who were genuinely seeking jobs and could not find them. The benefit of relieving them of that burden, that insult that is cast upon them by many unthinking people as a consequence of the fact that there are some dole bludgers, would be very great. The second way in which such a system would offer an opportunity is that it would provide the opportunity for work experience-work experience either as a learning process if the unemployed person had never had a job, or reinforcement of experience and retention or maintenance of work skills. In that sense I believe that such a scheme would provide opportunities.

The second principal benefit which I mentioned and which was mentioned originally by Senator Chaney is that there would be some return for expenditure. The community is only too aware of the parlous economic situation; it is concerned at growing government expenditure and looks to the enormous expenditure on welfare and asks what it is getting in return. If people in receipt of unemployment benefit were to make some contribution to the community, I think that would be a fair equation. The third aspect in support of such a system is that it would put great restrictions on abuse, because if a person had to offer some community work in exchange for the benefit received, it would make it much more difficult for someone to receive an additional number of cheques under pseudo- nyms, or whatever term is used for people who change their name to get extra benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aliases.

—Aliases; I thank the honourable senator. I wish to return to the nature of welfare benefits so that there is no misunderstanding as to my views. Unemployment benefits, as with other forms of welfare assistance, should be seen as essential transitional support, not a trap that seduces people into permanent dependence. It is true, as Senator Mason said, that young people want to work-for money, yes, but for reasons in addition to money; for self-respect. We should be providing them with that opportunity when they are receiving unemployment benefits. Programs should try to assure recipients the same balance of rights and obligations that non-dependent people face in their daily lives. Thirdly, some form of community work in return for the receipt of unemployment benefits provides a means to restore connections between the society and its marginal members. It stops people floating around just collecting cheques and feeling less and less involved in their community. These points need to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: Speakers on the government benches have tried to evade the principal point which has been made and have referred to the administrative difficulties and costs of endorsing such a system. Such difficulties and costs are not denied. The Opposition seeks endorsement of a principle towards which we can work. There will be disagreement about the details and they should be faced as they arise on a one by one basis, but let us get the principle sorted out first. Some time ago on 11 June when the Prime Minister made his address to the nation some of us believed that perhaps the principle was about to be sorted out. The Prime Minister said on that occasion:

First, while society has a responsibility to the unemployed, this is a two-way process. The time has come, we believe, when this two-way responsibility will best be served by providing as far as possible the opportunity, particularly for the younger recipients of unemployment benefit . . .

But he was particularly evasive when interviewed following that statement. He refused to say that he believed that community work should be made compulsory. In a most idealistic fashion, he was of the view that if the work was offered it would be undertaken. From my reading of the transcripts of the interview with the Prime Minister, he refused to say what the Government would do if the work was offered and refused. All the Opposition is seeking here is some commitment to a principle from the Government. We are not seeking an outline in detail of the program the Government would or would not undertake; we are simply seeking an endorsement of the principle.

On 24 June an article written by Trevor Kennedy appeared in the Bulletin. He made the point that one does not need to be an Einstein to figure out that the dole can become a way of life for young children. Some members on this side of the House suggest that young people flock to Queensland to go on the dole in the pleasant weather there. I do not want to comment on that, but I want to draw attention to the question asked by Trevor Kennedy, which was as follows:
What is wrong then with asking able-bodied young men and women between the ages of 16 and 21 to work to qualify for the dole?
As he points out, it would at least teach them that there is not anything for nothing. He goes on in that article:

With luck it would cause many of them to seek alternative employment in a far more energetic fashion. If the plan involves too great an increase in the bureaucracy, the Government at least could require kids to accept jobs offered to them, rather than letting them get `unsuitable' work-and still collect the dole.
He went on in that article to deal with the claim that any sort of community work should be offered on a voluntary basis. He said:
The social workers lobby argued that the scheme must be voluntary and that there are dangers of producing hordes of unskilled people.
As he then points out:
The hordes already exist-and one of the big problems is that too many of them are illiterate in one of the greatest problems Australia has-the need to work.

They are the sentiments of Trevor Kennedy, and to an extent I endorse them. Comment was made by Senator McKiernan relating to the Government's Priority One: Young Australia program. Honourable senators will remember the flash in the pan that turned out to be. When the Prime Minister released that program, he was to talk to hundreds, if not thousands of young Australians. In fact he spoke to 172 in a phone-in. The Government was to offer 10,000 traineeships in the first year. We are now into the second year, but even in the first year the best the Government could manage was a total of 2,449. The Priority One scheme has a 10 per cent dropout rate, and the bulk of the positions are with Commonwealth, State and local government public service when, in fact, it was intended that it should be a private sector scheme. The Government's plans in this area are not working. All the Opposition seeks is the Government's endorsement of the principle that some form of community work be required of those who are in receipt of the unemployment benefit. To deny them that community work is to deny them the opportunity to escape the tag of `dole bludger' and the dependency that is associated with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone made some disparaging comments about the Commonwealth Employment Service and I wish to comment on that first. If she wishes to make such comments, she should produce evidence to back up her claims. The Commonwealth Employment Service and the people who work in that organisation are efficient and they should not be disparaged in this way without evidence being presented to back up such statements. I wish to make one other comment about the argument of the previous speaker. Apparently at one stage Senator Vanstone said that she would like to see a compulsory system of community work so that people would no longer use the term `dole bludger'. That term was often used by some members of the previous Government, particularly in that Government's early stages. We could get rid of that term `dole bludger' in other ways. We need a more intelligent approach to the needs of the unemployed. If we had such an approach that term would not be used. We do not need the sort of provisions that are outlined in the urgency motion in order to get rid of the term `dole bludger'. I remind honourable senators that this afternoon we are debating a motion by the Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
the need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

The Australian Democrats have suggested an amendment to that motion. That amendment is that the words `required of' be left out and the words `made available for' be inserted. I will return to that amendment later. I believe that the Senate should accept the amendment in lieu of the motion that has been proposed by the Opposition.

For those who have never been out of work, there is often a superficial attraction in suggesting that the unemployed should work for benefits. Many of those who have been in the position of not being able to find work, really do want meaningful work. A compulsory work for benefits scheme is not regarded by those people as acceptable. Some members of the Right-and I suppose, in 1986, the New Right-regard the unemployed as victims of their own circumstances who should be taught a lesson by receiving no unemployment benefit. Fortunately, that philosophy has not taken hold in this country. By far the majority of Australians consider that those who are out of work should be helped financially until they gain work and therefore an income. This superficially attractive idea that the unemployed should work for their unemployment benefit is proposed by those who should know better. Perhaps they see their proposition as being electorally attractive. Do they care more about their own electoral chances than they do about the unemployed? I certainly hope not.

This urgency motion does not say that those without a job should be encouraged to undertake some form of community employment. To some extent-but I stress it is only to some extent-I would agree with some encouragement of this kind being given to the unemployed. However, if this encouragement became a de facto compulsion, I would not agree with it. For example, if employers began to insist that prospective employees should have performed voluntary work, the voluntary aspect of this scheme would disappear and compulsion would become the norm. Compulsion is obviously what the Opposition wants. After all, its urgency motion notes that some form of community work `be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit'. Although I do not like to use the word `dole', I must point out that the Opposition's proposal is little more than a thinly veiled work-for-the-dole scheme.

I suspect that not many people would object to the unemployed doing some form of community work voluntarily. Some do so now; those who do are to be commended. On the other hand, those who do not should not be condemned. I doubt whether the Opposition has really thought through this proposal. Has it properly costed it? To have a compulsory scheme, which would have to be policed, would require some government expenditure. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) earlier suggested that to introduce a compulsory scheme of working for benefits would cost $700m a year, over and above the cost of unemployment benefits. An army of public servants would be required to police the scheme. Compulsory community work, as proposed by the Opposition, would not cost as much but there would be substantial costs involved. Has the Opposition considered whether all unemployed people would have access to community work? I am thinking particularly of those in isolated areas and perhaps those in areas where there are so many unemployed people that all possible forms of community work would be taken. What happens then? Do the unemployed have to travel to an area where they can undertake some community service? That would be rather reminiscent of people moving from place to place to draw rations, as was the case in the days of the Great Depression. There are far too many aspects of this compulsion proposal to make it a workable proposition. I suspect that the Opposition knows this, but is trying to make political capital out of the plight of those who cannot find work.

I was particularly interested in the Opposition's proposal because of the untenable level of unemployment that has developed in the State I represent. A great deal of the blame for this must lie at the feet of the Queensland State Government. This is no idle claim, because unemployment figures in Queensland have continuously been either the highest in Australia or far above the national average. Let me mention the unemployment statistics in Queensland, because these are relevant to the matter we are discussing this afternoon. The most recent official figures available are for September 1986. At the end of September, 113,800 people were unemployed in Queensland, and that represented an almost 12 per cent increase over the figure for the previous September. Again, in September 1986, Queensland's unemployment rate was 9.3 per cent, compared with 8.7 per cent one year earlier. The Australian average in September 1986 was 8.3 per cent, compared with 9.3 per cent for Queensland.

I shall try to put that in some sort of context, because it is very easy to mention numbers and percentages. If the rate of unemployment in Queensland were the same as the national average, we would have 12,100 extra people employed in that State. That illustrates the sort of unemployment problem we have in Queensland. That figure of 12,100 people is about the same as the whole population of Gympie or Hervey Bay; it is about half the population of Mount Isa or twice the population of Kingaroy. All those extra people would be employed in Queensland if our figures were about the national average. It is significant that as the parties campaign for the forthcoming election in Queensland, the ruling National Party of Australia has not given any indication that the plight of the unemployed in that State will receive the attention it deserves. Unfortunately, a negative approach has been adopted by the outgoing Premier of Queensland. Against all the statistical evidence to the contrary, he claims that the high unemployment in Queensland is caused by young southerners who are exploiting the social security system. That is the type of unsustainable anecdotal evidence to which Senator Grimes referred earlier. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's claims in this regard are baseless and his efforts to assist the unemployed are non-existent. This is in direct contrast to the attitude of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland. The provision of employment is high on its list of priorities. Yesterday Mr Warburton, on behalf of the Labor Party in Queensland, said:

To combat youth unemployment we will allocate $41m in 1987 to fund our specific YES or Youth Employment Schemes program. To all young Queens- landers leaving school, my Government will extend a youth guarantee: the guarantee of either a job, job training or the opportunity of further education.

This type of approach to the provision of jobs as outlined by Mr Warburton should be the principal aim of any Queensland Government. It will certainly be the aim of a Queensland Labor Government. The aim should not be, as proposed by the Opposition, to coerce the unemployed into some form of community work for those who cannot find work. If the Opposition's proposition is so great, one would expect that it would have been tried and implemented overseas. The plain fact is that compulsory work for benefit schemes are not common-place in comparable overseas countries. In the United Kingdom and Canada, for example, voluntary schemes have been introduced which are similar to what is already present in Australia and is being built upon by this Government. In the United States of America, which has been used by proponents of a compulsory scheme as some type of model, compulsory schemes are by no means widespread.

I would like to give details of a scheme which is used in Canada. The voluntary initiatives program has been in operation in Canada since December 1983. The major aim of this program is to provide unemployed people with voluntary opportunities to work within voluntary charit- able organisations. Unemployed people of any age on unemployment insurance are eligible to participate without having their entitlement to unemployment insurance affected. They receive from the Federal Government, in addition to their unemployment insurance benefit, $60 for working a full week, which is a minimum of 30 hours, and $30 for working part time, which is at least 15 hours. Full time participants must spend one half day per week actively looking for work. In this program work opportunities can range in duration from six to 52 weeks and must satisfy the following conditions: At least 15 hours work per week; must provide participants with any necessary training and/or experience to maintain or develop employability; and must not displace existing paid or volunteer employees. Further, sponsors must be registered or assessed as charitable organisations or foundations. There are some further requirements in relation to the program. I should mention that at January 1985 550 agreements had been signed representing some 2,100 positions in the voluntary sector. This scheme is provided by the Canadian Government for those who have not worked but are able to work within charitable organisations. I stress that it is a voluntary scheme, not the type of compulsory scheme which has been mentioned in the motion moved by the Opposition.

I mention briefly a scheme which is used in Massachusetts in the United States. The scheme, which is called the employment and training choices program, was introduced in 1983. It enables welfare recipients to participate on a voluntary basis in a wide range of activities. These activities include education and training, supported work experience, career planning and job placement. Again I stress that that scheme is voluntary.

If the Opposition wants to develop policies it should take account of schemes such as this and should examine the positive scheme which has been developed by the Hawke Government. The Opposition should not take the easy way out by simply proposing a slick but largely unworkable scheme for the unemployed. The matter raised by the Opposition is ill-thought out and, not being a matter that the Government should contemplate, can by no stretch of the imagination be regarded as a matter of urgency. I suggest that the amendment moved by Senator Mason be accepted and the Opposition's proposition be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. Needless to say, I disagree with some of them, including the remarks made by Senator Colston who has just resumed his seat. I thank in particular Senator Grimes, who raised some of the issues which need to concern us about this matter. In an environment where the Government has made very conflicting statements-clearly there is a variety of views within the Government-I welcome the fact that for the bulk of the debate this afternoon serious attention was given to the genuine issues. The Opposition has put forward the proposition that it is a matter of urgency that the Government endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit. It does so because it believes that that would be in the interests of the unemployed, the community and taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the unemployed are concerned, it is fascinating to find that 77 per cent of unemployed people who were surveyed in the past month or so said that they were ready to accept working for their dole. A survey which was done in June of this year, the result of which was published in July, of people who wanted Australians to work for the dole, showed that only 4 per cent of Australians stood up and supported the status quo; 39 per cent supported a voluntary approach; and 56 per cent supported a compulsory approach. I do not believe that the Government of this country should be conducted on the basis of opinion polls; I merely quote those figures to show that there is, for the best possible reasons, broad community support for the notion that requiring some social obligation on the part of those who are paid by the taxpayer is no more unreasonable than requiring social obligations on the part of those who work.
