Indeed, the Opposition believes that the adoption of this principle would be a great step forward in a social sense as well as an economic sense.

I do not wish to prolong the debate, but I will finish by quoting a passage from a very thoughtful book which has been written about the United States of America situation, entitled Beyond Entitlement, which deals with the problem of obligations and social policy. I quote from the first chapter of the book, which states:
Washington does give too much to the poor-in the sense of benefits given as entitlements.
The comments which follow apply to the social security system which I administered and which is currently administered by this Government. The author goes on:

It also gives too little-in the sense of meaningful obligations to go along with the benefits. What undermines the economy is not so much the burden on the private sector as the message government programs have given that hard work in available jobs is no longer required of Americans. The main problem with the welfare state is not its size but its permissiveness, a characteristic that both liberals and conservatives seem to take for granted. The challenge to welfare statesmanship is not so much to change the extent of benefits as to couple them with serious work and other obligations that would encourage functioning and thus promote the integration of recipients.

I respectfully adopt those words as being very close to my own personal view. After years of working with people who suffer the very great disadvantage of unemployment, I do not believe that anybody who has a working history in this country-I would put in that category honourable senators opposite such as Senator McIntosh; people who have worked in a range of circumstances and with a range of men-would doubt that for many young Australians, in particular, the present system is demoralising and unhelpful to them. The imposition of some social obligation for those who are in receipt of unemployment benefit or are entitled to be in receipt of unemployment benefit would be a great step forward for them, the community and ultimately the taxpayers.

I regret that the amendment which has been moved by the Australian Democrats will have the support of the Government. We will vote against that amendment, but we will support the amended motion, if the amendment is carried, because we believe that that is a more desirable situation than the present situation where for many people unemployment is simply an indication of the fact that unemployed people are outside the mainstream of Australian society in a way which is extremely destructive for them and their self-esteem.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Mason's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURE ADMINISTRATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This one-page statement by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) shows the Government's true colours, its contempt for the people of the Australian Capital Territory and its complete disregard for the principles of local decision-making in the Australian Capital Territory. I believe that this paper is a disgrace. It has been brought on under Government papers rather than in Government Business as a ministerial statement so that we each have only five minutes to talk on this matter which is of prime importance to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. Despite various attempts by the Minister to insinuate otherwise, I wish to point out to the Senate that the self-government package has not been debated in the Senate. We have not had a chance to debate this very important issue. It lies at the bottom of the Notice Paper at the choice of the Government, not at the choice of either the Opposition or the Australian Democrats.

The Government is now moving from proposing self-government, which is what it is proposing under its Australian Capital Territory Council Bill, to no self-government at all under the Advisory Council Ordinance. This Advisory Council is simply a group of people who will have cosy chats about what the Minister wants them to talk about. The sad thing about it is that we will be paying that group to do this. Of course, the Minister, without coming to this Parliament, could choose a group of 13 people, 24 people or any number of people and get these people around him to give him advice. However, he has failed to do this in the past. He has failed to take advice from the community in the past and now he will formalise the situation by getting a group of Yes, Minister people actually to tell him what he wants to hear and to give him a cosy feeling.

This is a costly non-proposal. The Government is appointing a new statutory body-a new quango-which I am sure the Liberal Party of Australia will be against. It will cost the people of Australia extra money and it will not achieve any of the purposes which the Minister proposes. The sad saga associated with this is that over the years Ministers have ignored the elected Assembly. There is the case of the Tobacco Ordinance 1927 which was meant to be revised earlier this year, but nothing has happened about it. There is the case of the Nuclear Activities (Prohibition) Ordinance which was put forward by the Assembly and which was ignored by the Minister for 19 months from 17 April 1984. We are still waiting for all these things to be brought before the Parliament. In relation to the Tobacco Ordinance, we have heard in the Senate that the tobacco industry has been printing special cigarette packets for Qantas Airways Ltd. The Minister for Territories told us he could not make the revived Tobacco Ordinance follow arrangements agreed to by all Health Ministers in 1985 because it would cost the industry too much to print simple health warnings just for the Australian Capital Territory. That was thoroughly dishonest of the tobacco industry, as is the whole proposal in this paper. Tomorrow I will be moving for the disallowance of the Ordinance which is associated with this statement of the Minister, and I hope to gain support from the Senate in so doing because the proposal is an insult to the people of the Australian Capital Territory, the people of Australia and this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a paper entitled `Future ACT Administration'. It appears to be a ministerial statement put out in the form of a Press release and now brought in here as if it were a paper. I would agree that it is hardly the appropriate way to be debating this matter. I notice also that no financial statement is attached to it, although the Advisory Council Ordinance 1986 that has been tabled refers very clearly to remuneration of the people who will comprise the Advisory Council that the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) intends to appoint. Since this matter came up, I have said that the Minister is entitled to have an advisory body, if he so wishes, but I do not think we quite envisaged that it would take this form. It is clear that it is intended that the members will be remunerated. The Ordinance provides for remuneration to be fixed either by the Remuneration Tribunal, or, it would seem, by the Minister himself.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to the number of advisers that he wishes to have. We all know that he recently appointed one of the former members of the House of Assembly to his staff as an adviser in a paid position. DEBATE.TITLE: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK PLAN OF MANAGEMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Kakadu National Park Plan of Management, prepared under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, and laid before the Senate on 18 September 1986, be disallowed.

It gives me no pleasure to move this motion. There has been a bipartisan approach to the Kakadu National Park. It has been recognised by all the major political parties in Australia as one of the major parks in this nation. It was the Fraser-Anthony Government that recognised Kakadu as a national park and had it listed in 1979. However, Opposition speakers will be pointing out various aspects of the plan and why we believe the plan is deficient and should not be proceeded with. It is a plan that has been prepared by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and obviously acceded to by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), who has not been prepared to take the necessary decisions to see that the Kakadu National Park goes ahead in the way originally set down and as laid down by the original plan of management.

In 1979, as I have indicated, the Fraser-Anthony Government declared stage 1 of Kakadu National Park. That covered an area of 6,144 square kilometres. In 1981 stage 1 was placed on the World Heritage List and in 1984 the Hawke Government declared stage 2, and declared its intention to list it also on the World Heritage List. Stage 2 was an area of 6,929 kilometres. Stages 1 and 2 gave a total area of 13,073 square kilometres, or, to get it into perspective, about five times the area of the Australian Capital Territory. Just this year, in conjunction with the plan of management, it was announced that stage 3 is to be declared. Stage 3 is a further 6,726 square kilometres, giving a total area for the Kakadu National Park stages 1, 2 and 3 of 19,799 square kilometres, or an area eight times that of the Australian Capital Territory. I suppose that national parks can mean all things to all people. But definitions are set down. Indeed on page 1 of the plan of management, the concept of a national park is put down in a definition which was arrived at by the General Assembly of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources in New Delhi in 1961. It states:

A national park is a relatively large area set aside for its features of predominantly unspoilt natural landscape, flora and fauna, permanently dedicated for public enjoyment, education and inspiration and protected from all interference other than essential management practices, so that its natural attributes are preserved.

I have no quarrel with that definition. In line with that, I suggest that we declare national parks for four main reasons: Firstly, to preserve as widely as possible the genetic pool of our flora and fauna; secondly, to preserve for aesthetic reasons locations of unique natural beauty; thirdly, to preserve for posterity areas of historical and cultural significance; and, fourthly, for recreational purposes. When we put those definitions together and we start to look at the Kakadu National Park, we start to see why certain areas are preserved. I put it to the Senate that three main areas are involved: The wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal rock galleries. Around those areas is a fairly large buffer area. There should not be any quarrel with the fact that in Kakadu we are trying to preserve the wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal rock galleries.

I referred to buffer areas. Interestingly, when the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act was brought in in 1975 it referred to conservation zones. From my layman's reading of the Act, with all of the legal gobbledegook that we get used to, conservation zones or buffer areas, as I referred to them, are one and the same thing. Interestingly, sub-section 8 (a) of that Act states:
In addition to the powers to make regulations conferred by sub-section (6) and section 71, regulations in relation to conservation zones may be made-
(a) making provision for and in relation to operations for the recovery of minerals;

That is quite significant when one sees what has happened in this second plan of management and how the exploration for and recovery of minerals has been almost totally excluded in stages 1 and 2. In stages 1 and 2, the significant areas that I mentioned would account for approximately 35 per cent of the total area of the park, or about one-third of it. The buffer areas or conservation zones represent about 65 per cent or a little under two-thirds of the total area. When stage 3 is added, the areas of significance come down to considerably less a percentage of the total area; I have even heard a figure of about 10 per cent. So when stage 3 is declared about 90 per cent of that area will be termed buffer area or conservation zone.

The argument then gets down to how those buffer areas should be used. Let me say right here and now for everybody who follows in this debate that we are not debating the areas of significance. We are not debating the wetlands. We are not debating the escarpment. We are not debating the Aboriginal rock galleries. For the purposes of this debate they are sacrosanct. What we are talking about is how the buffer zones should be used in the future. When one draws up a national park such as Kakadu, when one must recognise the areas of significance and the buffer zones, the boundaries become somewhat arbitrary. They are basically in the minds of those who draw them up at the time. Areas of one or two square kilometres, or even 40 or 50 square kilometres, provided they are outside the areas of significance, do not make such a heck of a lot of difference. So our argument is that those areas inside the buffer zone should be available for multipurpose use, as indeed they were under the first plan of management. Quite often, those buffer areas are not normally of great concern. But in this instance there are a large number of minerals in that area. It is a very great mineral province. The second Fox report, at page 289 under the sub-title `Mining', states:

Gold in significant quantities is associated with the uranium ore body at Jabiluka. Other minerals, including copper, silver, lead, nickel, cobalt and zinc, have been reported in the region and several leases for these have been granted.

As I have said, the concept of the use of this buffer area, which probably normally would not be of great concern, takes on a whole new meaning. Indeed, one could be quite cynical about why these boundaries have been drawn and why there is such a large buffer area around the areas of significance. A question was asked in the House of Representatives on Friday when it was found that the Opposition had moved for this disallowance. Mr Cohen, in what has now become known in such a short time as his Swiss cheese answer, had a few things to say. I must say that it is nice to see the Minister so concerned. It is a pity that he was not so concerned when for months picketers breached all the regulations and laws under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act in that area. They camped where nobody else would have been allowed to camp, breaking down some of the flora and obviously disturbing the fauna. It is quite significant that the Minister now shows great concern. I do not quarrel with that except that he seems to be rather compliant with the wishes of the National Parks and Wildlife Service now but not too long ago he was prepared to overlook the illegal camping by picketers at the Mudginberri meatworks. Anyway, Minister Cohen said in his answer:
The simple fact is that there are very delicate wetlands in that area-and almost all the uranium prospectivity is in the wetlands.

My information is that very little of the uranium prospectivity is in the wetlands area. There is certainly some there but, having talked with a mining company just recently, it appears there are a considerable number of areas of prospectivity outside the wetlands areas. Let us remember what Minister Cohen said. It is quite interesting to read page 290 of the second Fox report under the sub-heading `Mining'. The second paragraph states:

The evidence indicates that the Magela Basin includes a good sample of the wetlands of the Northern Territory, but is inferior to many other areas in this respect. For example, the swamplands in which magpie geese congregate for nesting are small in extent compared with others elsewhere. Disturbance by buffaloes has been greater in the Magela system than in the flood plains west of the Stuart Highway. Hence, if any wetland area is to be placed at risk, we believe the evidence leads to the choice of the Magela.

Minister Cohen, if he read that some time ago, has obviously forgotten about it or conveniently forgotten about it. Interestingly, at a hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on 3 October, Professor Ovington, who is the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, commented that an inventory should be made. On page 2193 of the draft transcript, Senator Townley asked:
Do you agree that the mineral potential of the Kakadu area is not known?
Professor Ovington replied:

Yes. There are all kinds of potentials. You have a potential to grow bananas at the South Pole if you are willing to put the money into it. Of course, for any stretch of land people can talk about potentials. The point we make is that there has been considerable opportunity for exploration within this region. It has been under investigation for some time. We believe, and what we suggest, is, that there is a need for some kind of an inventory, which could lead to exploration at some time in the future if that was seen to be desirable. What we really need is this broader basic inventory.
I repeat those last words:
What we really need is this broader basic inventory.

As I said, that quotation was from the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in reply to a question put by Senator Townley. How do we get such an inventory? One had a better chance of getting such an inventory a little while ago under the first plan of management, but there is no chance under the second plan of management. It is not ludicrous for the Director to say in that instance that there should be an inventory. That is something with which we would all agree. It is absolutely crazy to lock up an area that big, an area which is known to be one of the greatest mineral provinces in this nation, without knowing what one is locking up. The use of those resources, of course, is another argument to be dealt with at a later time. But to lock up an area that we know has some of the greatest mineral deposits in this nation while not knowing precisely what is there is an act of absolute folly. We have Professor Ovington saying that we should have an inventory and then in the next breath bringing in a plan of management which precludes everybody from finding out what is there.

On 20 August last an interim consultative committee delivered a final report on a national conservation strategy for Australia. This committee comprised members from the States, conservation groups, the Federal Government and industry groups. What emerged from the final report was a strategy based on a balance between the needs of development and the needs of conservation and their mutual dependence. The following quotation illustrates what I mean:

Conservation and development are fundamentally linked by their dependence on living resources. Both conservation and sustainable development require an attitude of stewardship, especially towards those plants, animals and micro-organisms and the non-living resources on which they depend, that could be destroyed if only short term interests are pursued. To provide for today's needs as well as to conserve the stock of living resources from tomorrow, both conservation and development are necessary.
The report goes on to give definitions of `conservation' and `development' which bear repeating in part. `Conservation' is defined as:

the management of the human use of the biosphere so that it may yield the greatest sustainable benefit to present generations while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations.
`Development' is defined as:
the modification of the biosphere and the application of human, financial, living and non-living resources to satisfy human needs and improve the quality of human life.

Following the definitions as laid down in our national strategy leads one to suggest that this plan that we are debating today does not follow the national conservation strategy's concept of a balance between conservation and development. In other words, it is defective; it is not a genuine, multi-use document. Quite often when talking about areas of great significance and national parks one hears used the terms `natural', `unique', `pristine', `primeval' and all the rest of it. I quote Professor Ovington on the use, or really the abuse, of this term `pristine'. These very interesting remarks appear on page 2247 of the draft Hansard:

People talk about pristine or primeval places in this world. As an ecologist of 40 years standing I claim that this is a myth: There are not really untouched places in this world . . . Everywhere in the world you have some degree of human interference, but it varies in intensity. People forget that Kakadu has been managed as a land area by Aboriginals for perhaps 40,000 years. Their impact is there. But in assessing the value of the area you assess it for what it is, not with some kind of concept of pristineness.

I think that is a quotation that should be well remembered by those people who want to take part in this debate and those people who look at our national parks as something that can be locked away and never touched again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Aborigines make the water radioactive? Of course not.

—No, the Aborigines did not make the water radioactive, Senator Sanders. Indeed, I am very pleased that the honourable senator has brought that up, because the water there has been radioactive for thousands of millions of years. There is naturally occurring uranium there. If Senator Sanders cares to check this out he will find that the water there has been radioactive for thousands of millions of years, even before the Aborigines came. That is a fact that is acknowledged by everybody, including the reasonable conservationists.
—Reasonable! The ones who work for Geopeko.

—Obviously Senator Sanders is not reasonable, as can be seen from his remarks. His turn is coming. Man does have an impact on the environment, whether he likes it or not, wherever he goes. Our roads, our homes and our public buildings can so easily destroy an attractive and natural environment. Indeed, they have done this. Yet we seem to accept that. We do not see the people living in the cities wanting to do away with their benefits because what was once there has been destroyed. So there is an impact, sometimes for better and sometimes for worse. But I think it is fair to say that, particularly in the last half century, we have learned greatly that we can live within our environment and do less destruction than we have been doing in times past and still reap the benefits of the better standard of living that we require in the twentieth century.

SPEECH.PARA: A mine in an area such as this is but a speck in the vastness of our country. We are fortunate in that we travel a lot, but many people do not understand just how vast this nation of ours really is and that a mine is but a speck. If all the known mineral deposits in Kakadu were to be mined it would affect an area of less than one per cent of the total area of stages 1, 2 and 3. So we are looking at but a small speck in the total area of stages 1, 2 and 3, let alone in the vastness of this country of ours. It is also but a small speck in time. I have a relative who is a bus driver. He took a group of students with a lecturer from one of the universities in Brisbane to Fraser Island. As they were driving along the beach the lecturer, who was rightly going through all the attributes of Fraser Island, was saying: `Look at what would happen. Look at this wonderful foreshore. Imagine how it would be destroyed if the sand miners were allowed in here'. My relative pointed out to him that that area had been mined less than 10 years before. Interestingly, that lecturer never spoke to my bus driver relative from that time onwards. But so it is that a mine is but a speck in the vastness of our country and also a speck in time.

People think that an area can be preserved like a picture frame, as if we could take a snapshot of it now and capture how it has always been and expect it to be that way for eternity. It is really a ridiculous supposition when one thinks of it. But that is the way a lot of people, unfortunately, think things are and should be. Man does have an effect on the environment, for better or for worse, and we cannot get away from that. What we have to do is learn to minimise that effect. It is a noble gesture to try to minimise that effect and one with which I have no argument. But, at the end of the day, governments have a responsibility. They have to take into consideration the environment and the need to preserve it as closely as possible. But the political parties have to take decisions because we also have to provide food and fibre and we have to provide jobs for the citizens of this country. So I suggest to the Senate that the challenge before us is not to lock away areas completely, because that is not going to protect them anyhow. The challenge before us in the twentieth century is to provide for food and fibre and to provide jobs. But at the same time we have to manage the environment so that the impact on it is as minimal as possible. That is the challenge for us, and it is the challenge that the Opposition is prepared to meet and wants to meet. Because this plan of management does not meet that challenge, we have moved this motion to disallow the plan and thus reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion moved by Senator Collard. I think that the Opposition, instead of moving a motion of disallowance, should congratulate Professor Ovington and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service on an outstanding document which meets many of the requirements mentioned by Senator Collard in his speech. Later speakers no doubt will respond to Senator Collard's remarks, but I would make the point that he claimed that there was no inventory in the plan. I refer him to page 28 of the report, which no doubt he has read carefully, where it says under `Objectives':

SPEECH.PARA: to develop an inventory of all renewable and non-renewable resources in the Park--

This is the very matter that he claimed was not done. Also on page 153 the report states in relation to jobs to be done, `survey and inventory of natural features'. I shall leave further discussion of Senator Collard's comments to later speakers. However, I do remind the Senate that we are talking about stages 1 and 2 and would not want to confuse the issue by mentioning stage 3 at this time.

I draw attention to the fact that the plan of management we have in front of us today was devised after consultation with groups involved. This point needs to be made because there has been some criticism outside this place that this matter has been rushed through and that it is an Ovington job in which nobody else has had a hand. I remind the Senate that public notices appeared, as they always do in these matters, in May 1984 inviting submissions. Some 26 submissions were received and considered by the group. There were wide consultations within the Northern Territory and outside. The formal consultations included consultations with groups such as the Kakadu Interest Groups Advisory Committee and the Consultative Committee of Traditional Owners. There was informal discussion of various sorts, including two major seminars, one in Darwin in September 1984 and one in Jabiru in 1985. This was to allow the public to listen to speakers, to have the details of the draft plan explained to them, and to have public discussion on the concept of the plan and on the way it might develop. The plan was then published in June 1986 to allow further representation and 74 further representations were received from interested groups. On the basis of these further representations the plan was revised and presented to the Minister along with the 74 representations, so that the Minister would have at his disposal all the material that had come in from the various groups with an interest. This is the document we have before us which is now open for debate in both places.

I am glad that Senator Collard reminded us of the definition of `park' when he referred to the General Assembly of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources which, as he told us, met in New Delhi in 1961. He quoted the definition, but I believe it is worthwhile quoting it again because we have to keep clearly in our minds what we are talking about in relation to a park:

A national park is a relatively large area set aside for its features of predominantly unspoiled natural landscape, flora and fauna permanently dedicated for public enjoyment, education and inspiration and protected from all interference . . .
I think that is the key element which was not emphasised when Senator Collard cited the definition. It goes on as he indicated:
. . . other than essential management practices, so that its natural attributes are preserved.

The International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources went on to talk about management objectives. Once again this is worth reading because we will have to think of the objectives which Professor Ovington had in front of him when this plan was produced. I quote from the document:

. . . call for the protection of natural and scenic areas of national or international significance for scientific, educational and recreational use. The area should perpetuate in a natural state representative samples of physiographic regions, biotic communities and genetic resources and species in danger of extinction to provide ecological stability and diversity.

The Act itself sets out in section 11 (8) the objects under which it works. I shall not read out those provisions but would commend them for study by all those who intend to speak and who will debate the matter this evening. It is unfortunate, as in so many cases with an emotive issue such as this, that there has been a campaign of media disinformation. Completely misleading statements have been made about mineral deposits and economic potential. I should like to put forward three examples. The first I take from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Hatton, who said:
There are a dozen Coronation Hills, in the $34 billion in known reserves in Kakadu, and many of them will now be locked up in world heritage area for ever.

Let us examine that statement and take the most recent data I could get from the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, his own department, which says firstly that there is less than 3 per cent of this $34 billion in Kakadu-less than 3 per cent. It says also that there is nothing like a dozen Coronation Hills and indeed that there are no other Coronation Hill type deposits in Kakadu, and-this is very important relating back to what Senator Collard said-only one deposit is in the area to be nominated a World Heritage area, and that particular deposit is not gold. Lawrie McIntosh of the Australian Mining Industry Council has said:
The known reserves in the Kakadu area are uranium (356,000 tonnes), gold (390,000 ounces), zinc (150,000 tonnes), Kakadu is one of the most mineral rich deposits in the world.

Again, looking at the figures supplied by the Department of Mines and Energy, of the 356,000 tonnes of uranium, 346,000 tonnes are outside the park-only 10,000 tonnes within it; of the 390,000 ounces of gold, 390,000 ounces are outside the park; of the 150,000 tonnes of zinc, 150,000 tonnes are outside the park. I use the figures from the Department of Mines and Energy for the Northern Territory. Paul Everingham, the member for the Northern Territory, said:

. . . proven uranium reserves in stages 2 of Kakadu National Park could pay all Australia's national debt and leave $8 billion in change . . . the area is probably the richest piece of real estate in the world. Uranium reserves have been identified as equal to energy reserves of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait . . . lies and deceit are very much part of the Kakadu story.

Well, there is certainly one aspect of that statement by the honourable member for the Northern Territory with which I would agree, and it is in the latter part of the quotation. However, let us look again at the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, which states that the total value of known uranium reserves in stage 2 is less than one billion dollars. That is a fair amount of money but a lot less than that suggested by Mr Everingham. Again this is more misinformation put out to mislead and provoke emotive debate.

Senator Collard in his contribution spoke of the three main areas, the wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal galleries, and committed himself by saying that he would support no interference with those. On the AM program this morning he spoke of other areas. He did not call them buffer zones but mongrel scrub, and said that they were useless areas of the park. Let us look to see whether the mongrel scrub referred to by Senator Collard is useless or part of the park. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation study, a long term study that went on for five years, said that this area referred to as useless is rich in terms of flora and fauna. It said that the woodlands were extremely diverse and an integral part of the ecological makeup of the park. Some would like to suggest that the mining potential in the park is in the mongrel scrub-in the useless bits-and not in the area that Senator Collard is so keen about-the wetlands, the escarpment and the galleries. But of course, this is not the case. Most of the potential is on the flood plains or the flood plain margins. To date, experience has demonstrated that we are still not able to cope with the problems of mining in the flood plain or on the flood plain margins. We certainly do not have the foolproof system that we will need if we are to meet the requirements that even Senator Collard has mentioned.

The known mineral deposits are outside the park. The work done by the Bureau of Mineral Resources in the Northern Territory shows that there is great potential, even outside stage 3. There is a general feeling in the Northern Territory that the mining companies are working very hard to ensure that they get access to stage 3 because they know that eventually they will be able to go outside that stage. The 14 mineral leases, of which we have been reading so much in the papers in recent days and which are subject to court action, are each approximately 40 acres. I understand from experts in the field that the 40 acres would not be sufficient so there would need to be either aggregation or extension. Aggregation is possible in one area-up to six of these leases could be combined. I am not sure whether that will be sufficient for a mining area, but I am sure of one point and that is that extension of any lease under this Government is highly unlikely. I suggest that the mining companies concentrate their activities outside the park.
Kakadu has been described in this way:
. . . unrivalled combination of spectacular and varied scenery; diversity of native plants and animals; and a wealth of Aborginal art. A place of national and international significance.

It is not surprising that the tourism industry is developing in the Northern Territory. Over the past few years there has been a 30 per cent annual increase in the number of tourists, and that is what the plan is all about. It is meeting the objectives set out by the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources and those set out in the Act. It is developing a multipurpose situation with the emphasis on tourist development. The motion by Senator Collard would deny the tourists the experience and would deny the Northern Territory the money that would flow from that.

One aspect of the plan causes me some concern and that is the professional fishing of barramundi. I wish to read part of a letter from the Northern Territory Commercial Fishermen's Association to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. The letter is signed by the chairman of that organisation, Mr Mundy. The letter relates to crocodiles and barramundi and I shall read only a small section which gives some of the reasons why professional fishing should be allowed in the park. It says:
2. Barramundi-
(a) This industry has been active for over 100 years although the majority of exploitation has occurred over the last 20 years.

(b) The annual value of the Northern Territory Barramundi industry is around $2m and although this appears to be a small figure, if one looks at the tourist industry where people visiting the Territory want to eat wild caught Barramundi the value to the Territory cannot be calculated. Because of this, if the industry was to gradually die the effects would be far reaching.
(c) The Barramundi industry is currently under strict management control-
(i) Licences have been decreased from well over 100 to the equivalent of 35 full licences.
(ii) The amount of net allowed per fisherman has been decreased from unlimited to 1,000 metres.

(iii) Fishing during the breeding season, October to February has been banned. The effect of this is that the amount of effort applied to the resource can no longer put fish or crocodile populations in danger.
(d) The areas fished by professionals in Kakadu is relatively small, which can be confirmed by consulting a chart and would have minimal effect on overall park management.

(e) A.N.P.W.S. seems to ignore Justice Fox's recommendation in the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry report when it was recommended that commercial fishing should be allowed to continue and be restricted to the areas currently permitted. Since the Fox report potential effort is only about one fifth of what was available at that stage which makes a closure of the park to barramundi fishermen ludicrous.

I read that because of the interest shown by commercial fishermen in the Northern Territory in their own industry. I note that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources will visit the Northern Territory again next week and will hear further representations from the Northern Territory Commercial Fishermen's Association. The Committee will make recommendations in due course. Perhaps under those circumstances it would be inappropriate for me to discuss the matter here.

It is most important to finish on the note that Kakadu's delicate ecosystems must not be violated, and the plan before us, which the motion seeks to disallow, ensures long term viability of this marvellous World Heritage site. In speaking of World Heritage, I wish to read one paragraph from the Press statement put out jointly by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment. It says in paragraph 3:

The World Heritage List identifies areas of ``outstanding universal value'', the disappearance or destruction of which would constitute a ``harmful impoverishment of the heritage of all nations of the world''. Stage II of Kakadu National Park will be a fitting addition to the World Heritage List. It includes wetlands of major international significance, mangroves of great scientific interest and extensive archaeological and rock art sites.
I urge senators to reject the disallowance motion and so keep Kakadu clean, unspoiled and worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support the motion. We do not believe that the management plan should be disallowed, even though it is deficient in some areas which we will mention. However, we believe that it should be strengthened rather than weakened and it certainly should not be thrown out.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collard made a plea. He clothed it in reasonable terms, but really he is asking for open slather for his buddies in the New Right. He is pandering to those people; he wants to become the leader of the parliamentary wing of the New Right. The New Right wants to subjugate the entire work force of Australia. When it gets the work force working for 20c a day and the return of child labour and all the things that existed 100 years ago, then it will start digging up the front lawn of Parliament House. The New Right wants to dig up every patch of land in Australia. Senator Collard is attempting to do so himself. He says that mining is only a small speck in the vastness of our country and a small speck in the vastness of a national park. Perhaps it is a small speck, but what does a uranium mine look like to a tourist or someone who appreciates wilderness in a national park? For example, take a fine Beethoven recording, put one small scratch across that record and the whole thing is ruined. Having a uranium mine in a national park is ludicrous and having any more mines is unthinkable. Yet it is what Senator Collard wants, as do his Party and the Opposition in general. The Liberals go along with it; we have umpteen speakers on this matter and I am sure the Liberals will heap praise on the New Right and jump on the bandwagon because they too want open slather on every patch of land in Australia. They do not want any preserved for the people for the future.

Senator Collard talks about buffer zones. He says that these only consist of mongrel scrub so why not mine them in the national park. But it is a national park! He simply does not understand the concept of a national park-something that is to be preserved in its entirety in perpetuity. One cannot just separate a patch and say `This is mongrel scrub, we will mine this, but we will not mine other parts'. It is all the national park; it has boundaries. Those boundaries are not capricious, they have been set up to take account of the nature of Kakadu, the precious environment that it is and the entire ecosystem it comprises. The national parks in Australia have had a very chequered history. We finally do have a massive national park and that is Kakadu. Most of the national parks of this country are not national parks at all; they are State preserves. They are called national parks but they can be eliminated very easily and quickly with the stroke of a pen. We must cherish and preserve our true national parks, because they are endangered.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was pointing out that the National Party of Australia has been acting as the cutting edge for the New Right in its drive to get more and more access to what we hold dear in Australia. Senator Collard was the mover of the motion. I am reliably informed that his family brought forth to this country Collard's curse, the kikuyu grass, pennisetum clandestinum; so perhaps the idea of environmental utilisation, degradation and change runs in his genes.
—I think Senator Collard from north Queensland is a very respected person. Why don't you get on with your talk? How long have you been in Australia?

—I am talking about Collard's curse, the kikuyu grass. National parks should not be taken lightly in Australia. The New Right wants access to all national parks. Australia should be proud of its national parks because national parks actually started here in Australia. The first national park in the world was formed in 1879 when the term `national park' was applied to the Royal National Park near Sydney. America's famous Yellowstone National Park was not so named until a few years later.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told earlier by Senator Collard that this vast area would be locked up forever and that we should not lock up such a large area. He claimed that all stages of Kakadu National Park would be some 20,000 square kilometres. In fact, the parks of Africa are bigger than this. The parks in Kenya are bigger than all three stages of Kakadu. Kenya and other African countries are countries which we would consider Third World countries; poor, impoverished countries. Those countries are willing to set aside vast areas for national parks, yet we as a highly developed First World nation still want, apparently, according to Senator Collard, to determine what is there, see whether it is valuable, then change the classification so that we can mine it. I would be ashamed of our country if it took that course.

The International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, which was mentioned by Senator Robertson and Senator Collard, set forth standards for national parks and in fact Kakadu is in violation of one of those standards right now. At the Tenth General Assembly of the IUCN in New Delhi in 1969, the IUCN set rule 3, which states that the park should be reserved for specialised inspirational, educational, cultural and/or recreational public use. Yet here we have a uranium mine in a national park. I have been back to the United States and people there have said: `Gee, it sounds like you have a wonderful thing in that Kakadu, but what is a uranium mine doing in the middle of a national park?'. I said: `Frankly, it could only happen in Australia'. It was apparently some trade-off. It was the only way the park could be made. It is ridiculous to have a national park with a uranium mine in it; of all things, a uranium mine which is producing the substance of death. The substance of which wars and nuclear disasters are made is mined in a beautiful wilderness environment such as Kakadu. It makes no sense at all.

I am afraid that white Australians-I include myself-simply do not appreciate this land as do the original black Australians, the Aboriginal people. We may love our country, but we simply do not respect the land. Many of the people who came here first came against their will. They came from the northern hemisphere to an alien climate and an alien land. They learned to hate the land and many of them wanted to go back home to England. I am afraid that much of that attitude still exists. It certainly exists with the people of the New Right who simply want to rip off the land and move on. They do not mind what they leave behind; gouging, holes and roads. Sir Mark Oliphant said:

. . . the present policies of the Australian Government favour mining, farming and grazing as the sources of our wealth. These are the policies of a colonial government, not those of a proud, independent country.
How true it is, how sad it is.

The United States National Parks Service has in its enabling legislation a clause which states that the national parks of the United States are areas of notable environmental value and shall be preserved in perpetuity for future generations to enjoy. Yet here in Australia we find that this idea of preservation for future generations is derided by the New Right and the mining industry, which say: `You cannot lock something up forever'. Why not? If it is valuable now, it will be doubly or trebly valuable in the future; so we should lock it up now. Unfortunately we in Australia have the attitude of only making something a national park when the mining industry, loggers or hydro people do not want it. If they say that they do not need that area for anything, we make it into a national park. That is the residual approach and we simply cannot afford that sort of thing.

Another viewpoint, which I am sure will be quite alien to the members of the Opposition, including the National Party, is that park areas deserve to exist for the benefit of the species involved, not for tourism, mining or even for the benefit of future generations of people. That is the biocentric view; that plants and animals have a right to exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —And people.

—People certainly have a right to exist, but since they have the ability to destroy all other forms of life on earth, they also have a responsibility. In Alaska, where I lived for a number of years when I was a bush pilot, I flew into the Alaskan Eskimo settlements. The Eskimos had such respect for their surroundings that they would actually apologise to an animal before they killed it. They had the awareness that that animal had the right to live. Some Opposition senators are laughing; it is ludicrous to them that anyone could so appreciate his or her environment that he or she would actually apologise to an animal before killing it. But that is what has kept those societies alive for so many thousands of years. This society will not last for that long because we have completely lost touch with the sustaining environment around us.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the plan of management for Kakadu? I do not support it entirely because it is too development oriented, too tourist oriented, and it takes too little account of the tremendous value of Kakadu. It is an excuse, a compromise document. I am sure that the people who drafted it had a great deal of knowledge of and appreciation for the true value of Kakadu, but they thought that in this society they would have to sell it in terms of its economic value. They did not think that they could sell it in terms of its value as an area, an environment; so they have gone through and put in these plans for management in terms of visitor accommodation, roads and tourist facilities. I am afraid that they have gone far too far. However, they have restricted mineral operations in the plan of management. This is good.

I would like to run briefly through my criticisms of the plan of management. Tourism is only one of the uses of the park and it should not be the main reason for its existence. I do not think that any apology has to be made for the rest of the park. It is regrettable that because of the delay in adding stage 3 the plan of management is only for stages 1 and 2. After all, the park is an entity, an entire area, so the plan should be made for all of Kakadu and it should include stage 3. The plan of management should have provision for the traditional Aboriginal owners to be represented on the board of management. This has been done at Uluru, so why could it not be done at Kakadu? The draft plan of management is only reacting to the existing uses. The policy objectives should be clearly outlined in the plan of management. A study is needed of the tourist carrying capacity of the park. Restrictions on numbers of tourists may be necessary. People in the United States of America have found that in wilderness areas-which much of Kakadu is-they have actually had to put in registration lists, sometimes years ahead, for people to go into these areas because they know that the carrying capacity of the land is quite low and that tourists themselves could love the park to death. This may have to be done in parts of Kakadu.

The developments for tourists are excessive at the moment. They will encourage vast numbers of tourists to come in who have neither the knowledge nor the ability to survive in the area and it may cause difficulties for their own safety. The matter of accommodation is a vexed one in the park. I feel that all accommodation other than the low impact camping should be sited outside and not inside the park. An environmental impact study should be required on all major developments because this is a very fragile environment. Four-wheel drive vehicles should be strictly controlled. There should be no off-road usage of four-wheel drive vehicles because we know of the damage that they can do to the fragile economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And motor-bikes.

—And motor-bikes, certainly. Commercial fishing should cease immediately and recreational fishing should be strictly controlled. There should be no gun clubs at Jabiru and no hunting in the park. A number of workers at Jabiru have guns and it is a problem to the park management that these people go out and shoot the guns in the park. There should be no horse-riding in the park, no further airport development and the wilderness zones need to be declared over extensive areas of the park to limit the access. Feral animals should be eradicated and intensive efforts should be made to eradicate mimosa-the weed that has come in as a result of buffalo grazing in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Government say about the area? We have had some statements from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the Government will not allow any more mining activity in stage 1 and stage 2. We welcome that, but what about stage 3? I wish to quote from an article in Darwin's Northern Territory News of Monday, 13 October 1986, which is headed `More mining: that's the tip'. The article states:
Federal Cabinet is moving towards allowing mining to proceed in at least 35 per cent of Kakadu National Park's recently announced Stage 3.
Reliable sources in Canberra said today the Federal Government's recent go-ahead for mining at Coronation Hill was expected to be extended to other potential mining regions within Stage 3.

Several Cabinet ministers, including the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, are reported to strongly favour more mining going ahead `in the national interest' within the extended Kakadu boundaries. Federal Resources and Energy Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, is known to be among the Ministers who support the Territory Government in its case for mining at least Stage 3.

Of course, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is the man who called this country clapped out buffalo country. This is about equivalent to our Premier of Tasmania calling the Franklin a brown, leech-ridden ditch. Of course, it is not clapped out buffalo country. It has far more value than the Minister for Resources and Energy has implied. When the management plan came up and the New Right prevailed upon Senator Collard to raise this motion, the New Right also sent out a letter. The letter I have is from the Australian Mining Industry Council over the signature of its Executive Director, Lauchlan McIntosh. He wishes me to support Senator Collard and he lists a series of reasons why he wishes me to do so. He states:
About 13,000 square kilometres of land with high mineral potential will be locked up;
Australia will never know whether there are mineral deposits there that could be mined without adversely affecting the prime function of the Park;
This is rubbish. No mining could take place without adversely affecting the prime function of the park. The letter continues:
Australia will forgo the economic, employment and other benefits that mining in the Park could bring;
Australia will deny itself access to a source of raw materials for export and for use in expanding local secondary industries;
Australia will deny Aborigines access to the economic benefits that would flow from exploration and mining on land they own within the Park;
Australians will forgo excise, income tax and company taxes, jobs and infrastructure development;

So it goes on. What a load of absolute garbage. What about jobs? We have the Robe River dispute. What did Peko-Wallsend do? It sacked 1,100 workers. What about jobs? Peko-Wallsend is saying that it will bring about jobs. As far as it is concerned workers are mere profit fodder. When the workers are no longer valuable to it in some way and when it receives a few cents less in royalty for the minerals and it just does not want to have the workers around any more, they are gone. That is what happens to jobs. What a load of garbage. The letter from the Australian Mining Industry Council mentions `infrastructure development'. The infrastructure development brought about on behalf of the mining industry is what has caused the fiscal demise of this country. Over and over again throughout the last 20 years we, as taxpayers, were told that, if we supported a road, or a railway, or a power plant, these wonderful mining companies would come and put in some sort of development and bring jobs and prosperity to us all. We have blown all our dough on infrastructure. The mining companies are pulling out. They are firing people and they are saying: `It is not economic. We will go overseas'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They paid for them, be honest.

—Oh, they have, have they? Why are we in so much trouble financially then? Why is our secondary industry so neg- lected? It is because we poured all our money into infrastructure development for the honourable senator's buddies in the New Right. People on the Opposition side in the National Party of Australia are actually supporting the New Right in all its claims, desires and demands. Why?
—They are being told what to do.
—They are being told what to do. Does the honourable senator think they are being bribed?
—No, I don't think so.

—I do not think so. I do not think they are smart enough to be bribed. I do not think they actually realise the value of what they are giving away. They are too naive. People overseas, at least in Mexico and America, understand the value of this sort of thing and they say: `Sure, I want about $100,000 under the table to put through a Bill like this or a disallowance motion'. Here they do it simply because they do not know any better. They have no idea of the true value of what they want to give away to the New Right.
—Leaderless, no leadership.

—They are leaderless as well. Along with this letter from the Australian Mining Industry Council is a nicely prepared little brochure which is headed `Kakadu-The Case for Conservation and Development'. Do honourable senators think that conservation and development are both possible? I do not. I do not even think that the Australian Mining Industry Council thinks they are possible. It has really stretched a point here. The brochure under the heading `Modern Exploration has Little Impact' states:

SPEECH.PARA: The mining industry has developed exploration techniques which have extremely little or no impact whatsoever on the land surface.

That is an absolute lie. Anyone who has flown across the Simpson Desert would have seen bulldozer tracks transect, mile after mile, across the desert in a grid pattern. They still exist after years and they will always exist. Yet honourable senators talk about the little impact. They have completely changed the ecology of the whole area. It is a very fragile arid ecology. It cannot stand bulldozers wandering around on it. The brochure states further:
. . . the impact of much of the normal routine ground work such as geological mapping and the collection of small rock, soil or stream samples is barely perceptible.
Later exploration stages such as drilling and trenching do, of course, affect the immediate environment, but they occur on a limited scale only in the target area.

What a load of rubbish. If honourable senators doubt this, I urge them simply to take a look at some of the Landsat aerial photography of the area. They will see the impact of mining exploration everywhere but in the national parks and they want to extend it to the national parks. The brochure under the heading `Mining and the Environment are not Incompatible' also states:
The industry is used to working under such rules-
as were put down in the Kakadu region-
It has, over many years, built up a level of skill and ability in managing water quality . . .
What a joke. The industry claims that it can manage water quality. It got itself into trouble in the first place through its own stupidity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Send them down to Queenstown.

—We have talked about the mining industry and its environmental sensitivity but look at Queenstown. It has completely denuded Queenstown in Tasmania-my poor, benighted State. It has completely denuded an area of vegetation, not only trees but also vegetation. It looks like the face of the moon. Our highly responsible, environmentally-conscious mining industry did that and it is proud of it. Even today it is proud of it. Talk about the water at Kakadu. At Ranger the industry actually impounded water before it had to and this has caused massive difficulties with discharge. They have had discharges. It has held the Government to ransom over its discharges. It cannot manage water in this area. It is a very high rainfall area, and it simply does not know how to manage it. It says it is expert at rehabilitating mined land and caring for the environment in a manner that is equal to, or better than, any in the world today. That is palpably false; it is simply untrue. Yet we are expected to believe that we can have development in a national park. In the first place, even the roads leading to a development in a national park cause a massive impact not only on the direct environment but also in terms of fire and other impacts that human beings can have. The project itself completely degrades a national park. I have been to Ranger. It has two huge open pit mines, huge tailing dams, a great yellow pile of sulphur and tin sheds. It is an atrocity.
—What area does it cover?

—It does not matter how much area it covers. It is supposed to be an area of wilderness. The honourable senator is obviously quite insensitive-probably insensible as well-if he feels that that is an excuse simply because it is a small thing. It is a visual blot on a landscape which should be pristine. I am afraid that we will have to be classified as a second rate society indeed if we cannot set aside a small section of wilderness in our vast, developed continent so that our children and their children's children can see at first hand what the whole world looked like before the developers, bulldozers, chainsaws and all the rest of the technological marvels destroyed the environmental balance forever. I very strongly oppose this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Collard in opposing this management plan for Kakadu National Park. I believe that in the society we have today we need a sense of balance. We in the Opposition accept, as do the responsible mining industry, Aborigines and other balanced people, that a number of spectacular and scenic areas which could be called environmentally fragile zones and sites of Aboriginal significance should not be disturbed in Kakadu and that the park itself is justifiably famous for its spectacular escarpment and its wetland area. It should be stated, however, that even at the height of the monsoon season the wetlands cover only about 16 per cent of Kakadu stages 1 and 2.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collard has pointed out that, with the inclusion of stage 2, the total area which would be covered not only by a national park but also by a World Heritage area will be in the order of 13,000 square kilometres, and when stage 3 is declared as a national park that area will cover 20,000 square kilometres which is approximately 100 by 200 kilometres. We have also made it clear that the escarpment, the wetlands and the Aboriginal art areas are not in dispute. We are saying, however, that we should have a management of the region with its various planned uses producing a harmonious relationship between the various activities, whether they be park management, environmental protection, mining or tourism. Good management and good will can lead to natural resources being obtained with a minimum of interference to the region's inhabitants and environment.

I will quote from a comment made by a mines Minister from one of the States. He said that his Cabinet endorsed a package of recommendations to take the process of development further in a balanced way. He said that the package is designed to foster multiple land use concepts and ensure that no land is alienated from exploration without careful consideration of the sub-surface mineral or petroleum potential, relevant economic factors and the existing and potential sub-surface rights. That comment was made in a speech by the Minister of Mines from South Australia, Mr Ron Payne, to the South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy on 11 September 1986. I think the major problem that has occurred in this whole management plan has been that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has lost all credibility with the Northern Territory Government, the people of the Northern Territory and the Aboriginal people.

On 16 September the Federal Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment wrote to the Northern Territory Minister, Mr Coulter, assuring him that the Commonwealth would adhere to agreed guidelines in respect of any proposed listing of Kakadu stage 2. The Council of Nature Conservation Ministers agreement stated that the Northern Territory Government would be consulted. I will quote from a letter of that date to Mr Barry Coulter from the Federal Minister. That letter was received by Mr Coulter on 19 September. In that letter the Federal Minister said:

Should the Commonwealth decide to pursue World Heritage listing of the former Stage 2 area, your Government will be consulted in accordance with the CONCOM agreement prior to any approach being made to the World Heritage Secretariat in Paris.

The date of that letter was 16 September. On 17 September 1986, the day afterwards, documentation was forwarded to the World Heritage Commission by the Commonwealth nominating Kakadu stage 2 for inclusion in the World Heritage List. This was obviously a deception by the Minister of the Northern Territory Government. There is no way in the world that this proposal could have been sent and that this documentation could have been forwarded if it had not been planned days and perhaps weeks in advance. Yet the very day before that documentation was sent there was a letter from Mr Barry Cohen:
. . . your Government will be consulted in accordance with the CONCOM agreement . . .

Again, we have the slight differences. It would be useful if we could have a degree of honesty on this matter. At the meeting between Australia and the World Heritage Commission in February 1986 the Commonwealth pointed out-a subtle difference, I know-that it has indicated that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas of world heritage without the agreement of the State or the Territory concerned. It goes on to say:
In the Government's view, such action, if it occurred, would be likely to lead to confrontation with States or Territories which may well do more harm than good in the long run.
At another meeting between Australia and the World Heritage Commission in September 1986, a few months later, there was a subtle change of words:
The Commonwealth Government has indicated that it will not normally nominate areas for World Heritage listing without the agreement of the State or Territory concerned.

What faith, what confidence, can the States and the Territories have in this Government and in this Minister when one day a letter says `don't worry, we will consult you' and the very next day the submission is made to have stage 2 of Kakadu nominated for World Heritage listing? No wonder there is concern within the Northern Territory when this sort of thing happens.

The Minister used melodramatic words that would come better from Senator Sanders than Mr Cohen. He referred to the `Swiss cheesing' of Kakadu National Park. He was talking about the exploration of the stage 2 area to determine just what sorts of minerals we have within the ground, and the determination of that wealth, if there is any, to decide the proper and balanced management plan that should be implemented. The Minister uses the emotional phrase of `Swiss cheesing'. I think it is most important that Australians know what we are going to lock up in an area that is not only declared a national park but also proposed to be part of the national heritage.

It has been claimed that we are looking at various resources. Let us take, as an example, the Ranger uranium site. The energy produced from Ranger uranium provides fuel for about 30,000 megawatts of power, or about one and a half times Australia's total yearly power requirements. We have a financial crisis in Australia today, probably one of the worst financial crises this country has seen for many years; we have a balance of payments deficit for this year alone of approximately $16 billion to $17 billion; and we have a total foreign debt of over $100 billion. I do not believe that we can just willy-nilly lock up potential areas without even knowing what is there.

Once again, we are not debating stage 1, we are not debating the Aboriginal art areas and we are not debating the other sensitive areas within stage 2. We are saying that we should not lock up an area-if this legislation goes through, it will be included on the World Heritage List-of approximately 13,000 square kilometres, and stage 3 will be 20,000 square kilometres, because this country will regret it. I know and honourable senators opposite will know that the move to lock these areas up was not made with the support of the Minister for Resources and Energy Senator Gareth Evans, and probably did not have the support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It was a knee-jerk reaction caused by some of the more radical people on the Government benches.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was recommended by Fox.

—Senator, this was not the idea of Senator Evans; it was not the idea of the Prime Minister. It was something that was foisted upon them. My belief is that this will be to their eternal regret. We are not disagreeing with a proper, balanced management plan. We are disagreeing with some sort of sop to the ilk of Senator Sanders and the sorts of people within the Labor Party who share his viewpoint.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to comment on the remarks made by Senator Robertson. He talked about media disinformation, and about uranium amounting to approximately 350,000 tonnes, the majority being outside stage 2. The point is that we do not know what is inside stage 2. The Government is also not consistent. It talks about allowing no mining whatsoever and it excludes Coronation Hill. I am not complaining about the exclusion of Coronation Hill. I am talking about the total inconsistency when the Government says: `We will not allow this, but we will exclude Coronation Hill because we know there are good economic reserves there'. The point I am making is that it is important that we know what other economic reserves are included in stages 2 and 3 of Kakadu. I reaffirm that the Opposition supports Senator Collard's proposals in opposing the management plan laid down by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to say that it gives me some pleasure to enter the debate tonight, but really I enter this debate with considerable concern. I am the senator for the Northern Territory.
—You are one of the senators.

—Whatever the Minister wishes. I am one of two senators for the Northern Territory. I have lived in the Northern Territory for some 50-odd years. Like very many Territorians, I have spent much of my time in the bush of the Northern Territory. I doubt whether anyone who has accompanied me in my journeys through the bush and followed my life in the Northern Territory could accuse me of wishing to destroy the environment. I believe that the future of my family is in the Northern Territory. If a person believes that his family has a future in the Northern Territory, he must have due regard for its environment, its development, and the betterment of its people. It has many races. Aborigines comprise some 25 per cent to 30 per cent of the population. Non-Aboriginal people are much more extensive. Many people have come to the Northern Territory from many parts of the world. It includes some 75 to 80 nationalities. They look upon the Northern Territory as their future.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to represent them, because I know that I represent their views. I have been through various elections in my political career. I have spent some 12 years in the Senate and some 16 years in the Legislative Council and the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory. Over that period I have not lost an election. By so doing, I believe that I represent the majority viewpoint of the people of the Northern Territory. Fortunately for me, I have had their assistance, acknowledgment and support. I represent the viewpoint of many people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not being challenged for pre-selection like Senator Robertson is.

—That is quite true, as the honourable senator has said. I am under no pressure whatsoever to win just another election. As I have indicated before, after some 26 or 27 years in parliamentary service it is not my intention to seek re-election; so there is absolutely no pressure on me to do other than speak my mind on behalf of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are discussing the disallowance of the Kakadu National Park plan of management. Kakadu, like Uluru and the bush of the Northern Territory, is very close to my heart. The debate concerns a vitally important part of Australia, over 20,000 square kilometres of the Northern Territory, which makes up stages 1 and 2 and the proposed stage 3 of Kakadu National Park. The outcome of this debate may well determine the future of an area as big as Wales in Great Britain. Kakadu is far larger than at least 20 of the world's smallest countries.

Attempts have been made to reduce the debate on Kakadu to an emotive argument about an unspoilt wilderness, the totality of which is about to be destroyed unless it is absolutely protected from development by tourism, mining, fishing or other commercial interests. The statements of people such as Professor Ovington, who is head of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, that the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources into the future of Kakadu was not concerned with the national park but with mining in the first area that Australia had put on the World Heritage List, are indicative of the sort of argument put up to justify the stagnation of mining or other industries such as tourism in Kakadu. It may be true that Kakadu was the first area in Australia to be World Heritage listed but we need to consider whether it should have been listed in the first place, or at least whether the area which was listed should have been listed in its entirety.

I believe the decision to list this amount of land in the Kakadu area was taken irresponsibly and without due regard to the interests of this nation and particularly to the development of the north and the Northern Territory and its people. There are areas in Kakadu which are absolutely magnificent and unique and which should rightfully be preserved and protected. The fact remains, too, that sections of the area, far from being unspoilt wilderness, are basically scrub. I believe a disservice was done not only to Australia but also to the World Heritage Commission itself when this area was so listed without responsible description. I doubt very much whether the World Heritage Commission would want its credibility brought into question by governments or lobby groups using it as a shield. That is what this Government and the ANPWS are attempting to do. They use this area's place on the World Heritage List to justify their refusal to allow mining to proceed even in areas which are, as I have said, nothing more than scrub. For those people listening tonight who might wonder what scrub is, it is, in the outback of Australia, a hardy growth which survives in a hardy terrain, and it is not necessarily a part of the beautiful escarpment we are discussing tonight. No one is talking about digging up this magnificent escarpment or the other areas which are undoubtedly very beautiful, spectacular and to be preserved. The plan of management for this area should address multiple land use issues and provide guidelines which would facilitate land use within the park in keeping with its status as a park. This plan of management does not do that.

To take the most controversial point and the major failing of the plan of management first, the mining provisions are totally inadequate and unacceptable. Paragraph 11.6 of the management plan deals with operations for the recovery of minerals. This very brief paragraph sets out provisions of section 8 (b) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 which in effect provides that the provisions of the plan of management do not affect any interest in respect of land or minerals on, in or beneath that land, held immediately before the land was declared to be within the park. At sub-paragraph 11.6.3 of the plan the management prescriptions state that the main objective is to protect the park's resources from exploitation and to implement this objective subject to section 8 (b) of the Act. No operations for the recovery of minerals will be carried out in the park.

The mining provisions of the plan are therefore deficient in at least three critical aspects. First, they preclude development and exploration of mineral resources not located upon existing leases; secondly, they fail to address conditions to apply to mining on pre-existing leases; and, thirdly, they fail to provide assurances on the protection of existing applications. I shall go into these matters in a little more detail. First, the preclusion of development and exploration upon other than existing leases means that no mineral deposits not located within existing leases in stages 1 and 2 will be able to be developed. It would also prevent further exploration and development of minerals not located within leases within stage 3 once that stage is declared. Obviously it will be declared, as was indicated just a little while ago in an offhand manner. The prospective mineral wealth of the region is such that any decision or action, such as that before us tonight, which could effectively put an end to future resource development is of significant economic consequence to the entire nation.

Stages 1 and 2 envelop a vast proportion of the Alligator Rivers region which is recognised as containing a high percentage of the world's most important energy resource, uranium, as well as gold, silver, tin, lead, tungsten, zinc, copper and platinum. Stage 3 is also high prospective for all of these minerals, with Coronation Hill showing great potential for gold and platinum production. The potential mineral riches of Kakadu, if mined, could total from $70,000m to $100,000m on today's values. Coronation Hill is assessed as having gold, platinum and uranium deposits to the value of $5,000m. Passing the plan of management will lock up that mineral wealth at a time when Australia needs every export dollar it can get. This economically irresponsible Federal Government is ready to just shrug off potential export earnings of the magnitude to which I have just referred. Billions of dollars will go down the drain.

I say again, as a senator for the Northern Territory, that the protection of the environment that we are aiming for and development of mineral resources can be brought about by a balanced plan of management involving multi-use. If anyone in Australia does not believe me, I suggest that he not listen to some of the debate tonight but go to the Northern Territory and make up his mind as to the future development of Kakadu.
