As I have said, there is every reason for the multi-use of this land for the benefit of those who love the country, as I do, but who also love to see the Territory and the north develop in their rightful way.

But it is not just mineral development on other than existing leases that the plan fails to provide for. Even those prospectors or com- panies which have existing interests in the park are effectively prohibited from exploring or developing those interests because such activity can proceed only in accordance with the guidelines set out in the plan of management. By not including any guidelines such activity is precluded. It means that, as there are no guidelines set down within the plan of management, there is no future for mining in this area. The warehouse of future wealth for Australia cannot be assessed. What fools members of the Government and people are who say that an assessment of this wealth should not be brought about so that we will know what is available to be put into our warehouse.

The third issue which arises in relation to the future of mining in Kakadu is: What is to become of those who possess applications, as opposed to leases, over land in the park? The Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Professor Ovington, has foreshadowed a contest over whether existing mining applications would constitute an existing interest and would survive the declaration of the park. Those are legal questions to be assessed and determined. Professor Ovington has suggested that, while it seems clear that leases would be protected, the status of applications would need to be tested before the court. The plan of management before the Senate fails to give any undertaking regarding the protection of those interests, the interests of Australians, the interest of pioneers and the interests of people who are prepared to go out into the bush and give it a go.

The holders of these interests include mining companies, many of which spent considerable amounts on exploration prior to 1973 when they were given assurances by Dr Rex Patterson, a Minister in the Whitlam Government. I remember Dr Rex Patterson very well. If ever there was a member of parliament who worked for the development of the north, it was Dr Rex Patterson. He was on the opposite side of politics to me; he was a Minister in the Whitlam Labor Government. I regret very much that Dr Rex Patterson is not in the Parliament of Australia today. He was interested in the development of the north. Dr Rex Patterson said that, if the mining companies surrendered their interests to enable the declaration of the park to proceed, they would be issued with fresh titles to complete their exploration programs following the declaration. This is what happened: Relying on those assurances, the companies surrendered their titles, but to date no fresh title has been issued. Dr Patterson gave that assurance in good faith but he has been let down by his fellow Labor colleagues.

To give an idea of just how much money has gone into exploration, I understand that Denison Australia Pty Ltd has spent about $150m on the Koongarra project and Pancontinental Mining Ltd has spent about $49m at Jabiluka. Of course, these are uranium deposits and not able to be developed under the Federal Labor Government's present three-mine policy-a ludicrous policy arrived at out of political expediency and a need to pander to the left wing of the ALP. It is ironic to note that the operative uranium mine at Ranger was established during the Whitlam era. That Government could hardly be accused of having ignored environmental issues. A recent article in the Bulletin drew attention to the fact that the environmental impact of bulldozing the road into Kakadu for the purposes of extracting its uranium, of developing the north, for the security of the north and to serve the Aboriginal settlements, et cetera, was 10,000 times greater in magnitude than all of the mining activities in the Northern Territory put together. I am talking about the environmental impact of bulldozers. The article by Dr Leslie Kemmeny, a senior lecturer in nuclear engineering at the University of New South Wales, makes the very valid point that there is no alternative to the peaceful nuclear fuel cycle. That is what our uranium should be used for-energy. Dr Kemmeny said:

The country which continues to burn or deplete its irreplenishible fossil and hydrocarbon resources is depriving future generations of fuel for transport and feed stock for plastics, pharmaceutical and agricultural industries. It is also destroying earth's environment.
He also said:

The problem in Australia is that for more than 30 years we have had to wait for a pragmatic, well-informed peaceful nuclear policy. We still do not have it. Political expediency still rules decisions in this area. No wonder our traditional partners for uranium are restless and our competitors are laughing!

It is no wonder. Dr Kemmeny has articulated the view of many people in this country who believe that not only should Australia be mining its uranium but also we should be working belatedly towards the development of enrichment facilities in this country. We should be involved in the full nuclear fuel cycle. The vast majority of our uranium for the development of nuclear energy is in Kakadu. While we sit here, and while many people in this chamber are ready simply to dismiss billions of dollars worth of potential uranium exports, not to mention frustrating the development of the north, our competitors are scooping the pool. Let us not be fooled by those who say that there are not markets for uranium. The markets are there and there is no doubt that, if existing mines were allowed to increase production and new mines allowed to come on line, there would be no problem in obtaining contracts. That is very obvious.

This plan of management, while it does not specifically relate to uranium mining, relates to all mining and has the potential to deprive Australia of export markets which are vitally important, and deprive the world of an energy source which is essential for many countries, such as France which generates 70 per cent of its power from nuclear energy. Of course, we have noticed that the Labor Government has agreed that France should be supplied. But we have sufficient uranium to supply not only France but many countries in the free world.

I also wish to mention very briefly that mining in the park, while it has been grabbing the headlines, is not the only issue for which the plan of management fails adequately to provide. One other very important consideration is tourism. At present there are totally inadequate tourist accommodation facilities available to cater for the thousands of visitors to Kakadu each year. As the numbers grow, the need for substantial accommodation becomes more urgent. Whilst the plan states that, at the discretion of the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, some tourist accommodation may be constructed, this is not enough. The plan ignores the need for a co-ordinated approach to tourist development. The Territory Government has been extremely successful in promoting the Top End as a tourist destination and has supported the construction of first class tourist facilities at the Yulara resort at Ayers Rock. In Alice Springs and Darwin we have seen the construction of a number of international standard hotels, which are accommodating the very many international tourists, as well as interstate tourists, now visiting the Territory. The impression I get, reading through this plan, is that there is an aversion to providing moderate to large scale accommodation in Kakadu. It refers to camp sites and caravan parks, which are, no doubt, also very necessary. A range of accommodation options must be available to tourists, but there is no reason why accommodation of international standard cannot be provided in such a way as to fit in with the park and have a minimal impact on the environment. If anyone doubts whether this is possible, one need only look at Yulara to see just how well a large accommodation complex can be adapted to suit the environment.

Lest anyone be under the misapprehension that such facilities would not be welcomed by the traditional Aboriginal owners, I assure all honourable senators that that is far from the case. The attitude of the Gagadju Association is that it is striving to develop tourist accommodation at Jabiru. Only the ANPWS, the Federal body, stands in its way, in the same way as that organisation and the Federal Government stand in the way of the development of uranium on traditional Aboriginal land. Senator Zakharov, who is trying to interject, has been up there and knows full well what the Aborigines believe in. They say: `Let us have a fair go to be able to develop ourselves'. They say that they do not have to live on government handouts, which is what the honourable senator wants them to do. She wants them to be subjected to the Federal Government so that their very existence is a handout to handout situation from day to day whereby they are not allowed to develop. As an example, Uranerz has recently come to an agreement with the Aboriginal people of Arnhem Land. Yet unless there is some change to Federal Government policy no progress will be able to be made on the development of mineral deposits which are the subject of this agreement, an agreement, as I said, entered into by the Aboriginal people.

There are other deficiencies in this plan of management, including its proposal regarding the phasing out of commercial fishing in the park, in spite of the fact that the two species principally concerned-barramundi and crab-could by no means be regarded as at risk under existing arrangements. I emphasise those words: `under existing arrangements'. Those who drafted this plan, I fear, suffer severely from tunnel vision and short-sightedness, much like the Australian Labor Party-particularly its left wing. Under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act the Director of the Service is required to provide comments on representations received on the plan of management which was released for public comment. If one looks at the comments accompanying this plan, it is difficult to imagine a less scholarly, less scientific treatment of this requirement under the Act. The Director of the ANPWS has allocated a number to each representation and added up those in favour of the plan and those against in order to show, in terms of these numbers, that the plan is well supported. Every representation is treated with equal weight. A lengthy representation prepared by the best brains in the country would carry the same weight as a sentence from a primary school student under this primitive method. There is no comment on individual submissions. Instead, for every topic the Director selects a series of one- or two-sentence quotations from some of the representations and provides a generalised comment. It is extremely dubious whether comments on a few selected quotations fulfil the requirements of the Act. There is no doubt that it contravenes the spirit.

The Northern Territory Government provided a comprehensive representation which was highly critical of the proposed plan of management in a number of important respects. It is frustrating that this representation has been totally ignored. It is reprehensible that it has not even been directly commented on by the Director. For the Northern Territory Government to be relegated to the status of a minor lobby group is intolerable. The Northern Territory Government is the duly elected Government of the region. If a democratic voice is to be brought to bear on the issues involved in management of the park, it is more likely to come from this source than from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, the ANPWS or environmental groups. The Northern Territory Government's criticisms were not accommodated in the plan of management. They have not been addressed by the Director's comments and they still stand.

Time is running out, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I thank you for that time. In closing I say that the plan, if it is passed and implemented, will deprive the Northern Territory and Australia of vital resources. It will ensure that the undisputed natural beauty of Kakadu remains the province of a select group, which has demonstrated little regard for the true interests of the nation. If the Government and the Australian Democrats pass this plan, they will be guilty of committing a grave disservice to the nation and will, I hope, be judged accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure for me to take part in this debate. As a member of the Senate I have visited the Kakadu park several times over the last seven or eight years. It is one of the areas of natural interest that I have visited in many parts of the world. Such areas are highly prized in other countries. I cite such places as the Kinabalu National Park in Sabah and areas in Europe, the United States of America and Britain. I can say without any risk of denial or contradiction that in the Kakadu National Park we have something which is so much better and so much more significant in world terms than any of the places I have mentioned that it is just beyond discussion. This is a point which I very much want to get across to honourable senators and to those who are listening, because the Kakadu National Park is a long way off, up in the Northern Territory, and most of the people in Australia are not up there; they are down here in south-eastern Australia. What I want to get across is that we have something there which, at all costs, must be preserved in its natural form so that it can be handed on in a pristine, natural form to our children, our grandchildren and to those who come after them.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with my colleague Senator Sanders, who spoke earlier in this debate, that the park needs no justification in economic terms. It justifies itself. It is something of enormous significance to this country. It is one of those things which make me go back to those well known words: In spite of our economic problems we truly are in the lucky country, because we have such a tremendous diversity of habitat, land forms, nature forms and animal and plant forms on this continent. This generation of Australians, then, has an absolute responsibility to preserve them. It should also have the sense of vision to look forward into the future far enough to see how even our economic interests are best served. I do not agree entirely with Senator Sanders's criticism of this plan of management for Kakadu. He mildly criticised it for what he called attempts to justify the park on economic grounds by providing tourist accommodation, roads and things of that kind. But this is a world-as can be seen from what we have heard from the Opposition-in which natural values are not necessarily of any great significance and in which it is necessary perhaps to compromise one's principles to the extent of saying that there are economic aspects to this matter that ought to be looked at.

Unfortunately, in this world, the fate of the park may well rest on the proposition that it is better for Australia in the long run-and worth more money to Australia-not to mine it and to keep it in its original, pristine state. The fact is that anybody who has looked recently at some other parts of the world such as Japan, Europe and places of that kind, will realise that there are very few places left in the world which are natural and original in their pristine state. Where such places do exist, the people of those countries guard them with the utmost jealousy and they are anxious to go there. In America, the number of people allowed to go into national parks has been limited because of the danger of damage to them that could arise from unlimited access to them. In Japan, the areas of natural beauty to which Japanese people can go are pitifully small. They, very reasonably, are very interested in other parts of the world where that kind of facility is available.

The Kakadu National Park, of course, is one of those rare places left in the world that have that kind of value. As the decades go on, it will be appreciated in Australia that in this area there is, in effect, better pay dirt than could be achieved through mining. If we leave the park alone, keep it under a proper plan of management-there will always be disagreement on what that is-and do not allow it to be the subject of mineral exploration and mineral development on any kind of large scale, in future times it will be worth enormous sums of money to Australia. Future generations will see tourists going to the area in their tens of thousands. It will be a major export income earner. But if in the meantime the area is ruined by unlimited mining-and it will be ruined if mining proceeds-we will have thrown all that away for short term gain which we would hope to get in our own time. As I shall say later, even that gain is not really there; it is illusory, Those of us who have not learned that so far in this country are fools.

We all thought eight or 10 years ago that the mining boom would sustain us right through into the 21st century, which was great. There was all that uranium, coal and iron; we would continue to be the lucky country and everybody would buy those commodities. But that was not the case. We put faith in that area of our economy to our great cost. It is now time that every Australian and every member of parliament recognised that. We have made a boo-boo, and a pretty bad one it is. What is happening to our economy at the moment is largely attributable to that. Our job now is to try to salvage the situation and not to make the same mistakes in future as we have made in the past. One area in which that is basically of great significance is in our attitude towards areas of enormous natural merit such as the park.

I was greatly entranced with the East Alligator River and its strange flora and fauna, its backwaters, its sandbanks, its birds and especially its crocodiles sliding off mudbanks at spots where Japanese tourists can photograph them. These features are worth a very great deal of money to this country. When one goes to Japan, as I have done, one finds that the people there agree. They want to come here and want to see these sights. But they do not want to come to a place that has been pockmarked all over with uranium mines, with ancient roads going across and uranium trucks or any kind of mining trucks trundling across the landscape. Surely we are not so naive as to think that in that way we shall retain the Kakadu National Park as an area of great beauty. Will the people coming along from other countries, with their attitudes towards their natural assets, think that it is great to see these vehicles trundling through these areas, and that it is economic and fine that we should be going in for mining of that sort? Those visitors will laugh at us and regard us as the barbarians of the twentieth century, and with good reason. If that is the sort of reputation Opposition members want for this country I can assure them that it is not the sort of reputation the Australian Democrats want for this country.

There are certain standards in the world that are set and kept in environmental matters, and they are pretty high. They are high because other countries which have been bitten hard by the disease of development have found out from bitter experience that if one goes on long enough destroying natural assets, there is not much left in the end. There are a few pitiful fragments left and one nurtures and cherishes them. It is pitiful to go to Japan to the few areas of natural beauty and to see how carefully the people there have nurtured and looked after them. We would not think twice about those areas. To us they would be nothing but scrub. We must get away from the insularity of our outlook and do something about it.

I try to wax fervent and emotional on this matter because I am very concerned about what I have heard from the Opposition. The course of democracy being what it is, it is quite possible that at the next election or the election after that this mob over here on my right may get back to government. I shudder to think what will happen to the Kakadu National Park in that eventuality, judging by what we have heard in this House today. The park will be plundered, torn apart and virtually destroyed. That is something the people of this country should not tolerate. For that reason the more people in Australia in the environmental movement and outside it who understand that here we have an asset of enormous importance to us and who make that known to the Government and to the Opposition and get across the feeling that interference with Kakadu National Park is an electoral no-no for everybody, the sooner something will be done about preserving the area.

We know that the Opposition is under pressure from the Australian Mining Industry Council and the miners. We do not have to investigate the nature of that pressure too far. At some time I would like the Opposition to explain to me the nature of that pressure. I do not think that I shall be given a very honest answer. The point is that anybody who thinks that there will be any sort of restriction over mining in the Kakadu National Park is kidding himself. Once there is any kind of mining, it continues. As those of us who have been through the area know only too well, the uranium is the bottom line for the Kakadu National Park. I do not care what the Prime Minister is saying now, once one starts mining in that area it is the bottom line because that is the most prominent mineralisation of that area. It is a uranium mine or potential uranium mine of vast proportions. If anybody says `No, we will only go there for gold or platinum', that is nonsense. They will go there and when they get the gold and platinum, they will say: `Oh, there is all this uranium here. It is uneconomic not to do something with it'. Then we will be back where we started.

I have seen a lot of material coming out from the public relations area of the mining industry recently saying that one can mine areas and put them back together the way they were. That is absolute rubbish. I admit that in some parts of Australia there have been careful plans to try to restore the landscape. One such area is the coast along southern Queensland and northern New South Wales and on the Gold Coast where there has been sand mining. It is very boring, almost monocultured country, though it has been restored. It looks nothing like the natural coastline elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness. It's marvellous.
—Senator Crichton-Browne may think it is marvellous. I do not know why he does.
—It was all scrub.

—You called the original thing scrub. That is the difference between Senator Crichton-Browne and me. He calls it scrub, but I like it because it is what nature put there. It is the natural thing that has always been there and always should be there. That delicate, fragile coastline is one of the most important parts of our society, and it must be kept. Senator Crichton-Browne sees nothing wrong with what has happened there, and I give him the benefit of the doubt. He sees nothing wrong with tearing all this to pieces and destroying it, provided that one can plant something else there afterwards.
—Even if it is better?

—What does the Senator mean by `better'? I say it is not better because it is not what was there originally. This world was created in a certain way, and it is part of our responsibility to see that at least small parts of it remain so that people in future can see those areas as they are. If they are given some sort of phoney landscape that is put back together and is completely unrecognisable from the original state, that is not the right thing to do. People who pay large sums of money to be in original, authentic wilderness will not come here unless that wilderness is preserved in its original form. There is a straight economic background to it. That is essential to us.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very unhappy about Senator Kilgariff's remarks. He keeps harking back to uranium. I was waiting for this to happen in this debate because it is the final, fatal flaw among the Opposition. Opposition members seem to think there is magic in uranium, and I have never been able to understand that attitude. In virtually all the developed countries, except for France and Belgium, the authorities are drawing back on nuclear power. There has not been a nuclear power house commissioned in the United States of America for decades, and there will not be because of the dangers and difficulties that are being experienced with it. The Chernobyl disaster has finally put the lid on the whole idea of any large development of uranium in Europe. In Belgium it is incredible to see huge street lamps along all the roads all the way to the frontiers. It is not necessary to have such a system because one can drive at night without those facilities. However, this enormous overuse, almost waste, of electric power is due to the fact that Belgium is highly endowed with nuclear power plants, and this is the only way it can use that energy. I do not think that this is a sensible attitude towards life. What would we lose if mining were permitted extensively in the park, even in stage 2? We would destroy or at least mar, if we did so, an area of unique scenic and ecological importance.

There is no way in which I can overstress to anyone listening to this debate tonight the danger and damage that could be done to an area of great importance. If one flies over the park one can see pockmarks from old uranium mines all over it. We would be destroying, or risking destroying, some of the most valuable and historic Aboriginal sites in Australia. In Kakadu are some of the original land bridges which, over the millennia, Aborigines used to enter this country. These are of enormous importance from every point of view. In the park one can also see some of the rock paintings which go back to the time of the very early occupation of this country by the Aboriginal people. When one goes to France one can see the great tourist attractions of Cro-Magnon man preserved in the Madeleine area and in the caves of Les Eyzies, but what I saw in those caves-and they are difficult enough to get into-is not comparable in beauty and extent with the Aboriginal drawings in Kakadu. These things have a value which would certainly be appreciated overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is disputing that?

—Good; I am glad that Senator Puplick, agrees with me and is not disputing that fact. Therefore he must agree that we should not meddle with this area to the extent that some of his colleagues in the Opposition are proposing.
—Like whom?

—Senator Kilgariff, for a start. He says that we should take out all the uranium that we can because it is a great thing for the future and that it will bring us lots of money. He says we will be squandering millions of dollars if we do not do it.
—Billions.

—Billions, as Senator Crichton-Browne says. I think he has proved my point. Liberal members are not really limiting exploitation of that type in the park; they are prepared to carry on with it. I think it is absolutely tragic that they should think that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly about the fragility of the whole area. This is one of the great problems of any mining in the area, and of course, it is a problem for Ranger. Enormous sections of the area are flood plains. The East Alligator River, the Magela Creek and all of its back waters are flood plains. The whole region is subject to very heavy rainfall every year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage?

—All of it. The monsoon rain does not fall discriminately, it falls everywhere. There are small creeks and watercourses everywhere. I cannot believe that one could mine this area-particularly if one was thinking of extensive underground mining and it would appear that that is likely-without causing trouble and without releasing heavy metals and some sort of contamination into the environment. That has already been shown by mining experience in that area. With the best will in the world- and I credit the Ranger partners with that-it has not been possible to contain absolutely the contamination. Heavy metal contamination from Ranger has occurred from time to time in Magela Creek and places like that.

SPEECH.PARA: Stage 2 of the park is important. Some people say that it is not-that it has been pastoral properties and that it has been abused and used. I suppose that there is a certain truth in some of that. But I would point out that two wrongs do not make a right. If one has an area that is of great intrinsic importance and it has already been messed around with, there is no excuse for messing it around extensively any more. In fact that is much more a reason for looking after it, preserving it and trying not to mess it up any more. All sorts of things go on in stage 2. According to the Australian Conservation Foundation, Kakadu National Park is the most likely place for the salt water crocodiles to develop reasonable populations. Here at this stage they are safe from man and man is safe from them. That will not be the case if there is selective mining in these areas. The first major problems with crocodiles are now developing at the East Alligator tourist area in the park. These difficulties happen from time to time and there have been several incidents involving crocodiles. However, crocodiles are a threatened world species and the Kakadu National Park populations are probably the healthiest surviving in the world. That information comes from the Bonn meeting of the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals. In this case we have surveillance of a species that we may regard as a nuisance because crocodiles may eat people, but nevertheless they are an endangered species of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Puplick may laugh. He may ask what right a crocodile has to exist. I point out that we have these species and if we can provide a habitat for them that is not disturbed and where they can continue to exist, that is something worth doing.
—Then why do you support a plan of management that allows hunting for the first time?

—There is much in the plan of management that one could criticise. In this world one must take what one can get while one can. If Senator Sanders, I and a few other people were rewriting this plan, I am sure that we could improve it greatly. Unfortunately, due to the failure of the Australian people to give the Australian Democrats enough votes in the past, we are not in a position to do so. I can assure honourable senators that that will be remedied at some stage in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the question of Aboriginal interests. There is an interesting assessment of that by the Australian Conservation Foundation. Kakadu stage 2 contains many Aboriginal sites of importance which could suffer damage from exploration and mining. We have persistent statements from members of the mining industry disparaging or in some way running down the Aborigines' view of the land. That is very serious. A lot of those people with mining interests who make these comments represent foreign interests. Let us face it: They are not Australians; they are foreigners, who want to come here and loot this land for everything they can. If our indigenous people feel very honestly that they have an important link between their own personalities and the land-a form of animism, perhaps-then what right have people who are foreign to this country to come here and tell us that that is nonsense, it is mumbo jumbo and magic and it should be destroyed? How would those people feel if I went to a cemetery in France and said that I intended to dig it up to find out whether there was any coal underneath it? They would be scandalised, and quite rightly. For the same reason, the Aborigines would not want to see one of their sacred sites disturbed.

Quite apart from sacred sites, I recognise and appreciate the view of the Aborigines towards their land. It is something of value because it is based on something that we have not been able to do-and that is to live for generations and centuries with the land and not destroy it; to keep it in its natural form; to live in balance with nature and to get away from the neo-platonic view that somehow we are the lords of creation and that it is our right to maraud and to destroy all other species and that everything is only there for our greater glory and wealth. This is nonsense, and increasingly human beings are recognising that. Perhaps we need a more enlightened form of animism in this world. We must recognise the value of other living things. If we want to do that, the best place we can start to do it is in Kakadu National Park. Perhaps you, Senator Crichton-Browne, should go there for a few weeks, have a look around and wonder at what is there. Then perhaps you should consider what you think is of value-whether your grubby little friends from Italy or France should go there and take out minerals or whether it is better for us, the members of this Parliament who represent the people of this country, not those who come from overseas to tear it apart, to recognise that it is our responsibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—Order! Senator Mason, I think you should direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I point out to Senator Crichton-Browne that our duty as a Parliament is to look after the interests of this country and not those of people who come here with persuasive arguments and expensive public relations exercises to try to convince Australians that somehow it is perfectly all right to mine national parks and that somehow we will all be better off as a result.
—Like Senator Crichton-Browne's overseas friends.

—That is right, Senator Siddons. Senator Crichton-Browne can enlighten us on that point later. I return to the view of the Australian Conservation Foundation on the impact of mining development. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of exploration alone could be serious. There are 530 exploration leases over Kakadu Stage II already from one company, Peko-EZ. The map of Stage II shows that there is an overdevelopment of tracks and roads which extend disturbance. Road access to all exploration sites would greatly exacerbate this problem. Road access increases uncontrolled shooting problems and produces further problems of intrusion on Aboriginal sites.
Actual mine development would severely diminish the World Heritage value of the entire park.

Peko-EZ already know of and predict large mineral deposits deep in Stage II. They are unlikely to construct new milling and treatment plants with their Ranger complex relatively nearby. Therefore there would be a likelihood of streams of giant ore trucks moving continuously to and from the existing Jabiru plant, sharing the road with tourists to Kakadu.
The poor tourists; it must be great fun for them. Getting back to uranium, the letter makes the point:
It is frequently argued-
I heard this mentioned during Senator Sanders's speech-

that uranium mines are relatively small if underground, however impact is very widespread. Blasts from Ranger have been heard 50 kms away, dislodging massive boulders from cliff tops. Tailings dams and light glow cause visual pollution for considerable distances. This is not to mention the real danger of radioactive accidents-both existing mines have already had problems. We believe that this is hardly a suitable scenario for a World Heritage area.

This is not a matter for those people who have self-interests, people who for some reason or other are protecting the miners; it is a matter for the people of Australia. I appeal through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the people of Australia to see that this area is not despoiled and marauded. The area is there now and it exists largely in a form which can be preserved. Do not let us muff up this one. For heaven's sake, let us see that this is preserved so that it goes on for our children and their children and grandchildren as much as possible the way it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Collard's motion for disallowance of the management plan for Kakadu National Park. I propose to devote my remarks to three issues: Firstly, the history of the proclamation of stage 2 of Kakadu National Park; secondly, some analysis of the plan of management which we are seeking to disallow; and, thirdly, the potential for multiple land usage in stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park. Before I address those issues, I want to make a couple of comments about the speeches which have preceded mine and to anticipate a couple of remarks which Senator Richardson will make following me.
—I am not that predictable.

—Senator Richardson says that he is not that predictable. Anybody who knows the history of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales knows precisely that Senator Richardson is one of the most predictable persons one could come across. I will come to that matter in a few minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: In opening this debate Senator Collard made it perfectly clear, on behalf of the Opposition, that, in terms of our commitment to the protection of the wetlands, the escarpment areas and the Aboriginal rock galleries, nothing would be done or advocated by the coalition parties that would put any of those three elements of the Kakadu National Park or Kakadu region in any jeopardy. Senator Robertson, who led the debate for the Labor Party on this occasion, made two of the most outstanding comments that one could possibly make, both of which I hope to devote some attention to this evening. The first comment was that the management plan which we are seeking to disallow is an outstanding document. It is not an outstanding document; it is a shabby, second-rate and flawed document. Secondly, he made the great claim that all of the mineral leases which were matters of debate were somehow outside the area of the Kakadu National Park. What Senator Robertson failed to tell the Senate was that they were largely areas excised from the boundaries of the park; nevertheless, they were entirely surrounded by the park.

We had a contribution from Senator Sanders on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The most important point Senator Sanders made in his contribution was that the plan was deficient. I agree with that and I will return to that point in a minute. We had an extraordinary contribution from Senator Mason, who accused the Opposition of seeking open slather on development in the park area. He quite clearly misrepresented the point of view which Senator Collard had put forward and which Senator Parer and Senator Kilgariff had supported. This extraordinary diversion is his version of what is wrong with neoplatonism as a doctrine of human behaviour.

I am to be followed in the debate this evening by Senator Richardson. Senator Richardson has been sent in here to hold up the greenies' end as part of the Hawke Government's strategy to try to rebuild that famous coalition which it thinks it can cobble back together in order to try to re-establish some sort of credibility with the environmental groups on the issues of uranium, a great deal of South West Tasmania and woodchipping. Senator Richardson has been sent in here to stick his finger in the proverbial dike in order to try to make some last ditch effort to salvage the credibility of this Government with the environmental groups. I have no hesitation in predicting that Senator Richardson will say, when he follows me, that the record of the Hawke Government in terms of the environment has been outstanding and that woodchipping and uranium were merely aberrations. One thing he will not do in the course of the debate is address you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as `mate', because we always know that that is the absolutely fatal trigger word which means that you are about to get shafted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is almost unparliamentary, Senator.

—The last thing I would want to do is be unparliamentary. Therefore, for those who do not understand the term, let me put it in far more prosaic and parliamentary terms. Whenever Senator Richardson says `mate' it means that he is about to stab you in the back. As far as that is concerned, Mr Acting Deputy President, you know precisely what Senator Richardson will have to say when he rises to his feet in a few minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: The first issue I wish to address is the way in which the proclamation of stage 2 of Kakadu National Park has been handled. In July 1984 at a meeting of the Commonwealth and State Council of Nature Conservation Ministers-CONCOM-a regime was agreed upon between the Commonwealth and States under which the Commonwealth undertook that it would not proclaim areas for the World Heritage listing without proper and adequate consultation with the State authorities. This followed the events which had taken place as a result of the Commonwealth's actions on the South West Tasmania situation. The formal agreement between the Commonwealth and States was produced as part of a document entitled `Australia and the World Heritage Convention' which was issued by the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment in February 1986. That document made it quite clear that consultation with the States would take place. Under the heading `Process for nominating Australian properties' as part of the CONCOM agreement, the Commonwealth made the following agreement:
. . . the Commonwealth Government writes to the State and Territory Governments inviting them to submit suggestions . . .

any suggestions for World Heritage listing brought forward by other than a State or Territory Government to be referred, with supporting information, to the relevant State or Territory Government for comment prior to examination by the Commonwealth.
The Commonwealth Government has indicated, however, that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing without the agreement of the State or Territory concerned.

The written document produced at CONCOM and reproduced in the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment statement of February 1986 states that there will be not just consultation but agreement. In April 1986 I pursued some investigation of this matter with Professor Ovington, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, at the hearings of Estimates Committee D. On 10 April 1986 I asked Professor Ovington about the progress of stage 2 of Kakadu. As reported at page 53 of the Hansard of the Committee's hearings of that date, Professor Ovington said:
It is my understanding that the Northern Territory Government is being approached about that proposal to attach stage 2 in that way to the World Heritage area.
Subsequently he said:
Having got that advice it is my understanding that the Government-
that is, the Federal Government-
will be approaching, or has approached, the Northern Territory Government to say it is intending to do that.
That is, to proclaim or to move forward with stage 2. No consultation was undertaken. On 8 September, Senator Gareth Evans wrote to Mr Copeman of Peko-Wallsend and he said:

It is my view, which I have again conveyed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, that it would be premature to pursue the World Heritage listing of Kakadu Stage 2 until related questions about mineral activity in the Kakadu Region have been addressed by the Commonwealth.
That is what Senator Gareth Evans said on 8 September. On 16 September, Mr Cohen wrote to Mr Coulter, the Minister for Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory, and he said:

Should the Commonwealth decide to pursue World Heritage listing of the former Stage 2 area, your Government will be consulted in accordance with the CONCOM agreement prior to any approach being made to the World Heritage Secretariat in Paris.
When the Kakadu plan of management was tabled page 23 of that document indicated:
Consideration is being given to the nomination of the former Stage 2 area subject to appropriate consultation.

On 16 September, Mr Cohen sent that letter to Mr Coulter. On precisely the same day, 16 September, Mr Cohen and Senator Evans were party to putting out a statement in their joint names which said that they were going to pursue the listing of Stage 2 on the World Heritage List and that no further consideration of consultation with the Northern Territory was going to be undertaken or was required. On the day, 16 September, that Mr Cohen wrote to Mr Coulter promising consultation, he issued a statement in conjunction with Senator Evans who had previously written, no more than eight days before, indicating that there would be consultation, denying that any consultation would take place.

On the following day, 17 September, a document was sent to Paris as part of the nomination papers for stage 2 of the World Heritage listing. It is a lengthy document. It must have been in Mr Cohen's possession, or at least known to Mr Cohen, well in advance of his having signed the letter of 16 September to Mr Coulter telling him that there would be consultation. Mr Acting Deputy President, I say to you that it is perfectly clear that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment deliberately, wilfully and maliciously misled the Northern Territory Government over this matter. That is one of the criticisms that we clearly raise over the way in which the Government has proceeded in this matter.

I turn now to the specifics of the plan which we are seeking to disallow. I draw attention to at least six substantial deficiencies in the document entitled `Kakadu National Park Plan of Management'. The first of these is over the question of hunting. Senator Mason was in the Senate waxing eloquent tonight about the question of the protection of animals in Kakadu National Park, but this document for the first time provides a substantial regime for the carriage of firearms and for hunting to take place within the Kakadu National Park. I quote from page 63 of that document which states:
In the previous Plan, except for the purposes of traditional hunting for authorised scientific purposes or for Park management, hunting was not permitted.
Under this plan hunting is permitted. Under the heading `Objectives' the document states:
The prime objective is to ensure public safety and amenity within the Park whilst permitting legitimate use of firearms and allowing appropriate hunting, fishing and gathering by Aboriginals.

If one looks at the issue which Senator Mason specifically raised about the protection of estuarine and salt water crocodiles in the Kakadu National Park, one sees that it is quite clear that there is a degree of hysteria about the position of crocodiles as far as the northern areas of Australia are concerned. Earlier this month we saw in the Australian Financial Review discussions about the development of a process of export of crocodile skins from the Northern Territory. On 27 September this year, there was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald under the heading `Knives are out for a croc slaughter'. One sees in the journal Social Alternatives for September 1986 the question about the status of and the danger being posed to crocodile populations in northern Australia. As Senator Mason has indicated, they are deserving of protection. Crocodile species should not be wiped out willy-nilly in northern Australia and, in particular, in the Kakadu National Park. Yet this is a plan of management which, for the first time, allows large scale hunting to take place within the confines of the Kakadu National Park.

As far as the park is concerned one takes secondly the issue of tourism. It is quite clear that the restrictions which are to be imposed on tourists in the Kakadu National Park are entirely inadequate. There is an attempt in the plan to indicate that all sorts of facilities will be provided for the tourists, including the right to take photographs. I suppose that one is to be grateful to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for having developed a program which allows Australians to take photographs in a part of their own country. We know when we look at the Uluru National Park plan of management that, although that was supposed to take place-we can see the details of that appearing on page 123 of that management plan-there are now substantial areas of that national park where one cannot take photographs because the park service has conspired with various groups and interests around the place to prevent ordinary Australians from taking photographs in a part of their own country. At pages 134 and 135 of the plan of management, which we are seeking to overturn this evening, we now have this regime trying to provide some feeble protection for that. If we look at the Northern Territory Government's comments on the plan of management in respect of the Kakadu National Park we see that it states:

A fixed Plan of Management is not the ideal tool for managing the development of something as complex as the tourist industry over a period as long as five years. It is not possible to plan in detail for a rapidly expanding activity over this period of time. The draft Plan, however, is not even precise on the broad strategy for development. It is a vague and generalised collection of intentions almost devoid of specific commitments.

That is exactly what has happened in terms of the draft plan, going over into the final plan. One would be hard pressed to find as feeble a plan of management of tourist facilities in a national park as this document provides. I come now to the question of the protection of Aboriginal sites. Sacred sites allegedly are to be protected. This afternoon Senator Collard made a commitment that Aboriginal rock painting galleries would be adequately protected. But we have in this plan three or four pages of the most feeble attempts to define what will be protected in terms of Aboriginal sites. Let us just see what the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority has had to say about all this. The moment Coronation Hill popped up as a significant mineral deposit-perhaps one of the greatest gold deposits in the world-all of a sudden the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority found that Bulla was an Aboriginal site of some significance. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will not be surprised to know that it was sitting right on top of Coronation Hill. What happened, of course, was that Joe Fisher, a distinguished mineral and mining engineer and amateur anthropologist, a person who knows this area more intimately than almost anybody else and a person who was largely responsible for getting the Kakadu National Park put on to the World Heritage listing in the first place, came along and said: `I have got documentary evidence. I have got photographs. I know where this Bulla site is. In fact, it is 26 kilometres away from Coronation Hill'. There is plenty of evidence to demonstrate that that is the case, and this plan of management is deficient in exactly that sort of fashion. Let us turn to another area-the management of fire in the National Park. What is the objective set out in the National Park management document? It is:
The general aim of fire management is to re-establish so far as possible the traditional Aboriginal patterns of burning.

That is absolute nonsense in terms of dealing with a park which no longer can possibly respond to traditional Aboriginal patterns of anything, let alone traditional Aboriginal patterns of burning. Yet here is, allegedly, the statement in the plan of management that that is the way in which fire management, one of the most significant tasks that a national park authority has to undertake, is to be sent back to conform in some fashion with traditional Aboriginal patterns of burning. That is an absolute nonsense as far as national park management objectives are concerned. Nobody in his right mind would be prepared to put that down and accept that as part of a legitimate national park objective.

We come finally to the question of mining which I regard as one of the lesser issues in this debate. I am concerned about the general environmental validity of this plan. I do not give overwhelming preponderance to consideration of the question of mining, but page 122 of the plan states:
The main objective is to protect the Park's resources from exploitation.

Frankly, that is not correct. Tourists exploit national parks. We make national parks in order to allow tourists some form of exploitation of them. Animals and people who use national parks exploit them. They are not there to be protected from exploitation; they are there to be conserved within the limits of legitimate exploitation. This plan goes on to say:
Subject to Section 8b of the Act, no operations for the recovery of minerals will be carried out in the Park.

If one looks at the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 one will see clearly imposed upon the Director the responsibility, in drawing up a plan of management, to take into account the legitimate rights of miners. Section 8b (1) (a) (i) refers to the provisions of a plan of management which should not affect any interest in respect of that land or in respect of any minerals on, in or beneath that land held immediately before that land was within the park.

So the pre-existing mineral leases, of which there are a substantial number, ought to be provided for in terms of section 8b of the Act within the plan of management. The plan of management cannot override the Act which requires that it do certain things, yet here is a plan of management deliberately setting out to override the provisions of the Act which causes it to come into being in the first place. If one compares this with the regime which was established in the first plan of management, a far more significant, sensitive and intelligent document, one can see precisely how mining was properly provided for. I have shown this extract to Senator Grimes. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the section under the heading `Mining' which is taken from the first plan of management for Kakadu National Park.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
56. Mining

Operations for the recovery of minerals may be carried on in the Park during the period of this Plan where these have been approved by the Governor-General as required under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. Where the Governor-General gives his approval for such operations to be carried on the following conditions will apply:
Operations for the recovery of minerals may be carried on only in accordance with best practicable technology;
Suitably qualified and experienced officers are to be appointed to ensure effective environmental control including the protection of the natural and cultural resources of the Park;

All persons employed in connection with each operation shall be instructed in and informed of the provisions of this Plan of Management, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, and other applicable laws relating to the preservation of the environment and the protection of people from the effects of mining;
No plants or animals exotic to the Alligator Rivers Region shall be introduced without the written permission of the Director;

Any release of contaminants into the natural water systems of the Park shall be controlled under specifications approved by the Director acting on the best advice available including that of the appropriate supervising authorities;
Erosion products resulting from the operations shall, to the maximum extent practicable, be prevented from entering the natural water systems of the Park;
Good engineering practice shall be used in designing and constructing all structures connected with the operations;

The disposal methods and placement of waste products including tailings and waste rock shall be as approved by the Director acting on the best advice available including that of the appropriate supervising authorities;

All sites where ground has been disturbed shall be rehabilitated and revegetated to standards approved by the Director acting on the best advice available including that of the appropriate supervising authorities;
All practicable steps will be taken to protect vegetation and keep disturbance from trampling, cutting, picking, unplanned and uncontrolled burning and other causes to a minimum;

Monitoring programs, approved by the Director acting on the best advice available including that of the appropriate supervising authorities, covering all aspects of each operation shall be carried out during all phases of the operations;
Any buildings required in connection with operations for the recovery of minerals are to be designed and located so as to be in sympathy with the Park environment.
In the light of information that becomes available during the period of this Plan the Director may impose additional conditions in the interest of protecting Park values.
The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 requires, inter alia, that a mining interest in respect of Aboriginal land shall not be granted unless:
(a) both the Minister and the Land Council for the area in which the land is situated have consented, in writing, to the making of the grant; or
(b) the Governor-General has, by Proclamation, declared that the national interest requires that the grant be made.

Prospecting and exploration may require access to the Park for persons, equipment and supplies. Procedures may include, geological mapping, geochemical surveys, including shallow auger drilling, geophysical surveys, trenching, percussion and diamond drilling and the establishment of exploration camps with associated services in some areas of the Park.

Mining activities may include (a) either underground or open-cut operations or both, the access of persons, equipment and supplies and the construction of mining, ore treatment and associated facilities; (b) the provision of tailings dams and other facilities for storage of waste products and the storage of mine and process water; and (c) activities necessary or incidental to the production, handling, transportation, storage and treatment of ore.

It may be necessary for some excavation to be carried out in the Park for obtaining materials required for road construction and maintenance, construction and maintenance of the improvements and facilities listed in figures 46.1 and 54.1 and for other construction and/or maintenance for park operations approved by the Director.

Where such excavations are carried out disturbance of the soil and vegetation will be kept to the minimum feasible and appropriate rehabilitation measures will be taken including the use of species native to the region. In general the environmental standards applied will be comparable to those at Jabiru but additional conditions may be imposed in the interests of Park protection.

During 1979, literature about Kakadu National Park was supplied to the mining companies in the region for distribution to their staff. In addition, an orientation course for senior mining staff was held and proved to be an effective means of informing them of Park values and the problems of Park management to protect those values. There was general agreement that orientation courses of this type are useful and should be held each year and be available to larger numbers of senior mining staff. It is planned to hold at least one orientation course for mining staff in each year of this Plan.

The general provision of information about the Park and co-operation with the mining companies through periodic discussions, courses and seminars will continue. During the period of this Plan this liaison will provide a means to plan the infrastructure having regard to its possible use for park needs. Similarly this would assist rehabilitation measures once mining ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This makes it perfectly clear that it is possible to establish a plan of management for the Kakadu National Park which has proper regard to the objectives of the Act and which allows mining in controlled and proper circumstances. I turn finally to the question of multiple land usage in the park. In an address given to the South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy in September this year, Mr Payne, the Minister of Mines and Energy in South Australia-an excellent State Labor Minister-makes the point that it is possible for all the interests to be properly accommodated. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Recent initiatives in South Australia have shown that subsurface, surface and conservation interests can be accommodated through communication and consultation.

He goes on to describe the South Australian Government's policy by saying that a package has been designed to foster multiple land use concepts. That is the very point which, some time ago, Senator Evans was intent on making. On 18 September 1986 Senator Evans said to the Senate Estimates Committee in regard to this area:

. . . subject to appropriate protection there ought to be no intrinsic rational reason why a multiple land use regime should not be established for national parks, which already accommodate a variety of different land uses anyway . . .

One can even see from the documents of the Australian Conservation Foundation that it makes it quite clear that it understands the value of multiple land usage, even though it does reproduce with some disparity Senator Evans's description of stage 3 as `clapped-out buffalo country' which indeed is exactly what it is. Even the Conservation Foundation, Senator Evans and Mr Payne, the South Australian Labor Minister, know that multiple land usage is a viable way of exploiting the resources of a national park and, at the same time, preserving the important intrinsic features of a national park. Will Senator Richardson, who will follow me, and Senator Zakharov, who will speak later, denounce Senator Evans for his failure to understand what multiple land usage amounts to? Will they denounce Mr Payne, their South Australian Labor colleague, for being ignorant about what multiple land usage in these areas can be?

We know that even if the mining companies had entirely their own way in relation to the areas that they are seeking to exploit at the moment, less than one per cent of the entire region would be involved. Multiple land usage in which one per cent of the region is actually affected by these things seems to me to be an absolutely rational approach to making maximum use of our own national resources and, at the same time, preserving the inherent and intrinsic values of those parts of the Kakadu National Park that we want to preserve. We know that it is not just a matter of uranium.

I appreciate Senator Mason's particular hang- ups about uranium. I understand the strain and stress that Senator Mason is under now; he is thinking about whether he should have announced his decision to retire, seeing the wrong candidate has been preselected for the Australian Democrats in New South Wales, or whether he ought to resign early in order to allow some young person to get in and head off Mrs Kirkby at the pass before she gets in here and tells the Senate what she at least thinks of Don Chipp as the Leader of the Australian Democrats. I understand the psychological pressure that Senator Mason is under this evening, but he should not seek to try to take it out entirely on the poor old uranium miners. They are not responsible for the state of decay, radioactive or otherwise, that the Australian Democrats have got themselves into.

We know that the resources of the national park include not only uranium but also enormous deposits of gold, platinum, tin and tungsten, and we know full well that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has absolutely no idea of what those resources are. In the Senate Estimates Committee hearing of 7 October 1986 I was pressing Dr McCusker of the Service about the resources of the national park. She said:

There has not been a mineral survey to identify the total resources of the area that would complete the work that could be done, for example, by the Bureau of Mineral Resources or other bodies. Some information is available but I understand it is believed that more survey work should be done.

Of course more survey work should be done. Here are the Australian Labor Party and the Government trying to lock the cupboard without knowing what its contents are. Nobody knows; there is no evidence on record of the resources of stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park. Yet that is to be closed down under this plan of management which says there will be no mineral exploration and no mining activity, despite the clear requirements of section 8 of the Act that a plan of management provides for some method of dealing with mineral resources in the park.

I conclude by drawing the attention of the Senate again to three points. This stage 2 proclamation has taken place by the most underhanded, backroom series of deals involving the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and the Minister for Resources and Energy who have consistently misled the Northern Territory Government as to the way in which they would proceed. The plan of management is flawed in terms of its protection of the wildlife, its hunting arrangements, its tourist arrangements, its sacred site arrangements, its fire management arrangements and its mining arrangements-which it should have made under section 8 of the Act, by which it is bound-and it has failed to understand the principles of multiple land usage, which ought to be absolutely critical to the development of management plans in national parks if there is to be the broad-based consensus over support for national parks and the development of national parks which this country desperately needs, and in Kakadu in more ways than one. As a result, Senator Collard's motion for the disallowance of this plan of management ought to be supported by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my earnest hope that all those around this country interested in the cause of conservation and the preservation of our environment are listening to this debate, because nothing could make it more clear. There could be no more stark contrast between the two major parties. Lately I often hear people saying that the two parties have got policies that are too close together. Let me say that on the issue of the environment, and on Kakadu and the banning of mining in stages 1 and 2, our policies are miles apart. The gulf is wide and getting wider, because the battle for Kakadu represents in this country the great environmental battle of the next few years. Just as the Hawke Government took on the Liberal Party of Australia in 1983 and made sure that we won the battle over the Franklin River and that the south-west of Tasmania was not destroyed for no purpose at all, we will win this one too. I hope that all those who are listening understand that, if they have any concern for conservation and any concern for the great parts of our environment around this country, they have got to stick with the Australian Labor Party because we are the only party that can possibly deliver any saving grace for them.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot has been spoken about Kakadu in ignorance tonight, mostly by people who have never been there and will never go there. There is no Hilton Hotel in Kakadu, which makes it a bit hard for Senator Puplick. But those of us, working class lads, who struggled through it recently got to see a great deal. We liked it so much we are going back next week. It would have been nice if those on the other side could have been a little bit more patient and waited until the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, of which I am a member and Senator Zakharov is Chairman, was able to report and give its recommendations on mining in Kakadu. But here we are tonight debating the matter too early and, obviously, when too many members of the Opposition have not had time to find out what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Steady.

—Senator Crichton-Browne is the leader of that push. If we give him a lifetime, he will not find out what is going on. I will try to explain something about Kakadu. We have heard Senator Gareth Evans's rather colourful phrase tonight-`clapped out buffalo country'. I have got to concede, just for a start, that there is a lot of that in Kakadu. But I must also say that the area involved in Kakadu is massive-over 6,000 square kilometres in each of stage 1 and stage 2, before we get to stage 3, about which we are now having the argument. When we look at that massive area, we have to acknowledge that right along the escarpment and in the areas adjacent to it, we have some of the most beautiful country in Australia, magnificent country with phenomenal wetlands--
—About 100 acres of it.

—For Senator Lewis's information-which is deficient again-it goes for miles and miles. I will have to get him up there to have a look. It is great country. It is worth preserving, and that is what we will do. If honourable senators want to look at our most recent advertisement for Kakadu, we have got Crocodile Dundee. I hope they have all seen that film. One of the spots that are shown in Crocodile Dundee is UDP Falls. That name comes from the uranium development project from the 1950s. It is not exactly the sort of name one would normally choose for a magnificent spot, a spot of absolutely phenomenal beauty. The thing about UDP Falls in Crocodile Dundee is that if one looks at that magnificent scene, the fantastic waterfall, the crystal clear water and Linda Kozlowski's swimsuit-all of that-it is magnificent. When we look at that, we learn that that is one spot among dozens along that escarpment of magnificent falls areas that we have to save. The sad thing for the mining lobby and for its spokesmen in the Parliament is that so many of the prospective areas are right along the escarpment. If we give it carte blanche, we will find many of those magnificent falls and waterways will be destroyed. We cannot allow that. Let us just go through what the real argument is for the conservationists. It is all about water quality and the flow of the South Alligator.
—The falls are not in the park.

—I want Senator Townley to take a few deep breaths. I am worried about him. Let us look at the problem of the South Alligator River and its headwaters. As the catchment area spreads obviously much wider than just that small strip, if we allow untrammelled mining, as Opposition senators would have us do, through that area--
—Now you have opened your mouth.

—The rhetoric may be glib, but the reality is simple. Opposition senators will let anyone with a shovel have a go; we will not. If honourable senators look at the size of the catchment area and if they have a look at the effects of mining, they have to understand that there has to be some sort of compromise. It is not just the spot where one can say: `All in' or `All out'. So the Hawke Government, in its wisdom and to its everlasting credit, said no to mining in stage 1 and stage 2. Already in that area we have got--
—It is in stage 1 or stage 2, isn't it?

—Just a minute. Take it easy. Senator Puplick did not know that. He should not display too much ignorance; we have all seen enough tonight. We got 30 minutes of it. Let us not see much more. If honourable senators examine the difficulty that we have, they will see that the allowance of mining all over that park through stage 1 and stage 2, let alone into stage 3, means the destruction of so many of those areas. When Ranger is already operating-a big mine, employing--
—It is not a really big one.

—It is not as big as the honourable senator would have it, but I would say it is pretty big. It is well known in my Party-I must say, not to the pleasure of all-that I am a supporter of uranium mining. I do not resile from that point of view. I have no desire whatsoever to close down Ranger-none. But I have to say that to allow mines to operate in stage 3 will mean that those wetlands cannot be protected. The one factor that Senator Puplick fails to mention--
—Where is all the uranium?
—There is uranium in stage 3. We have got to concede that.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you are interjecting far too much.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Let us look at stage 3. We have got to an argument now about gold and about platinum. They are the two minerals in the world that are performing well. These days digging up anything else is hardly worth our while, but gold and platinum prices continue to go through the roof. I, unlike Senator Puplick, had the opportunity only in May of standing atop Coronation Hill, of looking all around it.
—Is that where Max Gillies saw you?

—I do not know where Max Gillies saw me, as a matter of fact; I am trying to work that out. I have had a low profile. I cannot work out how he ever heard of me. Let me get back to Coronation Hill. I thought Senator Puplick misled the Senate rather grievously, because in referring to the Bulla site, as he did, he attempted to have us believe that the Aboriginals were simply wrong about it being there, that it was in a place 26 miles away. The reality is that in the whole region there are Bulla sites all over the place. There is not one, there are not two; there are many of them. However, what convinced me at the time I was sitting atop Coronation Hill that it ought to be mined was the fact that the legend or religion of the local people has it that once the site is disturbed bulla leaves. Sitting atop Coronation Hill I realised that there are already two open cut holes in the side of the mountain and an adit going right through it; so I figured he might have left already. So I could not argue with Coronation Hill being mined. The region-it is not all that big, although we are talking about a big prospective area-covers a strip about 50 kilometres long and 10 kilometres wide. That is where we are told the big stuff is, where the hundreds of millions-or billions, depending upon whom one wishes to believe-of dollars worth of resources are all tucked away. The sad thing is that it goes right along the escarpment and right along the waterways. The conservationists have a legitimate problem.
—That is not an escarpment, it is a hill. Do you know the difference between an escarpment and a hill?

—I ask the honourable senator to take more than a deep breath. He sounds more stupid by the moment. When looking at that area and trying to assess its value and how we as a government can protect it, I think the biggest worry in relation to the decisions we are now making is that gold processing inevitably will involve the use of large amounts of cyanide. Gold cannot be processed without cyanide and it does not take a little bit of cyanide, it takes a lot. While it might be easy to say that tailings dams and everything can successfully keep pollution intact and that the environmentalists do not need to worry, the fact is that there would be a great need for worry if cyanide were ever to leak into those waterways at all. One of the things I would like the Committee that some of us in the chamber at the moment sit on to find out is just what the mining lobby has to say about that. I would like to know where the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd intends to process its gold before I agree to anything.

SPEECH.PARA: We still need to go through many big arguments. We want to make sure that right through that strip in stage 3 of which I have just spoken not only are the most obvious precautions taken in regard to the environment with initial mining but also we take a good look at processing. I would like to find out in this debate what anyone on the other side thinks of it, because all they can do is salivate at the prospect of getting the bulldozers in. There is no thought whatsoever for the heritage value of Kakadu. Fortunately this Government, in looking at areas the geology of which goes back several million years, will do something about it. On 16 September 1986 we had a joint statement from the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Barry Cohen. I take it it is that statement that has led us to this debate tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gave you epilepsy.
—I did not hear that interjection. I am probably glad I did not.
