—It gave me a what? I am sorry, I find this coarse language in the Senate very difficult to understand. This statement endorsed a revised plan of management for the park. We heard Senator Puplick refer to the plan many times during his contribution. He failed to mention, however, its purpose. Its purpose is to show all Australia that we are prepared to take the lead in protecting one of the great heritage areas of our nation, that we were not worried about the gibes of the Opposition and the complaints of the mining lobby.
—The left wing is screwing your tail.

—I have not heard Senator Evans and Mr Cohen referred to as the left wing, nor do I consider myself the Party's leading lefty. However, one does not need to be a leading lefty to support the cause of the environment. That is what I hope I am doing tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources were taken through a number of sites. We were shown where there were some gold prospects and where there were some platinum prospects and I have no doubt that in the area in which this plan allows mining there are a number of very prospective sites. There are a number of places where hundreds of millions of dollars could be earned relatively easily. That is why the Australian Labor Party chose to make the compromise-not to say no mining anywhere, ever, but to say that in the most important areas of stage 1 and stage 2 we draw a line and say there will be no more; and in relation to stage 3 we say that there can be some mining subject of course to some strict conditions, as well it should be. We are told by the mining industry that it does not mind and is happy with strict environmental conditions so I cannot understand why it is so upset, or even why Senator Crichton-Browne is upset.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not upset. I feel sorry for your getting done.

—From what I heard about the Western Australian Liberal Party elections, I think the honourable senator suffered a greater defeat than I did. Senator Chaney was the winner, was he not? The problem that we now have to address is the importance of assessing just how great the mineral resources are and just how many claims there can be.
—The plan does not allow for that.

—I again ask the honourable senator to take a deep breath. Over the next few weeks and months the Government has to give further consideration to that. Environmentalists and the mining industry itself have to be consulted, and over time the Party will make its decision. The Government will be able to tell us the exact, final position in regard to stage 3. But what we have already been told in regard to stage 1 and stage 2 is what the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Wilderness Society and all the hundreds of environmental groups around the country have been campaigning for for years. We have once again delivered the goods. That reminds me that I was attacked viciously by Senator Puplick earlier, and he referred to woodchipping in Tasmania. The Government has a committee examining what will happen with logging in heritage areas in Tasmania, and if genuine heritage areas are to be invaded by the bulldozers I have no doubt that Government will take action and cancel woodchipping licences. We will not put up with heritage values being destroyed by anybody. I hope Senator Townley gives Robin Gray the message.
—This is the greatest appeal to the pinkos since Barry Unsworth appealed to public opinion.

—That was highly intelligent. I can understand now what happened in Western Australia. I refer now to what the coalition has done on Kakadu in recent times. According to the general cross-sectional view, not only are we going to have an argument about what we can do in stage 3 but also we would be opening the door to stages 1 and 2 if that lot over there got their way. In the end we have to wonder why this debate is on and what it is all about. The Opposition knows it cannot get its motion through the Senate; so to whom is it appealing? Would it always be the case that the mining companies completely and absolutely pull the strings? When will those opposite just once have the courage to say no? We over here have stopped waiting with bated breath; we have stopped hanging by the neck. We have not given up. It is obvious that the mining lobby controls the Liberal Party and the National Party completely and utterly. It gets whatever it wants from them.
—Doesn't it control the Labor Party as well?

—We are the ones who have taken up the cudgels. We have done something about it. We are proud of our record. What Mr Hawke has done is to protect the environment. He has done what the great majority of Australians who elected him wanted him to do-to make sure that this great country stays great.
—What did Evans write to Copeman on?

—I would have thought that the mention of Copeman in respect of mining would have been difficult even for Senator Alston. The decision of Peko-Wallsend Ltd a couple of weeks ago to start exploration again in stage 2 is a disgraceful decision. It is, of course, meaningless and provocative because it gets nowhere. It will go round in a circle before it gets knocked off in the courts. It is another example of extremists running the Liberal Party of Australia. I would have thought that that would worry him because he has a lot more to fear from Andrew Hay than I have.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition, in saying that it would overturn the management plan, does not stop there. If we look at David Connolly's statement on Aboriginal affairs in recent times, we see that he has actually held a different view. In a couple of interviews he has been able to contradict himself but it seems to me that he is saying that he will not allow any mining in Aboriginal areas in stage 3. That is certainly not the view put here tonight by Senator Kilgariff, and I take it that it is not the view of the Liberal Party as a whole. There are many sacred sites; there are not just one or two; they are scattered all over the place. If one goes to those sacred sites one can look at some of the superb rock art and the other sites that are there. One very quickly gets the idea that for those people living there the land is all. Obviously, in any compromise the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory must lose out a bit and they do when it comes to allowing any prospectivity in the stage 3 areas.

But the facts are that, if we were to tear up the plan for stage 1, stage 2 and stage 3, a great many Aboriginal people in Kakadu would be robbed of their heritage. For them, it is not just a matter of the environment; it is not just a matter of nice waterways and all the rest of it. For them it is their whole life-their culture, their history and their future. The Australian Labor Party and this Government are not prepared to throw that away.

Once again, we see in this debate the contrast not just in style but in content between the Liberal Party and ourselves. If we look at the future of Kakadu, we should not concentrate solely on mining. The argument is not just about mining; it has to be about tourism also. Where I start to differ from Senator Mason in his contribution is that I have no doubt that tourism has a very great role to play in the future of Kakadu-in stages 1, 2 and 3, but in particular in stages 1 and 2 where so many tourists have flocked in recent years. We have to have some sort of balance. I say to Senator Townley, who has been interjecting, that balance is not something for which he is famed. TALK.START.PARA: —Make up your mind.

—There are some exceptions. Senator Alston replaced a hard Right senator, and he is one. One sees Senator Walters, Senator Watson, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Townley-there are plenty of them. There is also-I will not say who, Mr Acting Deputy President. The hard Right is over there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak briefly on road safety. I believe, naturally, that road safety in Australia is a matter of great concern. I take note, too, of the road safety leaflet that has been prepared on the cost of road crashes. No doubt many honourable senators here tonight have perused that very illuminating paper on road safety. But I wish to speak very briefly tonight on one aspect of road safety-radar detectors. Honourable senators and other people who do a lot of air travel would have noted quite a lot of advertising material relating to the availability of radar detectors. As I have said, I believe that road safety is a matter of great concern; it is a community responsibility. At the moment we are endeavouring to educate road users in the best ways of safe conduct on the roads. One such way is to obey the law. Laws exist, of course, to assist in road safety. The purpose of road safety is to cut down on road carnage.

SPEECH.PARA: If our roads were as safe as our skies we would have little to worry about. As I have said, I, like most honourable senators, spend a great deal of time flying. It is very comforting for parliamentarians and the people of Australia to know that Australia's domestic aviation record leads the world. It comes as an irony to find that our three major domestic carriers were recently, and perhaps still are, advertising car radar detectors in their in-flight magazines. I refer to Ansett Airlines of Australia, East-West Airlines Ltd and Trans Australia Airlines, which has been newly named Australian Airlines. It is very interesting to note that in-flight magazines contain full page glossy coloured advertisements aimed at car enthusiasts. They present the opportunity to buy radar detectors.

Radar detectors, of course, exist to assist car users to break the law. One could really say that the airlines, which are proud of their air safety, are assisting the carnage on the roads through promoting the sale of radar detectors which, as I said, exist to circumvent police. In reality, they are aimed at those who want to break the law and avoid the penalty. A portable model of radar detector is now available. Honourable senators will realise what I am talking about: The radar detector is an instrument which is fitted to a car and picks up the police radar ahead and, by a signal within the car, it indicates to the driver that he should slow down and drive within speed limits.

There is a portable model of radar detector for the busy executive traveller. When he travels interstate he can put the device, if not in his own car, in a hire car. I suppose that many honourable senators have noticed, as I have, the advertisements in in-flight magazines. The magazines are entertaining and informative and provide a diversion on flights to and from Canberra. I believe in-flight magazines have been marred by the inclusion of such an advertisement. I took it upon myself to write to the chairmen of the three domestic airline companies-Ansett Airlines of Australia, East-West Airlines Ltd and Australian Airlines-to express my concern at the advertisements being placed in the magazines. I pointed out that the speed laws are there to make the roads safer for all motorists. As I said before, the irony is that the airlines-with their excellent safety records-by having such advertisements in their magazines, are actually encouraging people to break the law on the ground in their vehicles. So I urged that the airlines reconsider placing such advertisements in their in-flight magazines in the future. To the very great credit of the airlines involved all three have replied that they would not place the advertisements in the magazines in the future. They said that apparently the advertisements were placed by the advertising departments of the companies involved and were accepted on a commercial basis. TALK.START.PARA: —I sincerely thank the gentlemen concerned for having taken the decision not to carry the advertisements. The road toll in Australia is horrendous and I believe that everyone must do all possible to reduce it. These airlines have acknowledged their moral and ethical responsibilities and have given a lead to others. I note recent stories that the New South Wales Government plans to outlaw radar detectors and I hope that the other States of Australia will do so too. It is a commendable move which should be followed by legislatures in other States. It is estimated that some 50,000 car drivers now use these detectors in one State alone-New South Wales. As I have indicated, these detectors are to enable people to go around the law. What they are actually doing of course is assisting in the carnage on the roads. How can the use of these detectors by 50,000 car drivers in New South Wales be justified when one considers the causing of deaths and injury and the cost involved with public hospitals, police surveillance, police action, et cetera? Indeed, the Department of Transport's figures show that road crashes, fatalities and the carnage on the roads now cost the Australian community an estimated $3 billion a year. In a typical road crash people are killed or injured, vehicles are damaged or destroyed and roadside equipment or buildings may also be damaged or destroyed. Restoring people to good health or looking after them for the rest of their lives, as well as repairing damaged property, all costs the public a good deal of money.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety produced a report concluding that speed was ranked third as the most important factor in road crashes. It found that while speed of itself is not the cause of crashes, the higher the speed of the vehicle the greater is the potential for serious injury or death from any mishap; if speed could be reduced there would be fewer and less serious crashes. That was the view of that Committee. Speed limits are there for all of us who use the roads-again this was the Committee's view-and the police use radars to detect those who are prepared to endanger their own lives and the lives of others. The report went on to point out that we should not sanction the use of radar detectors, which are used to avoid the penalties of speeding. It is incredible that a firm can assist in causing carnage on the roads, often resulting in deaths, and that that firm with impunity can advertise in magazines and sell this death-dealing equipment. Again, I congratulate the three airlines on giving a lead to the rest of the community in taking the decision not to promote radar detectors in their in-flight publications and thus to assist in reducing the amount of carnage on our roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this adjournment debate I wish to deal with what in an industrial relations sense is the flavour of the month. In an earlier debate on a matter of urgency Senator Chaney made clear that in the last 12 months the Opposition parties had discovered work practices. Through the actions of a whole range of companies, most notably Peko-Wallsend Ltd, the issue of work practices has grabbed the headlines in practically every media outlet. It is a matter to which I want to draw attention, and perhaps at a later stage I shall look at the matter from a different perspective when dealing with what the most notorious company in this country is doing in the area of work practices in the work-place.

SPEECH.PARA: It was strange to hear Senator Chaney speak of work practices having been discovered by the Opposition just over a year ago. I would remind the Senate that work practices have been with us ever since man has worked for a living. What have evolved from the system are restrictive work practices. On a future occasion I shall have something to say on that topic and how it applies within the Peko-Wallsend empire. It is worth remembering what happened at one of the subsidiaries of Peko-Wallsend Ltd in Sydney on Friday when 500 workers were tossed on to the scrap-heap. However, the company I want to talk about tonight is not Peko-Wallsend, but another large corporation within Australia, Lend Lease Corporation Ltd.

On reading the Business Review Weekly magazine of 17 October this year, I found a very interesting article entitled `Why work practices are not all bad'. The article refers to a study which Lend Lease, through its subsidiary company Civil and Civic Pty Ltd, had commissioned from Dr Vernon Ireland, head of the School of Business Studies of the New South Wales Institute of Technology. The study found that Civil and Civic is a far more efficient builder than 10 of America's biggest construction companies-companies, incidentally, in the United States which live under a largely deregulated union scene. The study documents that, in the Australian context of a highly regulated society, Civil and Civic can perform as well or better than its peer group in the United States in a deregulated environment. Stuart Hornery, described in the article as the hard-nosed Managing Director of Lend Lease, is reported in the article as having said:

In our opinion there is no advantage in deregulation. It is better to have creative management. The quality of life of employees in Australia is better than in the US in a very tough industry-and we're competitive.

The article continues to point out that less regulation has a cost, and it is a cost that is not always shouldered by the builder. For example, it found that in the United States, American builders could use footpaths and streets as part of a building site, to the cost of the local council and the local community, and at enormous inconvenience to the public. I again quote from the article:

Partly because of the higher building and safety standards, which are among the highest in the world, and tougher work practices negotiated by unions, Australian builders have been forced to be more innovative and better managers.
That was said by Mr Ireland, the author of the study. Mr Hornery, the Managing Director of Lend Lease, is quoted as saying:

Australia . . . enjoys a `good compromise'. If we deregulated, we might reduce our time of completion from 84 per cent (of the time American builders take on comparable projects as the study showed) to 72 per cent, but at what cost? On a comparable project in America, six people would have been killed against none here.
I couldn't sleep at night knowing we were working in some of the sorts of conditions Americans accept and which are patently dangerous.

There's got to be some price on human life. It is gratifying that we can be compassionate and care about people enough to put up safety nets and use safe work practices and still be considerably more efficient than those who don't care or try to cut corners.
I will continue to quote from the very impressive article, which I commend to every senator and member. Hornery states:

We recognise Civil and Civic is not the norm of Australian builders. We are much more consultative with unions, much more innovative in employee management and building design. And we're also involved in the building process much earlier than most builders.

For instance, we introduced superannuation for all employees in 1972, which puts us 15 years ahead of most of the rest of the industry. The new flavour of the month is employee ownership, which we've practised for a long time, and employees now own 27 per cent of Lend Lease.
The net result is that our guys are enthusiastic, which flows into better working practice. Our clients know we get jobs done on time and to quality.

``While we have tended to lead in many of these practices, much of the building industry here is as conservative as the Americans. It has required legislative and union pressure to introduce some standards.

``Our peer group asks how we can give away profit-sharing to employees, We've shown it works to co-operate. We're a blue-chip stock here and now this report shows we're competitive with America's best.

``The adversarial relationship between labor and capital is a myth as far as we are concerned. Outside government, Civil and Civic is probably Australia's biggest employer of operatives (carpenters and labourers), yet we have about the least disputation. We don't have personnel departments here because people management is part of every manager's job-all the way up from short pants.
``One of the reasons we build so quickly is that, aside from good planning, our investment in safety and employee relations pays off in reduced downtime.

``The Americans' lack of regard for employees and safety could be termed exploitation of labor. And as this report shows, it does not pay. The extent of unionisation in the US is about half here. But union employees tend to be of higher quality and more productive than the non-unionised. That's a generalisation, but Americans have not been able to introduce some of the more innovative building techniques, we believe, because their labor does not have the skills,'' Hornery says.
The study compares 22 US and Civil and Civic office and hotel projects.

The lesson in this very useful article is the comparison it makes between what is happening in Lend Lease or Civil and Civic and what is happening within the Peko Wallsend empire, particularly at Robe River in the Pilbara. At Robe River, as a result of the action of Mr Charles Copeman, of the New Right, a decision was taken to sack 1,100 workers and toss them on to the scrap heap, all in the interests of good management, management's right to manage and destroying inefficient work practices. The company gave a list of work practices which it had not even calculated and it was not in a position to show these to the Industrial Commission of Western Australia when it asked for them. The company was not able to do so either when the Commission demanded the list some two or three weeks later. The comprehensive list, which the company says continues to grow, has still not been presented to the Industrial Commission in Western Australia.

In the past three or four months Robe River has been a scene of confrontation and disputation, bordering on violence in many cases. The economies of both Australia and Western Australia have been disrupted because of the vanguard actions of Peko Wallsend in its quest to destroy trade unionism in this country. I do not believe that these tactics will work. Innovative companies, such as Civil and Civic and Lend Lease and many others, will prove to the Copemans and the Hays of this world that trade unions are responsive, responsible and will exercise all the influence they can in the interests of this country and its people.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 August this year the Session Clerk of the Presbyterian Church of St Andrew in Canberra wrote to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) expressing the church's views on the film Hail Mary. I shall seek to incorporate the letter but I wish to refer to a few parts of it. The letter invites the Attorney-General to fulfil his duty as the responsible Minister to have the film withdrawn because the church regards the film as in breach of the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations. It claims that the film is both pornographic and blasphemous and there are many other issues that it deals with in the letter. It was certainly a surprise to me to find that the reply came not from the Attorney-General himself, not from the Secretary to the Department, but from a secretary on behalf of a secretary for the Secretary to the Department. It was about fourth hand. That letter states that the film is not blasphemous or indecent as classified by the Film Censorship Board. It went on to state that the Attorney had received some 18,000 signatures on a petition inviting him to act and that the Attorney-General wrote to the Chief Censor requesting a review of the Censorship Board decision. However, the letter also points out that the Board has no power to review its decision. Other matters are set out in the reply. It also states that the New South Wales legislation enables the Attorney-General of that State to ask for a review. I would have thought that in the circumstances the Attorney-General might have written to the New South Wales Attorney to express some views on the matter. I also wonder whether he has taken any decision to review the legislation to enable a review of the decision of the Film Censorship Board. However, his letter does not convey that.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter to me from the Church of St Andrew states that the church regards the Attorney's reply as unsatisfactory, and I agree with it in terms of the way in which the letter is replied to and its content. That Hail Mary is intended as an intellectually and artistically serious film is not viewed by us as having ``redeeming merit''. Rather, such serious intention, or pretence, is viewed as compounding the offence. Dear Sir/Madam,
The Attorney-General, Mr Bowen has asked me to reply to your recent letter concerning the exhibition of the film ``Hail Mary''.
The film was examined by the Film Censorship Board and this Board unanimously was of the opinion that the film was neither blasphemous nor indecent.The Board classified it as an ``R'' film.

The Attorney-General has subsequently received many representations objecting to the registration and exhibition of the film, and he received a deputation from objectors who presented him with a petition of some 18,000 signatures expressing deep concern at the reported content of the film. Mr Bowen forwarded this petition to the Chief Censor with a request that in view of the public interest would the Board have the opportunity to reconsider its decision and particularly address the issue of blasphemy as is relevant under Regulation 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations.
The Board has sought advice as to its powers in respect of Mr Bowen's request, and advice has now been furnished that the Board does not have the power of review of its decisions.

With respect to the issue of blasphemy, Mr Bowen advised that this issue requires an examination of the film in the light of principles developed by the courts on what constitutes blasphemy at law. This virtually places the Board in the position of a jury and, unless the Board is of the opinion that the film is blasphemous, that ground for refusing registration does not apply.

The Attorney-General has received requests from a firm of solicitors that he grant his fiat to allow proceedings to be taken under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 concerning the licensing and registration of the film. A recent decision of the Federal Court, denied standing to two members of the Clergy who sought a review by the Court, of the Board's decision under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

The New South Wales legislation under the film and Videotape Classification Act 1984 enables the Attorney-General of that State to apply to the Appeals Censor for a review of the classification of the film.

In the declaration she crossed out the words which said that she had been told about her rights and obligations, but the answers to her questions were taken back to the Department by the officer.

SPEECH.PARA: She suggested to me that it might not be a bad idea if people were treated in an honest fashion by the Department's officers.
